questions.text: The LH surge is principally due to which of the following hormonal changes? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sustained/marked rise in Estrogen

 

The LH surge is triggered by a sustained peak level of estrogen for 24-48 hours in the late follicular phase, which results in a positive feedback effect on the anterior pituitary. When estradiol reaches beyond the critical level of 200 pg/mL and is sustained for about 48 hours, it exerts this positive feedback action to LH. This sustained estrogen elevation is essential for triggering the preovulatory LH surge that initiates ovulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Falling FSH levels: This is incorrect because falling FSH levels do not trigger the LH surge. In fact, during the late follicular phase, there is actually a preovulatory FSH surge that accompanies the LH surge, though smaller in magnitude.

 

Option C. Rise in Progesterone: While there is a trace amount of 17-α-hydroxy progesterone formed prior to ovulation, it's not the primary trigger for LH surge. Rather, this small progesterone rise facilitates the positive feedback action of estrogen for the LH and FSH surge.

 

Option D. Rise in Prostaglandins: Prostaglandins play a role in the actual process of follicular rupture during ovulation, but are not responsible for triggering the LH surge. They are produced in response to the LH surge rather than being its cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The midcycle LH surge is triggered by sustained high estradiol levels (>200 pg/mL for 48 hours) acting through positive feedback on the anterior pituitary - a critical mechanism that differs from estrogen's typical negative feedback effect seen during other phases of the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: following intrauterine contraceptive devices does not need to be replaced even after 3-5 years of use? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CuT 380A

 

CuT 380A has the longest lifespan among the options provided. It contains 380 mm² of copper (314 mm² on the stem and 33 mm² on each arm) and can remain effective for up to 10 years before requiring replacement. This makes it the only option that doesn't need replacement within the 3-5 year timeframe mentioned in the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CuT 200: This device has a much shorter lifespan of only 3 years. It contains 200 mm² of copper wire with 120 mg of copper and must be removed and replaced after this period.

 

Option B. CuT 375: This appears to refer to Multiload 375, which needs replacement after 5 years. This would require replacement at the upper limit of the timeframe mentioned in the question.

 

Option D. Multiload Cu devices: These devices have shorter lifespans than CuT 380A. The Multiload Cu 250 requires replacement every 3 years, while the Multiload 375 requires replacement every 5 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The CuT 380A is distinguished by its exceptionally long effective lifespan of 10 years, making it the most long-lasting copper intrauterine device available and an excellent choice for women seeking extended but reversible contraception without frequent replacements.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a germ cell ovarian tumor? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Granulosa cell tumor

 

Granulosa cell tumor is not a germ cell tumor but rather a sex cord-stromal tumor of the ovary. Ovarian tumors are classified into three main categories: surface epithelial tumors, germ cell tumors, and sex cord-stromal tumors. Granulosa cell tumors produce estrogen and contain characteristic histological features including Call-Exner bodies and coffee bean nuclei.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Dysgerminoma: Dysgerminoma is correctly classified as a germ cell tumor. It is the most common malignant germ cell tumor, accounting for 30-40% of malignant germ cell tumors. It occurs typically in young women and is characterized by "fried egg appearance" histologically and elevation of LDH as a tumor marker.

 

Option B: Endodermal sinus tumor: Also known as yolk sac tumor, endodermal sinus tumor is properly classified as a germ cell tumor. It's characterized by Schiller-Duval bodies on histopathology and has alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) as its tumor marker.

 

Option D: Choriocarcinoma: Non-gestational choriocarcinoma of the ovary is correctly classified as a germ cell tumor. It's a highly malignant tumor that produces hCG as its tumor marker.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granulosa cell tumor is a sex cord-stromal tumor characterized by Call-Exner bodies, coffee bean nuclei, and estrogen production leading to symptoms of estrogen excess like heavy menstrual bleeding or precocious puberty.

 

Classification of Ovarian Tumours

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with abdominal distension, pelvic pain, and respiratory distress. Clinical examination reveals ascites, and CA-125 levels are elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CA-ovary

 

The clinical presentation of a 55-year-old woman with abdominal distension, pelvic pain, respiratory distress, ascites, and elevated CA-125 levels is highly suggestive of ovarian cancer. Ovarian malignancy commonly presents with these symptoms, especially in postmenopausal women. CA-125 is the specific tumor marker for epithelial ovarian cancer, with elevated levels strongly supporting this diagnosis. The respiratory distress may be due to pleural effusion, which is a known complication of advanced ovarian malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: CA-cervix Cervical cancer typically presents with abnormal vaginal bleeding, postcoital bleeding, or foul-smelling discharge. Although advanced cervical cancer can cause pelvic pain, ascites is not a common presentation. Most importantly, CA-125 is not the tumor marker for cervical cancer. Cervical cancer spreads locally to parametrium and via lymphatics rather than producing ascites in its typical progression pattern.

 

Option C: CA-lung Lung cancer commonly presents with respiratory symptoms such as cough, hemoptysis, and dyspnea. While lung cancer can metastasize to various sites including the abdomen, the combination of ascites, pelvic pain, and elevated CA-125 is not characteristic. CA-125 is not a primary tumor marker for lung cancer.

 

Option D: Lymphoma Lymphoma can present with constitutional symptoms like fever, night sweats, and weight loss. While lymphoma can cause ascites, elevated CA-125 is not a typical finding for lymphoma. Additionally, lymphadenopathy would be a more common finding in lymphoma than ascites with pelvic pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triad of abdominal distension with ascites, pelvic pain, and elevated CA-125 in a postmenopausal woman is highly suggestive of epithelial ovarian cancer and warrants urgent gynecologic oncology evaluation.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to occur during a normal pregnancy? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Elevated systolic blood pressure

 

Elevated systolic blood pressure is least likely to occur during normal pregnancy. In fact, blood pressure typically decreases slightly during pregnancy, with the maximum drop occurring in the second trimester. This physiological change happens despite increased cardiac output because there is a corresponding decrease in systemic vascular resistance (SVR decreases by 21%) and peripheral vasodilation. Blood pressure normally begins to return to pre-pregnancy levels near term.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased heart rate: This is a normal physiological change in pregnancy. Heart rate increases by approximately 15-17% during pregnancy, typically rising about 15 beats per minute from baseline. This contributes to the overall increase in cardiac output needed to support the pregnancy.

 

Option C. Increased cardiac output: This is a well-documented normal change in pregnancy. Cardiac output increases progressively by about 40% above non-pregnant levels, reaching its peak around 30-34 weeks. This increase is due to both increased stroke volume (↑25%) and increased heart rate (↑15%).

 

Option D. Increased blood volume: Blood volume increases significantly during normal pregnancy by approximately 40%. Plasma volume increases even more, by about 40-50%, resulting in physiological hemodilution. This expanded blood volume supports the growing fetus and helps protect against blood loss during delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While normal pregnancy causes significant cardiovascular adaptations including increased heart rate, cardiac output, and blood volume, blood pressure typically decreases slightly due to peripheral vasodilation and reduced systemic vascular resistance, making elevated systolic blood pressure the physiological change least likely to occur in normal pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the active management of the third stage of labor? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Early cord clamping

 

Active Management of Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) consists of specific interventions designed to prevent postpartum hemorrhage. The standard components include administration of uterotonic drugs immediately after delivery of the baby, controlled cord traction for placental delivery, and uterine massage after placental delivery. Early cord clamping is not currently emphasized as a core component of AMTSL in modern obstetric practice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Controlled cord traction: This is a fundamental component of AMTSL. After administration of uterotonics, gentle traction is applied to the umbilical cord while counter-pressure is applied to the uterus to facilitate placental delivery while preventing uterine inversion.

 

Option C. Injection Methergine (Ergometrine): This uterotonic medication is used in the management of the third stage of labor. The dose is 0.2mg IV/IM with onset of action in 2-7 minutes and duration of 2-7 hours. While it has contraindications in hypertensive patients, it remains a component of AMTSL when appropriate.

 

Option D. Injection Syntocinon (Oxytocin): This is the primary uterotonic agent used in AMTSL. The standard dose is 10 units IM/IV with onset in 1-3 minutes. It promotes effective uterine contraction after delivery of the baby to minimize blood loss and facilitate placental separation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

AMTSL consists of administration of uterotonics (oxytocin or ergometrine when appropriate), controlled cord traction, and uterine massage after placental delivery, with early cord clamping no longer being emphasized as a core component of this protocol.

choices.text: The head was engaged at the time of presentation
The cervicograph progress is satisfactory
The cervicograph status suggests that intervention is likely to be required
The cervicograph on repeat examination would touch the action line

questions.text: A G3P1A1 woman is admitted to the labor room at term with a cervix dilated to 4 cm, intact membranes, and the fetal head palpable at 3/5 per abdomen. After 4 hours, a repeat examination shows the cervix dilated to 5 cm with an unchanged station, and the cervicograph remains on the right side of the alert line. Which of the following statements about the progress of labor is correct? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The cervicograph status suggests that intervention is likely to be required

 

This question is based on the WHO modified partograph, the cervicograph status suggests that intervention is likely to be required. Active labor begins at 5 cm cervical dilatation. The patient progressed from 4 cm to only 5 cm in 4 hours, which is significantly slower than the expected rate. The cervicograph remaining on the right side of the alert line is an indication of slow progress. This slow progression, combined with the unchanged station of the fetal head, indicates that intervention may be necessary.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. The head was engaged at the time of presentation: This is incorrect because the head was palpable at 3/5 per abdomen. Engagement is defined when the head is palpable at 2/5 or less above the symphysis pubis. At 3/5, the head is considered "not engaged."

 

Option B. The cervicograph progress is satisfactory: The progress is not satisfactory as it has fallen to the right of the alert line, indicating slower than expected dilation.

 

Option D. The cervicograph on repeat examination would touch the action line: The action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. Since the repeat examination was done at 4 hours and the cervicograph was only on the right side of the alert line (not specifically at the action line), this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When labor progress falls to the right of the alert line on a partograph, it signals slow progress requiring careful assessment for potential intervention, as it indicates deviation from the expected normal labor pattern.

choices.text: The first twin has a higher risk of birth asphyxia
The second twin has a higher risk of Hyaline Membrane Disease
The first twin has a higher risk of mortality
The second twin has a higher risk of intracranial hemorrhage

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the vaginal preterm delivery of twins is accurate? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The second twin has a higher risk of intracranial hemorrhage

 

The second twin faces significantly higher risks during delivery compared to the first twin. After the first twin is delivered, there is retraction of the uterus leading to placental insufficiency, which compromises oxygenation. Additionally, there is increased operative interference and higher incidence of cord prolapse for the second twin. These factors contribute to increased risk of birth trauma, including intracranial hemorrhage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The first twin has a higher risk of birth asphyxia: This is incorrect. The second twin is more likely to experience asphyxia due to placental insufficiency following delivery of the first twin, cord prolapse, and potential birth trauma from operative intervention.

 

Option B. The second twin has a higher risk of Hyaline Membrane Disease: This is incorrect as Hyaline Membrane Disease (RDS) is primarily related to gestational age and lung maturity, not birth order in twins.

 

Option C. The first twin has a higher risk of mortality: This is incorrect. During delivery, the second baby is more at risk (50%) than the first one due to uterine retraction, placental insufficiency, and increased operative interference.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The second twin has significantly higher perinatal risks during delivery, including intracranial hemorrhage, due to placental insufficiency, increased operative interventions, and higher rates of malpresentation and cord prolapse.

questions.text: How does the Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) change in pre-eclampsia? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreases

 

In pre-eclampsia, there is reduced glomerular filtration rate due to pathophysiological changes in the kidneys. The reduction is approximately 25% compared to normal pregnancy. This occurs because of spasm of the afferent glomerular arterioles and endothelial changes that lead to glomerular endotheliosis. The kidneys show enlarged glomeruli with swollen endothelial cells, which narrows the capillary lumen and impedes filtration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B (Increases): This is incorrect as pre-eclampsia causes vasoconstriction and endothelial dysfunction, leading to decreased renal perfusion and reduced GFR, not increased GFR.

 

Option C (Remains the same): This is incorrect as pre-eclampsia definitely affects renal function, specifically reducing GFR rather than leaving it unchanged.

 

Option D (None of the above): This is incorrect as option A correctly identifies the GFR change.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Pre-eclampsia causes endothelial dysfunction and renal vasoconstriction leading to reduced glomerular filtration rate, which contributes to the proteinuria commonly seen in this disorder.

questions.text: A 39-year-old gravida 4 para 3 woman presents to the antenatal clinic with her last menstrual period being 8 weeks ago. She reports no history of bleeding or pain. During her visit, VDRL-RPR tests come back positive, and the confirmatory microhemagglutination assay for antibodies to Treponema pallidum (MHA-TP) also returns positive. What is the best pharmacotherapy for her condition? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Penicillin

 

For syphilis in pregnancy, benzathine penicillin is the treatment of choice. The standard therapy for primary or secondary or early latent syphilis (<1 year duration) before 21+6 weeks of gestation is benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units intramuscularly as a single dose. This patient at 8 weeks gestation with positive VDRL-RPR and confirmatory MHA-TP tests requires prompt treatment with penicillin to prevent vertical transmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A (Erythromycin): While sometimes used in penicillin-allergic patients, erythromycin is not the first choice therapy for syphilis in pregnancy and has poorer efficacy for fetal treatment.

 

Option B (Azithromycin): This is only recommended if the patient is allergic to penicillin, and would be given as a 2g single dose. It is not the first-line therapy.

 

Option D (Tetracycline): This is contraindicated in pregnancy as it can cause dental discoloration and inhibition of bone growth in the fetus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Benzathine penicillin is the gold standard treatment for syphilis in pregnancy, regardless of the stage of infection, as it effectively treats both maternal infection and prevents congenital syphilis.

choices.text: Transmission most commonly occurs during early gestation
Majority of fetuses are not infected even without any intervention
The risk of mother-to-child transmission can be reduced by elective cesarean section
The risk is related to the status of infection in the mother

questions.text: Which of the following statements about mother-to-child transmission (MTCT) of HIV is incorrect? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transmission most commonly occurs during early gestation

 

HIV transmission from mother to child does not most commonly occur during early gestation. Vertical transmission primarily happens during labor and delivery or through breastfeeding. The intrapartum period represents the highest risk time for transmission, not early pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. is correct. Without any intervention, approximately 75% of infants born to HIV-positive mothers will not be infected. The natural transmission rate is about 25-30% without preventive measures.

 

Option C. is correct. Elective cesarean section significantly reduces mother-to-child transmission by minimizing fetal exposure to maternal blood and secretions during delivery. It's one of several interventions that can reduce transmission risk.

 

Option D. is correct. The risk of transmission is directly related to maternal viral load and disease status. Mothers with higher viral loads or advanced disease are more likely to transmit the virus to their infants.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

HIV vertical transmission occurs primarily during labor, delivery, and breastfeeding rather than early gestation, and can be significantly reduced through interventions including antiretroviral therapy, cesarean delivery, and avoidance of breastfeeding.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is strictly contraindicated during pregnancy? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methotrexate

 

Methotrexate is strictly contraindicated during pregnancy as it's classified as an FDA Category X drug. It poses proven fetal risks that clearly outweigh any possible therapeutic benefit. Methotrexate is an antimetabolite that causes craniofacial, axial skeletal, and gastrointestinal malformations in the developing fetus. Its teratogenic effects are severe enough to warrant complete avoidance during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cyclosporine: While cyclosporine is a cytotoxic drug that might cause immune suppression in breastfed infants, it is not strictly contraindicated during pregnancy. Cytotoxic drugs may cause teratogenic effects in the first trimester, but cyclosporine is not classified in Category X.

 

Option C. Chloroquine: Chloroquine shows no evidence of fetal toxicity when used in therapeutic doses for malaria. The benefits of chloroquine treatment typically outweigh the risks during pregnancy, making it acceptable for use when indicated.

 

Option D. Pyrazinamide: While caution is advised with most medications during pregnancy, pyrazinamide is not identified as strictly contraindicated in pregnancy in the way methotrexate is.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate is a Category X medication with proven severe teratogenic effects, making it absolutely contraindicated during pregnancy regardless of potential therapeutic benefits

questions.text: The maternal use of which of the following hormones is most likely to cause hypospadias in a male child? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diethylstilbestrol

 

Diethylstilbestrol (DES) is a synthetic estrogen that can disrupt normal fetal development, particularly affecting the reproductive tract. DES exposure during pregnancy, especially around 20 weeks of gestation, is associated with reproductive tract anomalies. Hormonal agents with estrogen-like or progestational effects can interfere with normal genital development in the male fetus, leading to conditions such as hypospadias, where the urethral opening is located on the underside of the penis instead of at the tip.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tolbutamide: This is an oral hypoglycemic agent used to treat diabetes, not a hormone. Tolbutamide does not have significant effects on fetal genital development and has not been linked to hypospadias in male offspring.

 

Option B. Clomiphene: This is an anti-estrogen medication used for ovulation induction. While it affects hormonal pathways, it is not typically administered during pregnancy and has not been documented to cause hypospadias in male offspring.

 

Option D. Clonazepam: This is a benzodiazepine with anxiolytic, anticonvulsant, and sedative properties. Benzodiazepines can cause neonatal effects like hypotonia and withdrawal symptoms, but are not known to cause structural genital abnormalities like hypospadias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exposure to hormonal agents during critical periods of fetal development can disrupt normal genital formation, with synthetic estrogens like DES posing particular risk for urogenital abnormalities.

questions.text: Mobius syndrome in a fetus may be caused by the maternal intake of which of the following medications? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Misoprostol

 

Misoprostol has been clearly documented as causing Mobius sequency in fetuses when mothers take it during pregnancy. This condition is characterized by facial palsy and limb abnormalities. The teratogenic effect specifically affects cranial nerve development, resulting in the characteristic facial paralysis seen in Mobius syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mifepristone: While mifepristone is used for medical abortion, it has not been associated with Mobius syndrome specifically. It functions primarily as a progesterone receptor antagonist rather than causing cranial nerve developmental defects.

 

Option C. Dinoprostone: Dinoprostone (prostaglandin E2) is not linked to Mobius syndrome. It is commonly used for cervical ripening and labor induction but lacks the specific teratogenic effect on cranial nerve development that would lead to Mobius syndrome.

 

Option D. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is associated with craniosynostosis (clover leaf skull) but not with Mobius syndrome. As a folic acid antagonist, methotrexate affects rapidly dividing cells and can cause various congenital abnormalities, but Mobius syndrome is not among them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Misoprostol exposure during pregnancy can cause Mobius syndrome (facial palsy and limb abnormalities), making it crucial to avoid during early fetal development.

questions.text: Which of the following metabolic changes is most commonly associated with hyperemesis gravidarum? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyperthyroidism

 

Hyperthyroidism is the metabolic change most commonly associated with hyperemesis gravidarum. This connection exists because of the similarity in structure between hCG and TSH. During pregnancy, especially in the first trimester when hyperemesis occurs, hCG has intrinsic thyrotropic activity that can lead to a state of physiological hyperthyroidism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypernatremia is not typically associated with hyperemesis gravidarum. In fact, with severe vomiting, patients are more likely to develop hyponatremia due to fluid losses and potential water retention from ADH release.

 

Option C. Hyperchloremia is not a characteristic metabolic change in hyperemesis gravidarum. Electrolyte disturbances are common, but typically manifest as hypochloremia due to loss of chloride in vomitus.

 

Option D. Hyperkalemia is not associated with hyperemesis gravidarum. Severe vomiting more commonly leads to hypokalemia due to potassium loss in vomitus and secondary aldosteronism from volume depletion.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hyperemesis gravidarum is associated with hyperthyroidism due to the thyrotropic activity of elevated hCG levels, which can mimic TSH action on thyroid receptors.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of breech presentation in pregnancy? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prematurity

 

Prematurity is the most common cause of breech presentation in pregnancy. In premature deliveries, the fetus hasn't yet had sufficient time to assume the normal vertex position. The fetal head is relatively larger compared to the body in premature fetuses, and this difference in proportion contributes to the higher likelihood of breech presentation. Additionally, in earlier gestational ages, there is more amniotic fluid relative to fetal size, allowing the fetus greater mobility to maintain or assume a breech position.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Cephalopelvic disproportion: This refers to a mismatch between the size of the fetal head and the maternal pelvis, making vaginal delivery difficult or impossible. While this is an important obstetric complication, it doesn't cause breech presentation; rather, it affects the progress of labor with a cephalic presentation.

 

Option C. Polyhydramnios: While excessive amniotic fluid can contribute to abnormal presentations including breech by allowing increased fetal mobility, it is not the most common cause of breech presentation. Polyhydramnios is less common than prematurity.

 

Option D. None: This option is incorrect because prematurity is clearly established as the most common cause of breech presentation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Prematurity is the predominant cause of breech presentation due to the relative proportions of the fetal body parts and increased mobility in the amniotic fluid during earlier gestational ages.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most frequently occurring Occiput-posterior position? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right Occiput-posterior

 

Right Occiput-posterior (ROP) is the most common occiput posterior position. ROP is more common than left occipito-posterior (LOP) because the left oblique diameter is reduced by the presence of sigmoid colon. In fact, Right occiput posterior is five times more common than the left occiput posterior. Dextrorotation of the uterus and the presence of the sigmoid colon on the left disfavor LOP position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct Occiput-posterior: This is less common than ROP. Direct occiput posterior occurs when the occiput rotates 1/8 circle posteriorly following short arc rotation in cases of marked deflexion.

 

Option C. Left Occiput-posterior: While LOP does occur, it is significantly less common than ROP. ROP is five times more common than LOP due to the presence of the sigmoid colon on the left side.

 

Option D. Indirect Occiput-posterior: This is not a standard classification of occiput posterior positions. The positions are classified as left, right, or direct occiput posterior.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Right occipito-posterior position is the most common OP position, occurring five times more frequently than left occipito-posterior, primarily due to anatomical factors including the presence of the sigmoid colon on the left side and dextrorotation of the uterus.

questions.text: What is the most common indication for performing a Posterior Colpotomy? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Drainage of Pelvic Abscess

 

The most common indication for performing a Posterior Colpotomy is the drainage of a pelvic abscess. This surgical procedure involves making an incision in the posterior fornix of the vagina, which provides direct access to the pelvic cavity. This approach is particularly useful for draining abscesses that may result from infections or inflammatory conditions within the pelvis.

 

Posterior Colpotomy has also been used for other indications, such as the removal of pelvic masses or assisting in laparoscopic vaginal hysterectomy. However, its primary and most frequent application remains the drainage of pelvic abscesses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tubal Sterilization: This procedure is rarely performed using a colpotomy approach, as it is generally done through less invasive methods like laparoscopy.

 

Option C. Removal of Pelvic Cyst: Although Posterior Colpotomy can be utilized for the removal of pelvic cysts, this is not its primary use. Laparoscopy is more commonly used for cyst removal.

 

Option D. Removal of Uterine Fibroid: Uterine fibroids are usually removed using more advanced techniques such as laparoscopy or hysteroscopy. While a colpotomy could technically be used, it is not the preferred method for fibroid removal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common reason for performing a Posterior Colpotomy is to drain a pelvic abscess, taking advantage of the direct access provided by the incision in the posterior vaginal fornix

questions.text: The softening of the lower uterine segment on bimanual examination is referred to as: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hegar's Sign

 

Hegar's sign refers specifically to the softening of the lower uterine segment that can be appreciated during bimanual examination in early pregnancy. This occurs due to hormonal changes causing increased vascularity and edema of the tissues. During bimanual examination, the examining fingers can be approximated between the cervix and the body of the uterus, giving the impression that the uterus and cervix are separate structures due to this marked softening of the isthmus or lower uterine segment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chadwick's Sign: Incorrect. Chadwick's sign refers to the bluish or purplish discoloration of the vagina and cervix due to increased vascularity during pregnancy. This is a visual sign rather than a palpable finding on bimanual examination.

 

Option C. Osiander's Sign: Incorrect. Osiander's sign refers to the pulsation of the uterine artery that can be felt through the lateral fornix during pregnancy. This is a vascular sign and not related to the softening of the lower uterine segment.

 

Option D. Goodell's Sign: Incorrect. Goodell's sign refers to the softening of the cervix during pregnancy. While this is also detected on vaginal examination, it specifically pertains to the cervix itself becoming softer and more velvety in texture, not the lower uterine segment between the cervix and uterine body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hegar's sign is a distinctive finding of early pregnancy where the lower uterine segment (isthmus) becomes remarkably soft, allowing the examining fingers to almost meet during bimanual examination, creating the impression that the cervix and uterine body are disconnected.

questions.text: If division occurs on the 7th day during twin gestation, the result would be: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diamnionic, monochorionic

 

When division of the embryonic mass occurs on the 7th day post-fertilization, the result is diamnionic, monochorionic twins. At this stage, the blastocyst has already formed the outer trophoblast layer (which develops into chorion) but the inner cell mass has not yet differentiated into the bilaminar disk and formed the amniotic cavity. Therefore, division at this point results in two separate embryos with their own amniotic cavities (diamnionic) but sharing a single chorion (monochorionic).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diamnionic, dichorionic: This type results from division occurring earlier, between days 0-3 after fertilization, when the zygote or early blastomeres split. At this early stage, each embryo develops its own chorion and amnion.

 

Option C. Monoamnionic, monochorionic: This results from division occurring later, between days 8-12, after the amniotic cavity has formed but before the embryonic disk differentiates. The embryos share both the amniotic cavity and chorion.

 

Option D. Conjoined twins: These result from incomplete division of the embryonic disk, typically occurring after day 13 post-fertilization, when the embryonic axis has begun to form. The division is incomplete, resulting in twins that are physically connected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The timing of embryonic division critically determines the amnionicity and chorionicity of twin pregnancies, with day 7 division specifically resulting in diamnionic, monochorionic twins due to the developmental stage of the trophoblast and inner cell mass at that point.

questions.text: The incidence of scar rupture in a previous lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) is approximately: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-2%

 

The incidence of scar rupture in a previous lower segment cesarean section is approximately 0.2-1.5%, which most closely corresponds to option A (1-2%). Lower segment scars have better healing properties compared to classical scars because of thinner cut margins that facilitate perfect apposition, inertness of the lower segment during healing, and stretching that occurs along the line of the scar during future pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 2-3%: This represents the incidence of scar rupture in classical or hysterotomy scars (4-9%), not lower segment scars. Classical scars have poorer healing due to thick muscle layers, difficulty in apposition, and contraction of the upper segment during healing.

 

Option C. 3-4%: This percentage is significantly higher than documented rates for lower segment scar rupture and instead represents rates seen with T-shaped or J-shaped incisions (4-9%).

 

Option D. 4-5%: This is an excessively high estimate for lower segment scars. Even classical scars have rupture rates around 4-9%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lower segment cesarean scars have a significantly lower rupture rate (0.2-1.5%) compared to classical scars (4-9%) due to better anatomical and physiological healing factors, making VBAC a reasonable option for properly selected patients with prior low transverse incisions

questions.text: The term Couvelaire uterus is associated with: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Uteroplacental Apoplexy

 

Couvelaire uterus, also known as uteroplacental apoplexy, results from bleeding into the myometrium in cases of placental abruption. This occurs when blood from the retroplacental hematoma extravasates into the myometrium, causing the uterine musculature to be infiltrated with blood. The myometrium appears purple-blue with ecchymotic patches. This pathology is associated with severe forms of abruptio placentae.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Placenta Previa: Placenta previa refers to the abnormal implantation of the placenta in the lower uterine segment, partially or completely covering the internal cervical os. It is characterized by painless vaginal bleeding, not myometrial infiltration with blood. There is no connection between placenta previa and Couvelaire uterus.

 

Option C. Pregnancy-Induced Hypertension: While hypertensive disorders of pregnancy can increase the risk of placental abruption (which may lead to Couvelaire uterus), PIH itself is a distinct condition characterized by elevated blood pressure developing after 20 weeks of gestation. PIH is not directly associated with the hemorrhagic infiltration of the myometrium.

 

Option D. Postpartum Hemorrhage: Postpartum hemorrhage refers to excessive bleeding after childbirth, typically defined as blood loss exceeding 500 mL after vaginal delivery or 1000 mL after cesarean delivery. It is a complication occurring after delivery, whereas Couvelaire uterus develops during pregnancy as a complication of placental abruption.

 

Educational Objective:

Couvelaire uterus represents myometrial infiltration with blood following retroplacental hemorrhage in abruptio placentae, clinically recognized as uteroplacental apoplexy with characteristic purple-blue discoloration of the uterus

choices.text: May be seen in Intrauterine Pregnancy
May be seen in Ectopic Pregnancy

questions.text: All of the following statements about Arias-Stella Reaction are true, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Follicular Endometrium

 

The Arias-Stella reaction is characterized by hypersecretory changes in the endometrial glands in response to high levels of chorionic gonadotropin. It shows nuclear enlargement, hyperchromasia, and cytoplasmic vacuolization of the endometrial glandular cells. This reaction represents a hypersecretory endometrium, not a follicular (proliferative) endometrium. The reaction is observed in both intrauterine and ectopic pregnancies as it is a hormonal response to hCG regardless of implantation site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. May be seen in Intrauterine Pregnancy: This is a true statement. Arias-Stella reaction is commonly observed in intrauterine pregnancies as the endometrium responds to the high levels of hCG produced by the developing trophoblast.

 

Option B. May be seen in Ectopic Pregnancy: This is a true statement. Even when implantation occurs outside the uterus (ectopic pregnancy), the circulating hCG can still stimulate the endometrial glands to undergo the Arias-Stella reaction.

 

Option C. Hyper-secretory Endometrium: This is a true statement. The Arias-Stella reaction is characterized by hypersecretory changes in the endometrial glands, with distinctive nuclear and cytoplasmic alterations that differ from typical secretory changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Arias-Stella reaction represents a hypersecretory endometrial change in response to hCG that can occur in both intrauterine and ectopic pregnancies, but it is not associated with follicular (proliferative) endometrial patterns which are estrogen-dependent rather than progesterone/hCG-dependent.

questions.text: At 28 weeks gestation, amniocentesis reveals AOD450 in Liley's Zone 3. What is the best line of management? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans B) Intrauterine transfusion

 

Liley's Zone 3 indicates severe fetal hemolysis requiring immediate intervention. When amniocentesis at 28 weeks reveals AOD450 (optical density difference at 450 nm) in Zone 3, this represents critical fetal hemolysis due to Rh isoimmunization. The spectrophotometric analysis of bilirubin in amniotic fluid directly predicts the severity of fetal hemolysis. With values in Zone 3, intrauterine transfusion is indicated to correct fetal anemia while allowing continued fetal development in utero.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate delivery: At 28 weeks, immediate delivery would expose the infant to significant prematurity risks. The fetus is not yet mature enough for delivery when intrauterine transfusion can correct the hemolysis while allowing continued intrauterine development.

 

Option C. Repeat amniocentesis after 1 week: Zone 3 indicates severe hemolysis requiring immediate intervention. Delaying treatment for a week would expose the fetus to continued severe hemolysis, potentially leading to hydrops fetalis or fetal death.

 

Option D. Plasmapheresis: Plasmapheresis is not indicated in the management of fetal hemolytic disease. This therapy doesn't directly address the fetal anemia, which is the immediate concern. The direct approach is to correct fetal anemia through intrauterine transfusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Rh isoimmunization with severe fetal hemolysis (AOD450 in Liley's Zone 3) at 28 weeks, intrauterine transfusion is the optimal management to correct fetal anemia while allowing for continued fetal maturation in utero.

questions.text: Which of the following medications may be safely discontinued with minimal risk of adverse effects before an abdominal surgery? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ACE Inhibitors/Angiotensin Receptor Blockers

 

ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) should be omitted on the day of surgery. According to pre-anesthetic evaluation guidelines, while most antihypertensive medications are continued, ACE inhibitors and ARBs are specifically recommended to be withheld due to an increased risk of significant intraoperative hypotension when taken on the morning of surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Statins: These should be continued perioperatively to maintain lipid control and vascular protection.

 

Option B. Beta Blockers: These should be continued on the day of surgery. Abrupt discontinuation can lead to rebound hypertension, tachycardia, and an increased risk of myocardial ischemia.

 

Option D. Steroids: Patients on chronic steroid therapy should continue their regular dose and receive supplemental IV hydrocortisone perioperatively. Discontinuing steroids can lead to adrenal insufficiency and hemodynamic instability during surgical stress.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While most chronic medications are continued perioperatively, ACE inhibitors and ARBs should be withheld on the day of surgery to reduce the risk of intraoperative hypotension. In contrast, beta blockers, statins, and steroids should be continued to avoid potential complications.

choices.text: Increased nicotine levels may elevate sympathetic tone.
Increased carboxyhaemoglobin levels may cause a rightward shift in the oxyhaemoglobin dissociation curve.
Reduced pulmonary capacity can result from diminished ciliary function and decreased surfactant production.
The risk of infection is heightened due to impaired immune function.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the impact of smoking on a chronic smoker scheduled for elective surgery is incorrect? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased carboxyhaemoglobin levels may cause a rightward shift in the oxyhaemoglobin dissociation curve.

 

Smoking increases carboxyhaemoglobin levels, which causes a leftward shift of the oxygen dissociation curve. This leftward shift means hemoglobin holds onto oxygen more tightly, impairing oxygen delivery to tissues. Smoking cessation for at least 12 hours before surgery decreases carboxyhaemoglobin levels, shifting the curve rightward and improving tissue oxygenation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased nicotine levels may elevate sympathetic tone: Nicotine stimulates sympathetic activity, which increases the risk of arrhythmias during anesthesia. Reduced nicotine levels from smoking cessation decrease this risk.

 

Option C. Reduced pulmonary capacity can result from diminished ciliary function and decreased surfactant production:  Smoking impairs ciliary function, increases mucus production, and reduces surfactant, leading to reduced pulmonary capacity.

 

Option D. The risk of infection is heightened due to impaired immune function: Smoking suppresses immune response, making infections more likely, especially in the postoperative period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Smoking increases carboxyhaemoglobin, causing a leftward shift of the oxygen dissociation curve and impairing oxygen delivery. Smoking cessation (even just 12 hours before surgery) helps reverse this effect and improves tissue oxygenation.

questions.text: In a patient with chronic renal failure, which of the following anesthetic drugs is contraindicated due to the risk of toxicity? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pethidine

 

Pethidine (meperidine) is contraindicated in chronic renal failure due to the accumulation of its active metabolite, norpethidine. Norpethidine has a longer half-life than the parent drug and is neurotoxic, potentially causing seizures, tremors, agitation, and myoclonus. Since renal excretion is impaired in chronic kidney disease, norpethidine accumulates, increasing the risk of central nervous system toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Morphine: Morphine does have active metabolites (notably morphine-6-glucuronide) that accumulate in renal failure, potentially leading to sedation and respiratory depression. However, it is not absolutely contraindicated—it can be used with dose adjustments and close monitoring.

 

Option B. Fentanyl: Fentanyl is the opioid of choice in renal impairment. It is metabolized in the liver and produces inactive metabolites, with minimal renal excretion, making it safe and predictable in patients with renal dysfunction.

 

Option D. Atracurium: Atracurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker that undergoes Hofmann elimination (a temperature and pH-dependent degradation process) and ester hydrolysis, making it independent of renal or hepatic clearance. It is thus safe and preferred in renal failure, particularly during surgeries involving renal function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Avoid pethidine in renal failure due to the risk of toxic metabolite accumulation. Opt for safer alternatives like fentanyl and atracurium, which have predictable pharmacokinetics and are less dependent on renal clearance.

choices.text: Increases the risk of malignant hyperthermia

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Total Intra-Venous Anesthesia (TIVA)? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reduces cerebral metabolic rate

 

Propofol, the primary induction agent used in TIVA, decreases cerebral metabolic rate (CMR), cerebral blood flow (CBF), and intracranial tension (ICT). These effects make propofol especially advantageous for neurosurgical procedures. When combined with remifentanil, it offers excellent hemodynamic stability and rapid recovery due to their short elimination half-lives. This combination makes TIVA particularly suitable for day-care surgeries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Causes increased renal toxicity: Propofol does not cause significant renal toxicity. It is primarily metabolized in the liver, with about 30% extrahepatic metabolism occurring in the kidneys and lungs. Its metabolites are inactive and do not accumulate to cause toxicity.

 

Option C. Increases the risk of malignant hyperthermia: Propofol is actually the induction agent of choice in patients susceptible to malignant hyperthermia, as it does not trigger this condition.

 

Option D. Inhibits hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction: This effect is more commonly associated with volatile anesthetic agents. Propofol has minimal impact on hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction compared to inhalational agents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Total Intravenous Anesthesia (TIVA) using propofol and remifentanil reduces cerebral metabolic rate, provides stable hemodynamics, enables quick recovery, and is ideal for both neurosurgical and day-care surgical procedures.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms explains the cerebroprotective effect of Thiopentone? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreased cerebral metabolism

 

Thiopentone offers cerebroprotection primarily by reducing cerebral metabolism. It decreases cerebral oxygen consumption (CMO₂), cerebral metabolic rate (CMR), and intracranial tension (ICT). This makes it particularly useful for cerebral protection in cases of focal ischemia, where reducing the brain’s metabolic demands helps limit damage during periods of impaired perfusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduction of vasospasm: Although thiopentone can have some vascular effects, there is no evidence that it reduces vasospasm. In fact, due to its high alkalinity, intra-arterial injection of thiopentone may actually provoke vasospasm.

 

Option C. Calcium channel blockade: Thiopentone does not act via calcium channels. Its primary mechanism is through potentiation of GABA-A receptors, increasing chloride ion conductance and leading to neuronal hyperpolarization. It also suppresses excitatory neurotransmission.

 

Option D. Free radical removal: There is no indication that thiopentone acts as a free radical scavenger. Its neuroprotective properties are attributed to its ability to decrease metabolic demand in the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiopentone provides effective cerebroprotection in focal ischemia by lowering cerebral metabolic rate and oxygen consumption, thus reducing the brain's oxygen demand during compromised blood flow.

questions.text: Which of The following muscle relaxants injection causes maximal pain? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rocuronium

 

Rocuronium is known to cause the most intense injection pain among non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers. The pain is often immediate and described as burning or stinging, largely due to its low pH and osmolality, which irritate the vascular endothelium. Pain on injection can occur in 50–80% of patients when no pretreatment is given. To minimize discomfort, lidocaine pretreatment or administration after induction with propofol is commonly practiced.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Succinylcholine: Although succinylcholine may lead to postoperative myalgia, it typically does not cause pain on injection. Because it is administered rapidly after induction, any injection-related discomfort is rarely noticed.

 

Option B. Vecuronium: Vecuronium is virtually painless on injection. With a near-neutral pH, it is well tolerated and often selected when avoiding injection discomfort is important.

 

Option D. Cisatracurium: Cisatracurium causes minimal to no injection pain. It has a more stable pH and a lower propensity for histamine release compared to atracurium, its parent compound.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rocuronium causes the most injection pain among neuromuscular blockers, and pretreatment is often needed to reduce discomfort.

questions.text: During a surgical procedure, a patient's level of consciousness and awareness under anesthesia is most accurately monitored using: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bispectral Imaging (BIS Monitoring)

 

Bispectral index (BIS) monitoring is specifically designed to assess the depth of anesthesia by analyzing the patient’s electroencephalogram (EEG). It provides a numerical score from 0 to 100, correlating with levels of consciousness:

 

  • 0–40: Deep anesthesia
  • 40–60: Optimal range for surgical anesthesia
  • 60–100: Increasing levels of consciousness

 

Because BIS monitoring directly reflects brain electrical activity, it is considered the most accurate and objective tool for evaluating a patient’s level of awareness during anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulse Oximetry: Measures oxygen saturation (SpO₂) and heart rate, essential for monitoring oxygenation, but it offers no insight into the depth of anesthesia or consciousness.

 

Option B. Colour Doppler: A diagnostic tool for assessing blood flow in vessels using ultrasound. It plays no role in monitoring anesthesia depth or patient awareness.

 

Option D. End-Tidal CO₂ (Capnography): Monitors the exhaled carbon dioxide to assess ventilation status and confirm airway placement, but it does not assess consciousness or brain activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bispectral index (BIS) monitoring is the gold standard for assessing depth of anesthesia, offering a reliable, real-time measure of brain activity that guides anesthetic dosing and reduces the risk of intraoperative awareness.

questions.text: During intraoperative monitoring, which of the following evoked potentials is the most resistant to the effects of anesthesia? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brainstem Auditory Evoked Response (BAER)

 

BAER is the most resistant to the effects of anesthesia among the evoked potentials. While most anesthetic agents decrease amplitude and increase latency of evoked responses, BAER remains relatively stable. This stability makes BAER especially valuable for intraoperative monitoring of brainstem function, particularly during procedures involving the posterior fossa or auditory pathways.

 

Drugs such as etomidate, ketamine, opioids, and dexmedetomidine have minimal clinically significant impact on evoked potentials, which further supports the utility of BAER under general anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Visual Evoked Response (VER): VER is highly sensitive to anesthetic agents. The visual pathways are particularly susceptible to suppression, making VER less reliable during general anesthesia.

 

Option C. Somatosensory Evoked Potential (SSEP): SSEPs are moderately affected, especially by volatile anesthetics and propofol, which reduce amplitude and increase latency. Though useful, they are less stable than BAER under deep anesthesia.

 

Option D. Electroencephalogram (EEG): EEG records spontaneous brain activity, not evoked potentials. It is highly sensitive to anesthetic depth, which is why it's useful in depth-of-anesthesia monitors like BIS, but not reliable for consistent evoked potential monitoring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BAER is the most anesthesia-resistant evoked potential, making it ideal for monitoring brainstem integrity during neurosurgical procedures, especially under general anesthesia.

questions.text: A biopsy was performed on a patient with a recurrent chalazion involving the upper eyelid. What is the most likely diagnosis on histopathology? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sebaceous Cell Carcinoma

 

Sebaceous cell carcinoma can often masquerade as a recurrent chalazion, making it a diagnostic challenge. It arises from the meibomian glands and frequently involves the upper eyelid. This malignancy typically presents initially as a nodule that may be mistaken for a chalazion, more frequently on the upper eyelid. Recurrent chalazion that doesn't respond to conventional treatment should raise suspicion for this malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basal Cell Carcinoma: While this is the most common malignant tumor of the eyelids (90% of eyelid malignancies), it typically presents as a noduloulcerative lesion with pearly rolled margins (rodent ulcer). It most commonly affects the lower eyelid (50%) followed by medial canthus, and doesn't typically mimic a chalazion.

 

Option C. Squamous Cell Carcinoma: This presents as a scaly, erythematous plaque with elevated and indurated margins or occasionally as nodular/polypoidal growth. It commonly arises from the lid margin, not from the meibomian glands, and doesn't typically resemble a chalazion.

 

Option D. Malignant Melanoma: This rare eyelid tumor (less than 1% of eyelid lesions) presents as a pigmented, well-defined lesion that later becomes elevated, or as a nodular growth. It doesn't typically mimic a chalazion.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Recurrent chalazia, especially in older patients, should raise suspicion for sebaceous cell carcinoma, warranting histopathological examination to avoid misdiagnosis of this potentially lethal malignancy.

questions.text: A malnourished child from a poor socioeconomic background, living in overcrowded and unsanitary conditions, presents with a nodule around the limbus and redness of the surrounding conjunctiva in his left eye. The child also has axillary and cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phlyctenular Conjunctivitis

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests phlyctenular conjunctivitis. This condition is characterized by a nodular lesion (phlycten) occurring at the limbus with surrounding hyperemia. It typically affects children living in poor hygienic conditions who are undernourished. The unilateral presentation is also characteristic, as phlyctenular conjunctivitis is usually unilateral, in contrast to conditions like vernal keratoconjunctivitis which are bilateral.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foreign Body Granuloma: This is incorrect because foreign body granulomas typically have a history of trauma or foreign body entry. They also don't correlate with the socioeconomic factors and malnutrition mentioned in the case. Foreign body granulomas are common following squint surgery or inadequately scraped chalazion.

 

Option C. Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis: This is incorrect because vernal keratoconjunctivitis is typically bilateral, seasonal (worse in warm weather), and characterized by severe itching, papillary hypertrophy arranged in a "cobblestone" pattern, and ropy discharge. It's not specifically associated with poor socioeconomic conditions or malnutrition.

 

Option D. Episcleritis: This is incorrect because episcleritis presents with sectoral redness without discharge, is more common in adults, and is not specifically associated with poor living conditions or malnutrition. The nodular lesion at the limbus is not a typical feature of episcleritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction to endogenous microbial proteins, particularly common in malnourished children living in poor hygienic conditions, presenting as a characteristic whitish raised nodule on the bulbar conjunctiva with surrounding hyperemia

questions.text: A regular contact lens user presents with complaints of severe pain, redness, photophobia, and blurring of vision for more than two weeks, not responding to standard treatment. On examination, a paracentral ring-shaped lesion with stromal infiltrates and overlying epithelial defects is observed in the affected eye. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acanthamoeba keratitis

 

  • This is a classic presentation of Acanthamoeba keratitis. 
  • The key diagnostic features include:
    • History of contact lens use (most common risk factor)
    • Severe pain that is disproportionate to clinical signs
    • Ring infiltrate in the cornea (pathognomonic sign)
    • Non-responsive to conventional antimicrobial therapy
    • Chronicity of symptoms (over two weeks)

 

Supporting Evidence:

 

Acanthamoeba keratitis presents with characteristic ring infiltrates, central or paracentral, with overlying epithelial defects. The most common predisposing factor is contact lens wear, particularly with improper lens hygiene or exposure to contaminated water.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial keratitis:

 

  • Typically responds to antibiotics within days
  • Pain is proportionate to clinical signs
  • Most common organism in contact lens users is Pseudomonas (causes hypopyon ulcer)
  • Does not characteristically form ring infiltrates
  • Usually has quicker onset and progression

 

Option C. Viral keratitis:

 

  • Characterized by dendritic or geographic patterns (herpes simplex)
  • Usually has reduced corneal sensations
  • Responds to antiviral therapy
  • Does not form ring-shaped infiltrates
  • Often has history of recurrence

 

Option D. Fungal keratitis:

 

  • Typically has history of vegetative matter injury
  • Shows feathery margins with satellite lesions
  • Cheesy necrotic appearance of ulcer base
  • May have Wessley immune ring but not typical ring infiltrates as seen in Acanthamoeba
  • Signs are usually more prominent than symptoms

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ring-shaped stromal infiltrates in a contact lens wearer with severe pain disproportionate to clinical signs and non-responsive to conventional antimicrobial therapy is pathognomonic for Acanthamoeba keratitis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male from a rural background presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a history of difficulty in vision for 10 days. He reports that vegetative material fell into his left eye about 15 days ago. On examination, an ulcerative lesion in the cornea with feathery margins and creamy exudates is observed. A few satellite lesions are also noted. What is the most likely etiologic agent? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fusarium sp.

 

This is a clear case of fungal keratitis, most likely caused by Fusarium species. The key diagnostic features include:

 

  • History of vegetative matter injury (classic risk factor for fungal keratitis)
  • Feathery margins of the corneal ulcer (characteristic of fungal etiology)
  • Creamy exudates in the ulcer bed
  • Presence of satellite lesions (strongly suggestive of fungal etiology)
  • Rural background (increased exposure to vegetative materials)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corynebacterium diphtheriae:

 

  • Causes membranous conjunctivitis rather than corneal ulcers with feathery margins
  • Not typically associated with vegetative matter injury
  • Does not produce satellite lesions
  • Rare cause of keratitis in the modern era
  • Not associated with creamy exudates in the cornea

 

Option C. Acanthamoeba sp.:

 

  • Though associated with corneal ulcers, it commonly affects contact lens wearers
  • Presents with severe pain disproportionate to clinical signs
  • Characteristic ring infiltrate rather than feathery margins
  • Radial keratoneuritis is a pathognomonic early sign
  • Does not typically produce satellite lesions

 

Option D. Streptococcus pneumoniae:

 

  • Causes ulcus serpens (hypopyon corneal ulcer)
  • Has oval, yellowish-white densely opaque ulcer with sharply defined margins
  • No feathery margins or satellite lesions
  • Often associated with nasolacrimal duct obstruction
  • Typically produces hypopyon rather than creamy exudates

 

Educational Objective:

 

A corneal ulcer with feathery margins, satellite lesions, and history of vegetative matter injury strongly suggests fungal keratitis, with Fusarium species being the most common causative agent.

questions.text: The wavelength of the laser (in nanometers) used for shaping the cornea in refractive surgery is? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 193 nm

 

The excimer laser used for refractive surgery procedures like LASIK and PRK operates at a wavelength of 193 nanometers, which is in the ultraviolet (UV) range. This specific wavelength is produced by excited dimers (hence the name "excimer") of argon and fluoride gases. The 193 nm wavelength is precisely absorbed by corneal tissue, allowing for accurate photoablation of the corneal stroma without thermal damage to surrounding tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 451 nm: This is incorrect. 451 nm falls in the visible blue light spectrum and is not used for corneal refractive surgery. This wavelength would not provide the precise photoablative effect needed to reshape the cornea without thermal damage.

 

Option C. 532 nm: This is incorrect. The 532 nm wavelength is in the visible green light spectrum and is typically used in some ophthalmic laser procedures like selective laser trabeculoplasty (SLT) for glaucoma treatment, not for corneal refractive surgery.

 

Option D. 1064 nm: This is incorrect. The 1064 nm wavelength is in the near-infrared spectrum and is used in Nd: YAG lasers for posterior capsulotomy after cataract surgery or for peripheral iridotomy in angle-closure glaucoma. The femtosecond laser used to create corneal flaps in LASIK uses wavelengths around 1054 nm, but this is distinct from the excimer laser that actually reshapes the cornea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 193 nm ultraviolet excimer laser provides the precise ablation characteristics needed for corneal refractive procedures, allowing for accurate tissue removal without thermal damage to surrounding structures - a critical factor in achieving predictable visual outcomes in refractive surgery.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the ophthalmic outpatient department with gradual blurring of vision in the left eye. Slit-lamp examination reveals fine stellate keratic precipitates, aqueous flare, and a typical complicated posterior subcapsular cataract. No posterior synechiae were observed. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heterochromic Iridocyclitis of Fuch’s

 

Fuchs Heterochromic Iridocyclitis presents with a characteristic clinical picture that matches this case. The condition features fine stellate keratic precipitates distributed across the cornea and a low-grade anterior chamber inflammation with aqueous flare. A hallmark feature is the presence of posterior subcapsular cataract (PSC) as a complication. Most importantly, Fuchs specifically lacks posterior synechiae formation despite chronic inflammation, which is a distinguishing feature noted in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intermediate Uveitis (Pars Planitis): This condition primarily affects the ciliary body and vitreous rather than the anterior chamber. Its characteristic findings include "snowball" opacities in the vitreous and "snowbanking" at the ora serrata, not stellate keratic precipitates. Macular edema rather than PSC cataract would be the primary complication affecting vision.

 

Option B. Heerfordt's Disease: This is a specific manifestation of sarcoidosis presenting with uveitis, parotid gland enlargement, facial nerve palsy, and fever. Sarcoidosis typically causes granulomatous uveitis with "mutton fat" keratic precipitates rather than the stellate KPs described here, and posterior synechiae would typically form.

 

Option D. Subacute Iridocyclitis: This general term refers to an intermediate duration anterior uveitis. It would typically present with posterior synechiae formation, which is specifically absent in this case. Additionally, the characteristic stellate KPs described are specific to Fuchs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The combination of stellate keratic precipitates, aqueous flare, posterior subcapsular cataract, and specifically the absence of posterior synechiae despite chronic inflammation strongly points to Fuchs Heterochromic Iridocyclitis, which follows the FUCHS mnemonic: Floaters, Unilateral uveitis, Complicated cataract, Heterochromia, Stellate KPs with Synechiae absent.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a limbal scar presents to the ophthalmology clinic with moderately defective vision for both near and far. Clinical examination reveals a wide and deep anterior chamber, iridodonesis, and a dark pupillary reflex. Vision of 6/6 is achieved with a corrective lens of +11D. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aphakia

 

The clinical presentation strongly indicates Aphakia. The key diagnostic findings include deep anterior chamber, iridodonesis (tremulousness of iris), and dark pupillary reflex (aphakic pupil). Additionally, the high hyperopic correction (+11D) needed to achieve normal vision is characteristic of aphakia. Presence of Limbal scar in his given scenario indicates a post-surgical condition differentiating it from simple posterior dislocation. Posterior dislocation occurs when all zonules are severed, allowing the lens to fall into the vitreous cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudophakia: This refers to a state where an artificial intraocular lens has been implanted. There's no mention of any surgical history or presence of an IOL, making this diagnosis incorrect.

 

Option C. Hypermetropia: While the patient requires a hyperopic correction (+11D), this is far beyond typical hypermetropia. Primary hypermetropia wouldn't explain the deep anterior chamber, iridodonesis, or dark pupillary reflex.

 

Option D. Posterior Dislocation of Lens: While sharing similar features (deep AC, iridodonesis), the lens would still be present in the vitreous cavity. On fundus examination, a posteriorly dislocated lens would be visible. Would be described as "lens in vitreous cavity" rather than merely a dark pupillary reflex

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aphakia presents with the classic triad of deep anterior chamber, iridodonesis, and dark pupillary reflex, requiring high plus power correction (+10D to +12D) due to the complete absence of the crystalline lens that normally contributes +15-16D to the eye's refractive power.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with uniocular diplopia. Examination with oblique illumination shows a golden crescent, while examination with co-axial illumination shows a dark crescent line. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ectopia lentis

 

This patient presents with classic signs of subluxation of the lens (ectopia lentis), which is a partial displacement where the lens is moved sideways but remains behind the pupil. The key diagnostic findings include uniocular diplopia and the characteristic appearance of the lens edge visible as a dark crescent on distant direct (co-axial) illumination and as a shining golden crescent on oblique illumination examination.

 

Subluxation of the lens (a form of ectopia lentis) presents with uniocular diplopia due to partial aphakia. The edge of the subluxated lens is seen as a dark crescent on distant direct (co-axial) ophthalmoscopy and as a shining golden crescent on oblique illumination, exactly matching the clinical findings described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lenticonus: Incorrect. Lenticonus refers to a cone-shaped elevation of either the anterior or posterior pole of the lens. It presents as an "oil globule" appearance in the center of the red reflex on distant direct ophthalmoscopy, not as a crescent. It doesn't typically cause uniocular diplopia.

 

Option B. Coloboma: Incorrect. Coloboma of the lens appears as a notch in the lower quadrant of the equator of the lens. While it is a structural abnormality, it doesn't cause the characteristic golden/dark crescent sign described, nor is it typically associated with uniocular diplopia.

 

Option C. Microspherophakia: Incorrect. In microspherophakia, the lens is spherical in shape and small in size. While microspherophakia can be associated with lens displacement, the primary finding would be the small, spherical lens rather than just the crescentic signs described.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Subluxated lens (ectopia lentis) has pathognomonic findings of uniocular diplopia and visualization of the lens edge as a dark crescent on co-axial illumination and a golden crescent on oblique illumination.

questions.text: An infant presents with bilateral white pupillary reflex. On slit lamp examination, a zone of opacity is observed around the fetal nucleus with spoke-like radial opacities. The most likely diagnosis is? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lamellar cataract

 

The clinical presentation describes a classic lamellar (zonular) cataract, which is characterized by opacity occupying a discrete zone in the lens around the fetal nucleus. The pathognomonic feature is the presence of "riders" - small linear opacities like spokes of a wheel that extend toward the equator. This perfectly matches the description of "spoke-like radial opacities" in the case.

 

This is the most common type of congenital cataract presenting with visual impairment. It typically occurs in a zone of fetal nucleus surrounding the embryonic nucleus. The main mass of the lens internal and external to the zone of cataract is clear, with small linear opacities like spokes of a wheel (riders) seen towards the equator, exactly matching the described presentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cataracta Centralis Pulvurulenta: Incorrect. This is an embryonic nuclear cataract characterized by a small rounded opacity lying exactly in the center of the lens with a powdery appearance. It doesn't present with the discrete zone of opacity surrounding the fetal nucleus or the spoke-like radial opacities (riders) described in the case.

 

Option C. Coronary cataract: Incorrect. Coronary cataracts are characterized by club-shaped opacities with a regular radial distribution in the periphery of the lens encircling the central axis. They don't form a zone around the fetal nucleus as described in the case.

 

Option D. Posterior polar cataract: Incorrect. This involves a small circular circumscribed opacity at the posterior pole, not a zone around the fetal nucleus. The progressive form typically has an "onion whorl appearance," not the spoke-like radial opacities described.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Lamellar cataract is characterized by opacity in a discrete zone around the fetal nucleus with pathognomonic "riders" (spoke-like radial opacities extending toward the equator), making it the most common type of visually significant congenital cataract.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with deterioration of vision 3 weeks after cataract extraction and intraocular lens (IOL) implantation. Slit-lamp examination reveals honeycomb maculopathy, and fluorescein angiography shows ‘flower petal’ hyperfluorescence. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cystoid Macular Edema

 

This patient presents with classic features of Cystoid Macular Edema (CME), particularly the Irvine-Gass syndrome, which is CME occurring after cataract surgery. The key diagnostic elements are: 

 

  • Deterioration of vision after cataract surgery (a common timing for CME)
  • Honeycomb appearance of macula on slit-lamp examination
  • The pathognomonic "flower petal" pattern on fluorescein angiography, which represents leakage and accumulation of dye in the macular region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age-Related Macular Degeneration (ARMD): This is incorrect as ARMD typically presents with drusen, pigmentary changes, or choroidal neovascularization. It does not show the classic "flower petal" pattern on fluorescein angiography and is not specifically related to recent cataract surgery.

 

Option B. Central Serous Retinopathy (CSR): This is incorrect as CSR typically affects younger patients, especially males with type A personality. On fluorescein angiography, CSR shows either "ink-blot" or "smoke-stack" patterns of hyperfluorescence, not the flower petal appearance.

 

Option C. Macular Dystrophy: This is incorrect as macular dystrophies are genetic disorders with gradual onset, not suddenly appearing after cataract surgery. They also don't typically present with the honeycomb appearance or flower petal pattern on fluorescein angiography.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cystoid Macular Edema is a common complication after cataract surgery (Irvine-Gass syndrome), characterized by honeycomb appearance on clinical examination and flower petal pattern on fluorescein angiography due to leakage from macular capillaries.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient underwent uneventful phacoemulsification with IOL implantation. On the third postoperative day, he presented with pain, diminished vision, redness, watering, and a grayish-yellow pupillary reflex. Examination revealed circumcorneal congestion, aqueous cells 4+, hypopyon in the anterior chamber, posterior synechiae, and retrolental flare. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endophthalmitis

 

This case presents a classic picture of bacterial endophthalmitis following cataract surgery. The presentation on postoperative day three with severe pain, marked diminution of vision, circumcorneal congestion, hypopyon, and a grayish-yellow pupillary reflex are hallmark signs. Bacterial endophthalmitis typically presents between 48-72 hours after surgery with precisely these symptoms and signs.

 

This is an emergency complication of cataract surgery with an incidence of 0.1-0.5%. The symptoms and signs typically present between 48-72 hours after surgery and include ocular pain, diminished vision, lid edema, conjunctival chemosis, marked circumciliary congestion, corneal edema, exudates in pupillary area, hypopyon, and diminished or absent red pupillary glow. This exactly matches the patient's presentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratitis: Incorrect. While keratitis (corneal inflammation) can cause pain, redness and diminished vision, it would primarily present with corneal findings such as infiltrates, epithelial defects, or corneal edema. The presentation with hypopyon, aqueous cells, posterior synechiae, and grayish-yellow pupillary reflex points to a more extensive intraocular inflammation.

 

Option B. Glaucoma: Incorrect. Postoperative glaucoma may cause pain and diminished vision, but it wouldn't explain the marked inflammatory signs including hypopyon, posterior synechiae, and significant aqueous cells. The grayish-yellow pupillary reflex also wouldn't be a feature of glaucoma.

 

Option D. Iridocorneal Cyclitis: Incorrect. While this would cause inflammation of the iris and ciliary body with pain and anterior chamber reaction, it typically wouldn't present with the severity described, especially the grayish-yellow pupillary reflex which suggests vitreous involvement. Postoperative anterior uveitis is typically less severe than the presentation described.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bacterial endophthalmitis following cataract surgery is an emergency characterized by presenting 48-72 hours postoperatively with severe pain, marked visual loss, hypopyon, and exudates in the pupillary area requiring immediate intervention with intravitreal antibiotics.

questions.text: Educating children on the importance of adopting a healthy lifestyle is an example of: [NEET PG 2016]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Primordial prevention

 

  • Primordial prevention refers to actions taken to prevent the emergence or development of risk factors in populations where they have not yet appeared. Many adult health problems like obesity and hypertension have their early origins in childhood, as this is when lifestyles are formed through habits related to smoking, eating patterns, and physical exercise.
  • Educating children about healthy lifestyles specifically aims to discourage the adoption of harmful behaviors before risk factors develop. The main intervention method in primordial prevention is through individual and mass education.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary prevention: This involves action taken prior to the onset of disease when risk factors are already present. Primary prevention includes specific protection measures (like immunization) and health promotion but assumes risk factors may already exist.

 

Option B. Secondary prevention: This level focuses on early diagnosis and prompt treatment of disease that has already begun. It includes screening programs and case-finding activities to detect disease in its early stages.
