Option C. Tertiary prevention: This addresses existing disease to limit complications, disability, and restore function. It includes rehabilitation and preventing further deterioration in patients with established conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primordial prevention represents the earliest intervention level in disease prevention, specifically targeting the formation of lifestyle habits in children before risk factors emerge, making it distinct from primary prevention which addresses existing risk factors.

choices.text: It proceeds from effect to cause
Recall bias is a major problem

questions.text: Which of the following statements about "Case-Control Study" is incorrect? [NEET PG 2016]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) It is a prospective study

 

  • Case-control studies are retrospective studies, not prospective. They look backward from the outcome (disease) to potential exposures or risk factors. 
  • In these studies, investigators select persons with the disease (cases) and without the disease (controls) and then compare their past exposures to determine associations.

 

Other Options:

 

In case-control studies, both the exposure and outcome have already occurred before the start of the study. "Case control studies, often called 'retrospective studies' are a common first approach to test causal hypothesis." Furthermore, they are characterized by working backwards from "effect to cause."

 

Option B. It proceeds from effect to cause: Correct Case-control studies begin with disease status (effect) and work backward to identify potential causes or risk factors. This backward direction from outcome to potential cause is a defining characteristic that distinguishes them from cohort studies.

 

Option C. Recall bias is a major problem: Correct Recall bias is a significant limitation of case-control studies. Since these studies rely on participants' memory of past exposures, cases (those with disease) may recall exposures differently than controls. This systematic difference in recall can distort the true relationship between exposure and disease.

 

Option D. Cost-effective: Correct Case-control studies are indeed cost-effective compared to other study designs, particularly cohort studies. They require fewer subjects and can be completed more quickly, making them a practical choice for initial investigations, especially for rare diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Case-control studies are retrospective investigations that work backward from disease status to potential exposures, making them useful for rare diseases but subject to recall bias.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a selection bias in case-control studies? [NEET PG 2016]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Hawthorne bias

 

  • Hawthorne bias is not a selection bias in case-control studies. It is a type of subject bias that occurs primarily in cohort studies.
  • Hawthorne bias refers to the phenomenon where study subjects alter their behavior when they know they are being observed, affecting the natural outcome of the study.
  • Hawthorne bias is specifically listed as a type of "Subject Bias" that occurs in cohort studies, not case-control studies. Since case-control studies involve examining events that have already occurred, participants cannot alter their behavior to affect the outcome that is being studied.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Berksonian bias: Incorrect Berksonian bias is a true selection bias in case-control studies. It occurs "due to different hospital admission rates" based on location and reputation of an institute. It is a type of investigator (selection) bias that affects hospital-based case-control studies.

 

Option C. Volunteer bias: Incorrect Volunteer bias is a selection bias that can occur in case-control studies when those who volunteer differ systematically from the target population, affecting the representativeness of the sample.

 

Option D. Neyman's bias: Incorrect Also known as prevalence-incidence bias, this is a selection bias in case-control studies where fatal cases, mild cases, or cases of short duration are systematically missed, leading to non-representative case selection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selection biases distort the relationship between exposure and disease by affecting who is included in a study. Hawthorne bias is fundamentally different as it relates to behavior modification during observation, making it relevant to prospective studies but not retrospective case-control designs.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about propagated epidemics is incorrect? [NEET PG 2016]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) No secondary waves occur

 

  • Propagated epidemics are characterized by person-to-person transmission of disease, creating a distinctive epidemiological pattern. 
  • The statement that "no secondary waves occur" is incorrect because propagated epidemics typically may display secondary waves as the infection spreads through successive generations of cases.
  • The epidemic curve in propagated epidemics usually shows a series of progressively taller peaks followed by smaller ones, reflecting the pattern of disease transmission through multiple generations of hosts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exhibits successive peaks: This is accurate for propagated epidemics. The epidemic curve shows successive peaks representing multiple generations of cases as the disease spreads from person to person.

 

Option C. Involves person-to-person transmission: This is the defining feature of propagated epidemics. They only occur with diseases that can be transmitted directly from one person to another, such as HIV/STDs and polio.

 

Option D. Determined by serial interval: The serial interval (time gap between primary and secondary cases) is a key determinant of the pattern and timing of successive waves in propagated epidemics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propagated epidemics feature person-to-person transmission with a pattern of successive waves determined by the serial interval between cases, making the statement that secondary waves do not occur incorrect.

questions.text: A boarding school has 100 students, with 15 of them immunized against measles. During a measles outbreak, 10 students were affected on the first day of the month, and another 35 were affected on the eleventh day. What is the secondary attack rate for measles in this scenario? [NEET PG 2016]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 35/75 × 100

 

  • Secondary attack rate (SAR) is defined as "the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of the incubation period, following exposure to the primary case." It measures disease transmission among susceptible contacts of primary cases.
  • In this scenario, the 10 students affected on day one are the primary cases, and the 35 students affected on day eleven represent secondary cases.

 

To calculate SAR, we need:

 

Total susceptible population after primary cases = Total students - Immunized students – 

 

Primary cases

= 100 - 15 - 10 = 75 students

 

The secondary attack rate is therefore:

 

Secondary cases / Susceptible contacts × 100

= 35/75 × 100 = 46.7%

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 35/85 × 100 - INCORRECT This calculation incorrectly considers only the immunized students (100-15=85) as the denominator, but fails to exclude the primary cases (10 students) who are already infected and thus not part of the susceptible population for secondary attack.

 

Option C. 35/100 × 100 - INCORRECT This uses the total student population as the denominator without excluding either immunized students or primary cases, which is incorrect for calculating secondary attack rate.

 

Option D. 45/85 × 100 - INCORRECT This incorrectly combines primary cases (10) and secondary cases (35) in the numerator, which contradicts the definition of secondary attack rate that specifically measures secondary cases only. It also fails to exclude primary cases from the denominator.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary attack rate specifically measures the proportion of susceptible contacts who develop the disease within the incubation period after exposure to primary cases, making it a valuable metric for evaluating person-to-person disease transmission.

questions.text: The relationship between two variables that is attributed to a shared third factor is referred to as: [NEET PG 2016]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Indirect association

 

  • When two variables appear to be associated but their relationship is actually due to a shared third factor, this is an indirect association.
  • In this situation, there is no true causal relationship between the two variables themselves - instead, both are related to a common third factor. 
  • ‘This third factor (the common factor) is also known as a "confounding variable."
  • Indirect association occurs when there's a statistical association between a characteristic and a disease due to the presence of another factor that is common to both. The relationship appears to exist only because both variables are independently linked to this third factor, not because they directly influence each other.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spurious association: Incorrect A spurious association is completely false or artificial - it's an apparent association that doesn't actually exist but appears due to errors in study design, data collection, or interpretation. Unlike indirect association, there is no real connection between the variables, even through a third factor.

 

Option C. Direct association: Incorrect Direct (causal) association means one variable directly affects or influences the other. This is the opposite of the scenario described in the question, where the relationship is mediated through a third factor rather than being direct.

 

Option D. Causal association: Incorrect Causal association is a type of direct association where one variable causes changes in the other. In the scenario described in the question, neither variable causes the other - they are both affected by a shared third factor, making this an indirect rather than causal association.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the different types of associations is crucial in epidemiology - an indirect association exists when two variables appear related only because both are independently associated with a common third factor (confounding variable).

questions.text: Which sampling method is predominantly utilized by the World Health Organization (WHO) to evaluate immunization coverage levels? [NEET PG 2016]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Cluster sampling

 

  • Cluster Random Sampling (CRS) is specifically used for immunization coverage evaluation. The WHO uses the "30 x 07" technique, where 30 clusters are selected with 7 children (aged 12-23 months) examined in each cluster.
  • This standardized approach involves selecting 30 clusters by systematic random sampling and then examining the first 7 children in each cluster, creating a total sample size of 210.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systematic sampling: While systematic random sampling may be used to select the 30 clusters in the first stage of cluster sampling, it is not the primary methodology recommended for immunization coverage evaluation.

 

Option B. Stratified sampling: For immunization coverage evaluation specifically, stratified sampling has a higher error rate compared to cluster sampling and is not the predominant method used.

 

Option C. Random sampling: Simple random sampling has a much higher error rate (±30%) compared to cluster random sampling (±5%), making it less suitable for immunization evaluation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cluster Random Sampling provides the most reliable results for immunization coverage evaluation with an error rate of only ±5%, making it the preferred methodology using the standardized "30 x 7" approach.

choices.text: An individual with a cough lasting 2 weeks or more
Contacts of smear-positive TB patients with a cough lasting 2 weeks or more
Individuals with suspected or confirmed extra-pulmonary TB with a cough of any duration
HIV-positive individuals with a cough of any duration

questions.text: According to the RNTCP, which of the following is not considered a 'pulmonary TB suspect'? [NEET PG 2016]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Individuals with suspected or confirmed extra-pulmonary TB with a cough of any duration

 

  • This is not specifically included in the criteria for pulmonary TB suspects. While patients with extra-pulmonary TB receive treatment, having a cough of any duration does not automatically qualify them as pulmonary TB suspects.
  • Under RNTCP guidelines, pulmonary TB suspects are identified through specific criteria. The primary criterion is a cough lasting 2 weeks or more. 
  • While special provisions exist for certain high-risk groups, there is no specific mention of individuals with suspected or confirmed extra-pulmonary TB with a cough of any duration being automatically considered pulmonary TB suspects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. An individual with a cough lasting 2 weeks or more: This is the fundamental definition of a pulmonary TB suspect. Cough ≥ 2 weeks is the primary symptom criterion listed in presumptive TB guidelines.

 

Option B. Contacts of smear-positive TB patients with a cough lasting 2 weeks or more: These individuals are considered pulmonary TB suspects because they both have the requisite symptom (cough ≥ 2 weeks) and are contacts of known TB cases.

 

Option D. HIV-positive individuals with a cough of any duration - These individuals are considered pulmonary TB suspects. HIV-positive status is a significant risk factor, and the threshold for TB suspicion is lower in this population due to their immunocompromised status.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The criteria for suspecting pulmonary TB vary by risk factors and comorbidities. While the general criterion is cough ≥ 2 weeks, special considerations apply to high-risk groups like HIV-positive individuals, but not specifically to those with extra-pulmonary TB having a cough of any duration.

choices.text: Distance to a safe water source is greater than 2.6 kms
Water source contains excess iron and heavy metals

questions.text: According to the National Water Supply and Sanitation Programme, a problem village is defined by all of the following criteria except: [NEET PG 2016]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Distance to a safe water source is greater than 2.6 kms

 

A 'problem village' is characterized by the following conditions:

 

  1. Distance to Safe Water Source: No source of safe water is available within a distance of 1.6 km in plains or 100 meters elevation in hilly areas.
  2. Water Quality Issues: The available water sources have quality problems such as:
    • Excess salinity
    • High levels of iron
    • Presence of fluorides
    • Other toxic elements
    • Biological contamination (e.g., risk of cholera) 

 

Therefore, a village where the distance to a safe water source is greater than 2.6 km does not meet the defined criteria for a 'problem village' under this programme.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Water contains high arsenic content: Correct. High arsenic levels in water are a recognized issue affecting water quality and are included in the criteria for identifying problem villages.

 

Option C. Water source contains excess iron and heavy metals: Correct. The presence of excessive iron and other heavy metals in water sources is a valid criterion for classifying a village as a problem village.

 

Option D. Water has high salt content: Correct. Excess salinity in water sources is one of the quality issues considered when identifying problem villages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the National Water Supply and Sanitation Programme, a 'problem village' is identified based on the availability of safe water within 1.6 km and the quality of the water, including factors like salinity, iron, fluorides, and biological contaminants.

questions.text: The National Family Health Survey (NFHS) conducted in 2015-2016 corresponds to which iteration of the survey? [NEET PG 2016]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 4th

 

  • The National Family Health Survey (NFHS) conducted in 2015-2016 was the fourth iteration of the survey. NFHS is conducted every 5-6 years by the International Institute of Population Sciences, Mumbai. 
  • The timeline of the NFHS rounds shows that NFHS-1 was conducted in 1992-93, NFHS-2 in 1998-99, NFHS-3 in 2005-06, NFHS-4 in 2015-16, and the most recent NFHS-5 in 2019-21.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2nd NFHS-2 was conducted in 1998-99, not 2015-16.

 

Option B. 3rd NFHS-3 was conducted in 2005-06, not 2015-16.

 

Option D. 5th NFHS-5 was conducted in 2019-21, not 2015-16.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The National Family Health Survey (NFHS) is India's comprehensive demographic and health survey conducted approximately every 5-6 years, with the fourth round (NFHS-4) conducted in 2015-16, which provided critical data on fertility trends, contraceptive use patterns, and unmet family planning needs across different demographic segments.

questions.text: What is the recommended BMI cut-off for the 'Normal' category among the Indian population? [NEET PG 2016]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 23

 

  • The normal BMI range for the Indian population is defined as 18.5 to 22.99. Once a person reaches a BMI of 23, they move into the overweight/pre-obese category by Indian standards. 
  • This lower cut-off point reflects the specific body composition patterns observed in South Asian populations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 35: This value is significantly higher than the Indian cut-off for normal BMI. A BMI of 35 represents severe obesity (Class II obesity) and is associated with substantially increased health risks.

 

Option B. 30: This represents the threshold for obesity in global classifications. For Indian populations, this value is well above both the normal range and even the overweight category.

 

Option C. 25: While this is used as the upper limit of normal BMI in some classifications, for Indian populations, a BMI of 25 or above already falls into the obesity category, not the normal range.

 

Significance of Different BMI Classifications:

 

Indian BMI classifications use lower cut-off points because South Asian populations typically develop metabolic complications at lower BMI levels than Western populations. South Asians tend to have higher body fat percentages and central adiposity at the same BMI compared to Caucasians.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For Indian populations, the normal BMI range is 18.5-22.99, with 23 being the cut-off point above which a person is classified as overweight.

questions.text: Which classification method does not take height into consideration as a parameter? [NEET PG 2016]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Corpulence Index

 

  • The Corpulence Index is calculated as the ratio of actual weight to desirable weight and is expressed as "Actual weight/Desirable weight."
  • This index should not exceed 1.2. The formula itself does not directly incorporate height as a parameter in its calculation, unlike the other indices mentioned which explicitly use height in their formulas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Quetelet's Index (Body Mass Index) - This index explicitly uses height as a parameter in its formula: Weight (kg)/Height² (m). Height is a squared term in the denominator.

 

Option B. Broca's Index - This index directly uses height in its formula, calculated as Height (cm) minus 100. For example, if a person's height is 160 cm, their ideal weight according to Broca's index would be (160-100) = 60 kg.

 

Option C. Ponderal Index - This index incorporates height as a key parameter in its calculation: Height (cm)/Cube root of body weight (kg). Height appears in the numerator of the formula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When assessing obesity classification methods, it's important to understand the specific anthropometric measurements each index utilizes, as this affects their applicability and sensitivity in different clinical scenarios. The Corpulence Index stands apart from the others by not directly using height in its formula.

questions.text: An immunoglobulin molecule is an example of which level of protein structure?      (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Quaternary structure

 

Explanation:

 

Immunoglobulins are complex proteins composed of multiple polypeptide chains - specifically two identical heavy chains and two identical light chains. This arrangement of multiple polypeptides into a functional protein complex represents quaternary structure. Quaternary structure refers to the spatial arrangement between various types of polypeptides in protein. For immunoglobulins, scientists often use the designation α₂β₂ to indicate two heavy chains and two light chains forming the complete functional protein.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary structure: This refers only to the sequence of amino acids in a polypeptide chain. While each chain in an immunoglobulin has a primary structure, the complete immunoglobulin itself represents a higher level of organization.

 

Option B. Secondary structure: This refers to the folding of short (3-30 residue), contiguous segments of polypeptide into geometrically ordered units like α-helices and β-sheets. Immunoglobulins contain these elements, but as a complete protein they represent a higher level of structure.

 

Option C. Tertiary structure: This refers to the assembly of secondary structural units into larger functional units such as the mature polypeptide. Each individual chain of an immunoglobulin has tertiary structure, but the complete immunoglobulin with multiple chains represents quaternary structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immunoglobulins exemplify quaternary protein structure as they consist of multiple polypeptide chains (two heavy and two light chains) assembled together to form a functional complex capable of recognizing and binding specific antigens.

questions.text: Which of the following metabolic functions does not occur in the mitochondria? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biosynthesis of fatty acids

 

Explanation:

 

Biosynthesis of fatty acids occurs in the cytosol, not in mitochondria. Fatty acid synthesis requires the multi-enzyme complex fatty acid synthase, which is located in the cytosol. The pathway uses acetyl-CoA and malonyl-CoA to build fatty acids through sequential addition of two-carbon units, with NADPH as the reducing agent. This compartmentalization separates fatty acid synthesis from β-oxidation, allowing independent regulation of these opposing pathways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta-oxidation of fatty acids: Oxidation of fatty acids does occur in the mitochondrial matrix, where fatty acids are broken down to acetyl-CoA units.

 

Option C. Protein synthesis does occur in mitochondria: Mitochondria have their own ribosomes and can synthesize some of their proteins from their own DNA.

 

Option D. The citric acid cycle: (Krebs cycle) operates in the mitochondrial matrix, oxidizing acetyl-CoA to CO₂ while generating reduced coenzymes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The compartmentalization of fatty acid metabolism between cytosol (synthesis) and mitochondria (oxidation) is a key regulatory feature that prevents futile cycling and allows independent control of these opposing pathways.

questions.text: Which of the following events does not occur when glucose concentration decreases in the liver? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased levels of Fructose 2, 6-Bisphosphate

 

Explanation:

 

When glucose concentration decreases in the liver (fasting state), glucagon is secreted, which increases cAMP levels. This activates cAMP-dependent protein kinase, which phosphorylates the bifunctional enzyme PFK-2/F-2,6-BPase. Phosphorylation inactivates PFK-2 and activates F-2,6-BPase, resulting in decreased levels of fructose 2,6-bisphosphate. The decrease in fructose 2,6-bisphosphate relieves the inhibition of fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase and removes the activation of phosphofructokinase-1, thereby promoting gluconeogenesis and inhibiting glycolysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inactivation of Phosphofructokinase-2 (PFK-2): This is correct. During decreased glucose (fasting), glucagon activates cAMP-dependent protein kinase which phosphorylates and inactivates PFK-2, reducing the formation of fructose 2,6-bisphosphate.

 

Option B. Activation of Fructose Bisphosphatase-2: This is correct. When glucose decreases, glucagon stimulates phosphorylation of the bifunctional enzyme, activating the F-2,6-BPase component, which breaks down fructose 2,6-bisphosphate.

 

Option D. Increased secretion of Glucagon: This is correct. Decreased blood glucose leads to increased secretion of glucagon from pancreatic α-cells, which triggers glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis in the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fructose 2,6-bisphosphate is a key regulatory molecule whose concentration decreases during fasting (low glucose) to inhibit glycolysis and promote gluconeogenesis, while its levels increase during the fed state to have the opposite effect.

choices.text: Brain utilization of ketone bodies increases

questions.text: Which of the following metabolic changes does not occur during prolonged fasting compared to fasting for 12-36 hours? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Liver gluconeogenesis increases

 

Explanation:

 

During prolonged fasting, liver gluconeogenesis actually doesn't increase compared to short-term fasting (12-36 hours). As fasting progresses, the body adapts to spare protein by decreasing the rate of gluconeogenesis. While gluconeogenesis remains active to supply glucose for glucose-dependent tissues, the overall rate doesn't increase because peripheral tissues decrease their glucose demands. The brain increasingly switches to using ketone bodies for energy (up to ~60% of its needs), which reduces the demand for glucose produced by gluconeogenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brain utilization of ketone bodies increases: This is correct. During prolonged fasting, the brain adapts to using ketone bodies for its energy needs, reducing its dependence on glucose. This is a critical adaptation that helps spare body protein by reducing the need for gluconeogenesis from amino acids.

 

Option C. Urea production rate decreases: This is correct. As fasting progresses, protein breakdown decreases to conserve vital protein stores. This results in decreased amino acid catabolism, leading to lower rates of urea production and excretion compared to short-term fasting.

 

Option D. Blood glucose production declines: This is correct. Total glucose production decreases during prolonged fasting compared to short-term fasting. This is due to adaptations including increased ketone body utilization by the brain and other tissues becoming more efficient at using fatty acids as fuel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During prolonged fasting, the body prioritizes protein conservation by reducing the rate of gluconeogenesis, while simultaneously increasing ketone body production and utilization, particularly by the brain, leading to an overall decline in glucose production compared to shorter periods of fasting.

questions.text: Which enzyme is shared between the pathways for cholesterol and ketone body synthesis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HMG-CoA Synthase

 

Explanation:

 

HMG-CoA Synthase is an enzyme shared between both cholesterol biosynthesis and ketone body formation. In both pathways, HMG-CoA synthase catalyzes the condensation of acetoacetyl-CoA with another molecule of acetyl-CoA to form 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA (HMG-CoA). However, there are two different isoforms of this enzyme: a cytosolic form involved in cholesterol synthesis and a mitochondrial form involved in ketogenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HMG-CoA Reductase: CoA Reductase is the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol synthesis, converting HMG-CoA to mevalonate, but is not involved in ketone body synthesis.

 

Option B. HMG-CoA Lyase: CoA Lyase is specific to the ketogenesis pathway, where it cleaves HMG-CoA to form acetoacetate and acetyl-CoA. It is not involved in cholesterol synthesis.

 

Option D. Thiokinase: (also called acyl-CoA synthetase) activates fatty acids for metabolism by forming fatty acyl-CoA, but is not directly involved in either cholesterol synthesis or ketogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Although cholesterol synthesis and ketogenesis are separate pathways occurring in different cellular compartments (cytosol vs. mitochondria), they share a common step involving HMG-CoA synthase, which catalyzes the formation of HMG-CoA in both processes.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is not phosphorylated by protein kinases in eukaryotic cells? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Asparagine

 

Explanation:

 

Protein kinases in eukaryotic cells catalyze the phosphorylation of specific amino acid residues by transferring the terminal phosphoryl group of ATP to their hydroxyl groups. Protein kinases phosphorylate commonly three types of amino acid residues: serine, threonine, and tyrosine, forming O-phosphoseryl, O-phosphothreonyl, or O-phosphotyrosyl residues, respectively. Asparagine lacks the hydroxyl group  for this phosphoryl transfer reaction, making it unsuitable as a substrate for protein kinases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Threonine: This is incorrect because threonine is one of the three amino acids that can be phosphorylated by protein kinases. Its hydroxyl group serves as the site for attachment of the phosphoryl group.

 

Option B. Tyrosine: This is incorrect because tyrosine is specifically one of the three amino acids that can be phosphorylated by protein kinases through its hydroxyl group.

 

Option C. Serine: This is incorrect because serine is one of the primary targets for protein kinases. Its hydroxyl group readily accepts the phosphoryl group during the phosphorylation reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Protein kinases are highly specific enzymes that catalyze the transfer of phosphoryl groups to the hydroxyl groups of serine, threonine, or tyrosine residues in proteins, not to amino acids lacking hydroxyl groups such as asparagine.

questions.text: Which amino acid in a protein is most commonly associated with O-glycosylation, facilitating the attachment of an oligosaccharide unit? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serine

 

Explanation:

 

Serine is most commonly associated with O-glycosylation, where oligosaccharide units are attached to the hydroxyl (-OH) side chain of serine residues. This is a post-translational modification that occurs during protein maturation. In collagen biosynthesis, hydroxylysyl residues undergo glycosylation when glucosyl and galactosyl transferases attach glucosyl or galactosyl residues to the hydroxyl groups. Similarly, serine residues, which also contain hydroxyl groups in their side chains, are primary sites for O-glycosylation in many proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glutamine: This amino acid contains an amide group in its side chain, not a hydroxyl group, making it unsuitable for O-glycosylation. Glutamine is involved in other forms of post-translational modifications but not O-glycosylation.

 

Option B. Cysteine: While cysteine has a sulfhydryl (-SH) group that can form disulfide bonds and participate in other modifications, it does not undergo O-glycosylation. Cysteine residues are important for protein stability through disulfide bridge formation.

 

Option D. Asparagine: Asparagine is associated with N-glycosylation, not O-glycosylation. In N-glycosylation, oligosaccharides are attached to the amide nitrogen of asparagine side chains, typically in the consensus sequence Asn-X-Ser/Thr (where X is any amino acid except proline).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serine residues, with their hydroxyl side chains, are the primary sites for O-glycosylation—a critical post-translational modification that attaches carbohydrate moieties to proteins, affecting their folding, stability, and biological function.

choices.text: It is transcribed from nuclear DNA.
It contains thymine instead of uracil.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes a characteristic of mature cytoplasmic messenger RNA (mRNA)? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is transcribed from nuclear DNA.

 

Explanation:

 

Messenger RNA (mRNA) is transcribed from nuclear DNA by RNA polymerase. This process occurs in the nucleus where DNA serves as the template for RNA synthesis. While mature cytoplasmic mRNA undergoes extensive processing after transcription (including splicing, capping, and polyadenylation), the fundamental characteristic remains that it originates from the transcription of nuclear DNA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It contains thymine instead of uracil: This is incorrect because mRNA contains uracil, not thymine. Thymine is specific to DNA, while RNA molecules (including mRNA) contain uracil instead.

 

Option C. Its sugar is deoxyribose: This is incorrect because mRNA, like all RNA molecules, contains ribose as its sugar component, not deoxyribose. Deoxyribose is found in DNA.

 

Option D. It is the smallest RNA: This is incorrect because mRNA is not the smallest RNA. The smallest major RNA type is tRNA, which is about 75–95 nucleotides long. mRNA is highly variable in length, often hundreds to thousands of bases long.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The defining characteristic of mRNA is that it is transcribed from nuclear DNA, carrying genetic information from the nucleus to the cytoplasm where it serves as the template for protein synthesis.

questions.text: What is the primary function of Type II Restriction Enzymes? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cut DNA at palindromic sites

 

Explanation:

 

Type II restriction enzymes cut DNA at specific sites termed palindromes. These enzymes function by recognizing and cutting DNA at specific palindromic sequences. As explained in the text, a palindrome is defined as having the same sequence on both strands when read in the 5' to 3' direction. For example, GGCC is a palindrome because when reading both strands in the 5' to 3' direction, the sequence is the same (GGCC). This specificity allows restriction enzymes to make precise cuts at defined locations in DNA molecules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prevent folding of proteins: This is incorrect as restriction enzymes act on DNA, not proteins. They have no direct role in protein folding or prevention of folding.

 

Option B. Remove formed DNA: Restriction enzymes do not remove or eliminate DNA; they make specific cuts at recognition sites, resulting in DNA fragments.

 

Option C. Prevent supercoiling: While some enzymes like topoisomerases are involved in managing DNA supercoiling, this is not the function of restriction enzymes. Restriction enzymes are specifically involved in cleaving DNA at recognition sequences.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Type II restriction enzymes are DNA-cutting enzymes that recognize specific palindromic DNA sequences, making precise cuts at these sites, which is crucial for many molecular biology applications including DNA analysis and genetic engineering.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is most appropriate for assessing the function of a gene? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gene knockout animals

 

Explanation:

 

Gene knockout animals are the most appropriate method for assessing the function of a gene. Gene knockout involves the complete deletion of a gene, allowing scientists to directly observe what happens when the gene is absent. This approach reveals the gene's function by demonstrating the physiological, biochemical, and developmental consequences of its removal. The phenotypic changes observed in knockout animals provide conclusive evidence about what the gene actually does in the organism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Southern blot: This technique is used for DNA-DNA hybridization to detect specific DNA sequences. It's useful for detecting mutations, genome mapping, paternity testing, and localization of genes for genetic disorders, but doesn't directly assess gene function.

 

Option B. Northern blot: This involves RNA-DNA hybridization to detect RNA expression. While it shows if and when a gene is expressed, expression patterns alone don't definitively reveal function. Expression analysis can indicate where and when a gene is active but doesn't conclusively demonstrate what it does.

 

Option D. Transgenic animals: These have foreign DNA introduced into their genome. While useful for studying gene regulation and expression, transgenic approaches typically introduce new or modified genes rather than determining the function of existing genes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Gene knockout animals provide the most direct assessment of gene function by revealing the consequences of gene deletion, offering definitive evidence of the gene's physiological role that other methods cannot provide.

questions.text: Which of the following assays is not typically used for the estimation of total serum protein? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bromocresol green

 

Explanation:

 

Bromcresol green is not typically used for estimation of total serum protein. Instead, it is a dye specifically used for the determination of albumin in serum. Bromcresol green binds selectively to albumin, forming a colored complex that can be measured spectrophotometrically. This makes it valuable for assessing albumin levels but unsuitable for measuring total protein content, which includes many different proteins beyond just albumin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biuret: This is incorrectly identified as a wrong answer. The Biuret test is a standard method for total protein estimation. It produces a purple color when the reagent (copper sulfate in an alkaline solution) reacts with peptide bonds. The Biuret test requires a minimum of two peptide bonds for a positive result, making it suitable for detecting tripeptides and proteins.

 

Option B. Bradford: This is incorrectly identified as a wrong answer. The Bradford assay uses Coomassie Brilliant Blue dye which binds to proteins, particularly basic amino acid residues. It is commonly used for total protein estimation due to its sensitivity and reliability.

 

Option C. Lowry's: This is incorrectly identified as a wrong answer. The Lowry method combines the Biuret reaction with the reduction of Folin-Ciocalteu reagent, which produces a blue color. It is a widely used and sensitive method for measuring total protein concentration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While Biuret, Bradford, and Lowry's methods are commonly used for total protein estimation through different molecular interactions with proteins, bromcresol green is specific for albumin determination and cannot measure the diverse spectrum of proteins present in serum.

questions.text: A protein solution forms a precipitate when heated to around 40°C, which then dissolves again at higher temperatures. This protein is most likely to be: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bence Jones Protein

 

Explanation:

 

Bence Jones proteins are immunoglobulin light chains that exhibit a unique property of thermal precipitation. They precipitate when heated to approximately 40-60°C but redissolve upon further heating to boiling point (100°C). This unusual behavior is a classic diagnostic feature used to identify these proteins in urine samples. Bence Jones proteins are found in multiple myeloma and related plasma cell disorders, where there is excessive production of monoclonal light chains that are filtered through the kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cryoglobulins: These are immunoglobulins that precipitate at cold temperatures (below 37°C) and redissolve upon warming. This behavior is opposite to that described in the question. Cryoglobulins are associated with conditions like hepatitis C infection, autoimmune disorders, and lymphoproliferative diseases.

 

Option C. Complement: This refers to a system of plasma proteins that plays a key role in immune responses. Complement proteins do not exhibit the thermal precipitation and resolubilization pattern described in the question. They are typically denatured irreversibly when heated.

 

Option D. Alpha-2 macroglobulins: These are large plasma proteins that function as protease inhibitors. They do not show the characteristic precipitation at 40°C with redissolution at higher temperatures. Alpha-2 macroglobulins are part of the acute phase response and are typically denatured when heated.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The thermoreversible precipitation property of Bence Jones proteins—precipitating at approximately 40-60°C and redissolving at higher temperatures—is a unique diagnostic feature that distinguishes these immunoglobulin light chains from other proteins and serves as a valuable marker for plasma cell disorders.

questions.text: Keratin in the skin is softer than keratin in the nails because keratin in the skin has: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fewer disulfide bonds

 

Explanation:

 

The hardness and strength of keratin structures directly correlates with the number of disulfide (S~S) bonds present. Keratin is rich in cysteine residues, which can form disulfide bonds between their sulfhydryl (-SH) groups. These covalent crosslinks significantly increase the structural rigidity of keratin. Nail keratin contains a higher density of disulfide bonds than skin keratin, making nails harder and more rigid. The fewer disulfide bonds in skin keratin allow for greater flexibility and softness, which is functionally appropriate for skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fewer salt bridges: While salt bridges (ionic bonds between oppositely charged amino acid side chains) do contribute to protein stability, they are not the primary determinant of keratin hardness. The difference in hardness between skin and nail keratin is specifically related to disulfide bond content.

 

Option C. Higher sodium content: Sodium content is not a determinant of keratin hardness. Keratin's structural properties are determined by its amino acid composition and the covalent and non-covalent interactions between protein chains, not by sodium ion content.

 

Option D. Different water affinity: Although different keratins may have varying levels of hydration, the primary factor determining hardness is the degree of crosslinking via disulfide bonds. Water affinity may affect some properties but is not the main reason for the hardness difference between skin and nail keratin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hardness gradient observed in different keratin-containing structures (skin, hair, nails) is primarily determined by the density of disulfide crosslinks between cysteine residues, with harder structures like nails containing significantly more disulfide bonds than softer structures like skin.

questions.text: A 14-year-old child presents with intellectual disability and a history of self-mutilation. Which of the following tests would be most helpful in establishing the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serum Uric Acid Levels

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of intellectual disability combined with self-mutilation strongly suggests Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. This genetic disorder is characterized by a complete deficiency of HGPRT (hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase) enzyme. HGPRT deficiency leads to markedly elevated uric acid levels due to disrupted purine metabolism. The condition presents with neurological manifestations including self-mutilation (typically lip and finger biting), intellectual disability, and spasticity, along with signs of hyperuricemia such as gout and renal problems.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum Lead Levels: While lead poisoning can cause intellectual disability, it does not typically cause self-mutilation behavior. Lead toxicity presents with abdominal pain, peripheral neuropathy, and anemia.

 

Option B. Serum Alkaline Phosphatase Levels: This would be elevated in bone disorders, liver disease, or growth disorders, none of which typically present with the combination of intellectual disability and self-mutilation.

 

Option C. Serum Lactate Dehydrogenase Levels: LDH elevation is seen in conditions involving tissue damage or rapid cell turnover such as hemolysis, myocardial infarction, or certain malignancies, not in conditions causing self-mutilation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome presents with the characteristic triad of hyperuricemia, self-mutilating behavior, and neurological dysfunction including intellectual disability; serum uric acid measurement is a key diagnostic test for this condition.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of 5-alpha reductase?  (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Breakage of C4-C5 double bond

 

Explanation:

 

5-alpha reductase is an enzyme responsible for converting testosterone into dihydrotestosterone (DHT). This conversion occurs by the reduction of the double bond between the 4th and 5th carbon atoms in the A-ring of the steroid structure. The C4=C5 double bond is saturated by the addition of hydrogen atoms, transforming testosterone into DHT, which has higher affinity and potency at androgen receptors. This process plays a crucial role in the development of male external genitalia and secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Breakage of C–N bond: This bond is typically cleaved during reactions involving hydrolysis of peptide or amide structures, which is not relevant to steroid metabolism.

 

Option C. Breakage of amide bond: Amide bonds are found in proteins and peptides, not in steroid hormones like testosterone. Their cleavage is unrelated to the action of 5-alpha reductase.

 

Option D. Breakage of N–N bond: N–N bonds are uncommon in biological systems and are not involved in steroid hormone processing or the function of 5-alpha reductase.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

5-alpha reductase catalyzes the reduction of the C4–C5 double bond in testosterone, forming DHT and enhancing androgenic effects.

questions.text: Which characteristic best describes an ideal therapeutic radioisotope for medical use? (NEET Pg 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Strong Beta; Low Gamma emitter

 

An ideal therapeutic radioisotope should be a strong beta emitter with low gamma emission. Beta particles have relatively high energy and are strongly absorbed by adjacent tissue, allowing them to cause substantial damage to targeted cells (like cancer cells). Low gamma emission is preferred to minimize radiation exposure to surrounding healthy tissues and healthcare workers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strong Beta; Strong Gamma emitter - While the strong beta emission is desirable for therapy, strong gamma emission is problematic because gamma rays penetrate deeply through tissue and beyond the patient's body, potentially causing unwanted radiation exposure to healthy tissues and medical personnel.

 

Option C. Low Beta; Low Gamma emitter - Low beta emission would provide insufficient therapeutic effect for treating conditions like cancer that require substantial radiation damage to abnormal cells. The radiation would be too weak to effectively destroy target tissues.

 

Option D. Low Beta; Strong Gamma emitter - This is the worst combination for therapy. The low beta emission provides insufficient therapeutic effect, while the strong gamma emission causes unnecessary radiation exposure to surrounding tissues and medical personnel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Therapeutic radioisotopes ideally emit strong beta particles to deliver localized cell damage with minimal gamma radiation to protect surrounding tissues and healthcare providers.

questions.text: Which of the following is not controlled by Kilovolt Peak (kVp) in X-ray imaging? (NEET Pg 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Density

 

Explanation: 

 

Kilovolt Peak (kVp) regulates the velocity of electrons traveling from cathode to anode in the X-ray tube. KVp determines the quality and quantity of X-rays and affects penetration. The relationship is expressed as "kVp ∝ penetration" and "kVp ∝ 1/contrast." Density (film blackening) is controlled by mAs (milliamperage second), not by kVp.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contrast - This is incorrect because kVp does control contrast. KVp is inversely proportional to contrast. When kVp increases, contrast decreases.

 

Option B. Penetrating Power - This is incorrect because kVp does control penetration. KVp is directly proportional to penetration. Higher kVp increases the X-ray beam's ability to penetrate tissue.

 

Option D. Quality - This is incorrect because kVp does determine the quality of X-rays. KVp affects the energy spectrum of the X-ray beam produced.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

KVp controls the X-ray beam's energy (quality), penetration ability, and contrast, while mAs controls the quantity of X-rays and thus the radiographic density (blackening) of films.

questions.text: Which type of X-ray film is most commonly used for high-detail imaging in Mammography? (NEET Pg 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Single Screen-Single Emulsion

 

Explanation: 

 

Mammographic X-ray tubes have specific characteristics that differentiate them from normal X-ray tubes. The entire mammography system is designed for high-detail imaging of breast tissue. Single Screen-Single Emulsion films are used in mammography because they provide the highest spatial resolution required for detecting small microcalcifications and subtle tissue changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Single Screen-Dual Emulsion - This film setup would not provide the optimal spatial resolution needed for mammography as dual emulsion films typically sacrifice some sharpness.

 

Option C. Dual Screen-Dual Emulsion - Using dual screens with dual emulsion would significantly reduce the resolution of the image, making it unsuitable for mammography where detection of minute details is critical.

 

Option D. Dual Screen-Single Emulsion - This combination would be impractical and inefficient, as dual screens would not properly expose a single emulsion film and would not provide the high detail needed for mammography.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mammography requires specialized equipment including Single Screen-Single Emulsion film systems to achieve the high spatial resolution needed for detecting subtle abnormalities in breast tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about T1-weighted MRI images? (NEET Pg 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Fluid appears bright

 

Explanation: On T1-weighted MRI sequences, fluid appears dark (hypointense), not bright. This fundamental principle of MRI physics is demonstrated throughout clinical imaging, where cerebrospinal fluid in the ventricles and spinal canal appears dark on T1-weighted images, providing natural contrast against the brighter surrounding tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Short TR - T1-weighted sequences utilize a short TR (repetition time). The repetition time between radiofrequency pulses is deliberately kept short to emphasize T1 relaxation properties of tissues.

 

Option B. Short TE - T1-weighted sequences utilize a short TE (echo time). The brief interval between the pulse and the resultant echo minimizes T2 effects and maximizes T1 contrast.

 

Option C. Fat appears bright - Fat appears bright (hyperintense) on T1-weighted images. This characteristic signal intensity of fat makes T1-weighted imaging particularly useful for evaluating fatty structures or identifying fat-containing lesions.

 

Educational Objective: T1-weighted MRI sequences produce images where fluid (including CSF, edema, and water) appears dark (hypointense), while fat and certain other tissues like subacute hemorrhage appear bright (hyperintense).

questions.text: The "Money Bag" appearance of the heart on a chest X-ray is most commonly associated with: (NEET Pg 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Pericardial Effusion

 

Explanation: 

 

The "Money Bag" appearance of the heart on a chest X-ray is a classic radiographic finding characterized by an enlarged, globular cardiac silhouette. This distinctive appearance occurs when fluid accumulates in the pericardial space, causing the heart to take on a rounded shape. The cardiac enlargement is typically symmetric and may obscure normal cardiac contours, resembling a money bag.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetralogy of Fallot - This congenital heart defect typically shows a "boot-shaped" heart (coeur en sabot) on chest X-ray due to right ventricular hypertrophy and a small pulmonary artery, not a money bag appearance.

 

Option B. TAPVC (Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection) - This condition usually presents with a "snowman" or "figure-of-8" appearance (supracardiac type) or cardiomegaly with pulmonary venous congestion, not a money bag appearance.

 

Option D. Emphysema - In emphysema, the heart typically appears small and vertical (referred to as a "hanging heart" or "drop heart") due to hyperinflation of the lungs. This is the opposite of the enlarged, rounded appearance seen in pericardial effusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Money Bag" appearance on chest X-ray represents a globular cardiac silhouette caused by pericardial effusion where fluid accumulation creates a rounded, enlarged cardiac shadow with smooth margins.

questions.text: Luckenschadel skull is most commonly associated with: (NEET Pg 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Arnold Chiari Malformation

 

Explanation: 

 

Luckenschadel skull (also known as "lacunar skull") refers to a radiographic finding characterized by multiple radiolucent areas separated by dense septa in the cranial bones, creating a "pond-like" appearance. This pattern is most commonly associated with Arnold Chiari Malformation, where the abnormal development of the posterior fossa and associated increased intracranial pressure can lead to this distinctive skull appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paget's disease - This condition typically shows a mixed pattern of osteolytic and osteoblastic changes in the skull with areas of increased density and bone expansion creating a "cotton wool" appearance, not the lacunar pattern of Luckenschadel.

 

Option C. Crouzon Syndrome - This craniosynostosis disorder shows premature fusion of cranial sutures resulting in skull deformities with a characteristic "copper beaten" appearance, not the Luckenschadel pattern.

 

Option D. Sturge Weber Syndrome - This neurocutaneous disorder is characterized by "tram-track" or "railroad track" calcifications in the cerebral cortex, not Luckenschadel changes in the skull bones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Luckenschadel (lacunar skull) with its characteristic multiple radiolucent areas separated by dense septa is strongly associated with Arnold Chiari Malformation and the developmental abnormalities of the posterior fossa that accompany this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a radiological feature of hypothyroidism? (NEET Pg 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Beaking of vertebra

 

Explanation: 

 

Beaking of vertebra is not associated with hypothyroidism. This vertebral finding is characteristic of mucopolysaccharidosis conditions, with central beaking observed in Morquio's disease and antero-inferior beaking seen in Hurler disease. Hypothyroidism has several skeletal manifestations, but vertebral beaking is not among them.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Wormian bones - These accessory sutural bones can be seen in various conditions including hypothyroidism, especially in congenital hypothyroidism or cretinism.
  • Option B. Stipulated ribs - Rib abnormalities can occur in hypothyroidism as part of the broader skeletal manifestations of the disease.
  • Option D. Epiphyseal Dysgenesis - This is a recognized skeletal manifestation in hypothyroidism, particularly in juvenile hypothyroidism, affecting the growth plates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vertebral beaking is specifically associated with mucopolysaccharidosis conditions rather than hypothyroidism, which has its own distinct pattern of skeletal manifestations.

questions.text: The "Double Bubble" sign on an abdominal X-ray is typically seen in: (NEET Pg 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Duodenal atresia

 

Explanation:

 

The "Double Bubble" sign is a classic radiographic finding specific to duodenal atresia. This sign represents two adjacent air-filled structures - the dilated stomach and proximal duodenum - with absence of air in the distal bowel due to complete obstruction at the level of the duodenum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colon carcinoma - Colon carcinoma typically presents with an "Apple-core sign" on imaging studies, which represents an annular constricting lesion causing narrowing of the colonic lumen, not a double bubble appearance.

 

Option B. Perforation - Perforation presents with "Pneumoperitoneum" on radiographs. Characteristic signs include "Air under the diaphragm," "Football Sign," "Cupola Sign," and "Rigler Sign," but not the double bubble sign.

 

Option C. Intussusception - Intussusception demonstrates "Target/Donut/Sandwich/Pseudokidney sign" on ultrasound and "Claw Sign" or "Coiled Spring Sign" on barium studies. These appearances differ significantly from the double bubble configuration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Double Bubble sign is a pathognomonic radiographic finding for duodenal atresia, consisting of two adjacent gas-filled structures (dilated stomach and proximal duodenum) with absence of distal bowel gas, while other gastrointestinal pathologies present with their own characteristic imaging patterns.

choices.text: Watchful waiting and follow-up if symptomatic
Surgical repair on the next elective list
Emergency surgical repair with exploration of the bowel

questions.text: An asymptomatic patient presents with a reducible hernia below the inguinal ligament. Which of the following is the most appropriate management to consider? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Surgical repair on the next elective list

 

Explanation:

 

A femoral hernia occurs below the inguinal ligament through the femoral ring. While this patient's hernia is currently asymptomatic and reducible, femoral hernias have rigid boundaries (femoral vein laterally, inguinal ligament superiorly, pubic arc inferiorly, and lacunar ligament medially), creating a high risk for strangulation. Femoral hernias warrant prompt elective surgical intervention regardless of symptoms, as they have a significantly higher risk of complications compared to other hernias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Watchful waiting and follow-up if symptomatic - Incorrect because femoral hernias have a significantly higher risk of strangulation (approximately 50% present as emergencies). Unlike some inguinal hernias, femoral hernias should not be managed conservatively, even when asymptomatic.

 

Option C. Emergency surgical repair of hernia - Incorrect because the hernia is currently reducible and asymptomatic, not requiring immediate emergency surgery. Emergency surgery is indicated for irreducible, obstructed, or strangulated hernias.

 

Option D. Emergency surgical repair with exploration of the bowel - Incorrect for the same reason as option C. Additionally, bowel exploration would only be necessary if strangulation was suspected, which isn't the case in this reducible, asymptomatic hernia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

All femoral hernias should be repaired surgically on an elective basis due to their high risk of strangulation, even when asymptomatic and reducible.

questions.text: Which of the following does not form a boundary of the 'Triangle of Doom'? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Inguinal ligament

 

Explanation:

 

The "Triangle of Doom" is an important anatomical danger zone encountered during laparoscopic hernia repair. This triangle contains critical structures, including the external iliac vessels that must be avoided during mesh fixation and dissection. This triangle is bounded by the vas deferens medially, the gonadal vessels laterally, and the peritoneal reflection forming the base. The inguinal ligament is not a boundary of this triangle in the laparoscopic perspective.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Vas Deferens - This is an incorrect answer because the vas deferens forms the medial boundary of the Triangle of Doom in laparoscopic hernia repair, creating an essential landmark surgeons must identify to avoid vascular injury.
  • Option B. Gonadal vessels - This is an incorrect answer because the gonadal vessels (testicular or ovarian vessels) form the lateral boundary of the Triangle of Doom, serving as a crucial landmark during laparoscopic hernia procedures.
  • Option C. Peritoneal reflection - This is an incorrect answer because the peritoneal reflection forms the base of the Triangle of Doom in the laparoscopic view, completing the triangular area containing the dangerous external iliac vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the boundaries and contents of the Triangle of Doom is essential for safe laparoscopic hernia repair, as inadvertent dissection or tack placement in this area can result in catastrophic vascular injury.

questions.text: Open pre-peritoneal large mesh repair for complex inguinal hernia is associated with which of the following procedures? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Stoppa operation

 

Explanation:

            

The Stoppa operation is the open pre-peritoneal large mesh repair technique for complex inguinal hernias. This procedure involves placing a large prosthetic mesh in the pre-peritoneal space that covers the entire myopectineal orifice bilaterally. It's specifically designed for complex, recurrent, or bilateral inguinal hernias. The Stoppa approach provides excellent coverage of all potential hernia sites while avoiding direct contact with nerves in the inguinal canal, reducing the risk of chronic pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lichtenstein operation - Incorrect because the Lichtenstein repair is an onlay mesh technique where the prosthetic mesh is placed on top of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, not in the pre-peritoneal space. While it uses mesh, it employs a different anatomical approach and placement technique.

 

Option B. Shouldice operation - Incorrect because the Shouldice repair is a tissue-based herniorrhaphy technique that doesn't use mesh at all. It involves multiple layers of suturing of the native tissue (double breasting of conjoint tendon and inguinal ligament and halves of fascia transversalis) to create a 4-layer posterior wall repair.

 

Option D. Mac-Vay Operation - Incorrect because the McVay (Cooper ligament) repair is another tissue-based repair that doesn't utilize mesh. This technique involves suturing the conjoint tendon to Cooper's ligament (pectineal ligament) rather than to the inguinal ligament.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Stoppa operation is characterized by placement of a large prosthetic mesh in the pre-peritoneal space for complex inguinal hernias, covering bilateral myopectineal orifices simultaneously.

questions.text: Ankle Brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) suggesting imminent necrosis is indicated by which of the following values? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. <0.3

 

Explanation:

 

The Ankle Brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is a quantitative assessment tool that measures the ratio of systolic blood pressure at the ankle to that in the ipsilateral arm. The normal resting ABPI ranges from 0.9-1.3. As ABPI decreases, it indicates progressively worsening arterial obstruction. An ABPI value of <0.3 specifically indicates imminent necrosis - the most severe stage of arterial insufficiency, where tissue death is about to occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. <1: This value falls within the normal to borderline range and does not indicate significant disease or risk of necrosis.

 

Option B. <0.9: This value indicates some degree of arterial obstruction with mild claudication symptoms but is not severe enough to suggest imminent necrosis.

 

Option C. <0.5: This value suggests more significant ischemia with rest pain but still doesn't reach the threshold indicating imminent necrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ABPI is a crucial non-invasive tool for assessing arterial insufficiency severity, with values progressively decreasing as ischemia worsens: <0.9 indicates claudication, <0.5 suggests rest pain, and <0.3 indicates imminent necrosis requiring urgent intervention to prevent limb loss.

questions.text: What is the most common site for a peripheral arterial aneurysm? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Popliteal

 

Explanation:

 

The popliteal artery is the most common site for peripheral arterial aneurysms. Popliteal aneurysms account for approximately 70% of all peripheral aneurysms and are classically diagnosed in males in their seventh decade of life. They are bilateral in about 50% of cases. An important clinical consideration is that one-third of patients with popliteal aneurysms also have abdominal aortic aneurysms, necessitating abdominal examination in these patients.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Axillary: Axillary artery aneurysms are rare compared to popliteal aneurysms and often occur secondary to trauma or arteritis.
  • Option C. Subclavian: Subclavian artery aneurysms are uncommon and may be associated with thoracic outlet syndrome or trauma but occur much less frequently than popliteal aneurysms.
  • Option D. Superficial femoral: While femoral aneurysms do occur, they are less common than popliteal aneurysms. True aneurysms of the femoral artery are relatively uncommon.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Popliteal artery aneurysms are the most common peripheral arterial aneurysms, with significant risk of complications when exceeding 20mm in diameter, requiring consideration for surgical repair to prevent thrombosis, distal embolization, or rupture.

questions.text: Which artery is the most common source of Cirsoid Aneurysms of the scalp? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Superficial temporal artery

 

Explanation:

 

Cirsoid aneurysm is an arteriovenous malformation that most commonly affects the superficial temporal vessels on the forehead and scalp. These lesions present as pulsatile masses and represent abnormal communications between arteries and veins without an intervening capillary network. The superficial temporal artery is the primary arterial feeder in these malformations, making it the most common source of cirsoid aneurysms of the scalp.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. External carotid artery: While the external carotid artery is the parent vessel of the superficial temporal artery, it's not directly involved as the primary source of cirsoid aneurysms.
  • Option C. Internal carotid artery: The internal carotid artery supplies intracranial structures and is not directly involved in scalp vascular malformations.
  • Option D. Occipital artery: Although the occipital artery can occasionally contribute to scalp vascular malformations, it is not the most common source of cirsoid aneurysms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cirsoid aneurysms are arteriovenous malformations predominantly affecting the superficial temporal vessels, presenting as pulsatile masses on the scalp or forehead that require appropriate vascular imaging for diagnosis and management.

choices.text: Typically presents between postoperative days 3 and 5
Suture length should be 4 times the wound length
High incidence if Catgut is used for closure

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Burst Abdomen is not true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Typically presents between postoperative days 3 and 5

 

Explanation:

 

Burst abdomen (abdominal wound dehiscence) usually occurs after 5-7 days post-laparotomy. This directly contradicts option B, which incorrectly states it typically presents between days 3-5. The condition is characterized by the "salmon fluid sign" where large quantities of serous fluid come out from the wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incidence is 1-3 percent - This represents an accurate statistical range for the occurrence of burst abdomen following laparotomy procedures.

 

Option C. Suture length should be 4 times the wound length - This is a correct technical specification for proper abdominal wall closure to prevent dehiscence, also known as Jenkin’s rule.

 

Option D. High incidence if Catgut is used for closure - This is accurate because catgut is an absorbable suture material associated with higher rates of wound failure compared to more modern synthetic materials.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burst abdomen is a serious post-operative complication that presents with the salmon fluid sign typically 5-7 days after surgery, requiring emergency management with a Bogota bag laparostomy followed by definitive re-suturing of the abdominal wall.

questions.text: Obturator Sign in Acute Appendicitis is most commonly associated with which appendix position? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Pelvic Appendix

 

Explanation:

 

The obturator sign is elicited when the examiner flexes the patient's right hip and knee and then internally rotates the hip, causing pain in the hypogastrium. This sign is positive when an inflamed appendix lies in contact with the obturator internus muscle. The pelvic position of the appendix places it directly adjacent to the obturator internus muscle, making this sign characteristic of pelvic appendicitis. When the obturator muscle contracts during internal rotation of the hip, it irritates the inflamed appendix, producing pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retrocecal - This position places the appendix behind the cecum against the psoas muscle, typically resulting in a positive psoas sign (pain on extension of the hip) rather than obturator sign. Retrocecal appendicitis often presents with flank or back pain.

 

Option C. Pre-Ileal - When the appendix lies anterior to the terminal ileum, it typically produces classic right lower quadrant pain at McBurney's point without specific muscle signs.

 

Option D. Post-Ileal - In this position, the appendix lies behind the ileum but not necessarily in contact with the obturator muscle, making the obturator sign unlikely.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The obturator sign indicates irritation of the obturator internus muscle by an inflamed appendix, most commonly occurring when the appendix is in the pelvic position, and serves as an important physical examination finding for identifying atypical appendicitis.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for a 0.5 cm carcinoid tumor located at the tip of the appendix? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Appendectomy

 

Explanation:

 

For carcinoid tumors of the appendix, the size and location of the tumor are the key determinants for treatment. For tumors less than 2 cm in size that are located at the tip of the appendix, simple appendectomy is considered adequate treatment. Carcinoid tumors of the appendix rarely metastasize, especially when small and distally located. The 0.5 cm tumor described in the question is well below the size threshold that would warrant more extensive surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right Hemicolectomy - This more extensive procedure is indicated only when: (1) the tumor is 2 cm or larger in size, (2) the base of the appendix or cecal wall is involved, or (3) there is evidence of lymph node metastasis. None of these conditions are present for a 0.5 cm tumor at the tip.

 

Option C. Omentectomy - This procedure involves removal of the omentum and is not indicated for appendiceal carcinoid tumors unless there is evidence of peritoneal spread, which is extremely rare for small carcinoids.

 

Option D. Hepatic wedge resection - This would only be considered if there were liver metastases, which are exceptionally rare with small appendiceal carcinoid tumors, especially those <1 cm.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Small carcinoid tumors (<2 cm) at the appendiceal tip can be adequately treated with simple appendectomy, as they have minimal metastatic potential and excellent prognosis following this conservative approach.

questions.text: What is the cut-off score for defining Severe Acute Pancreatitis from below? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. APACHE II Score > 8

 

Explanation:

 

Several prognostic scoring systems are used to predict severity in acute pancreatitis. The threshold for severe pancreatitis using the APACHE II scoring system is >8. This score helps clinicians identify patients at higher risk of complications who may require intensive monitoring and aggressive management. Severity stratification is particularly important to determine which patients might develop persistent organ failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ranson Score >1 - INCORRECT The Ranson score threshold for severe acute pancreatitis is ≥3 (not >1). This score is assessed at admission and 48 hours later, with criteria including age, white blood cell count, blood glucose, LDH, and AST initially, followed by hematocrit fall, BUN rise, calcium levels, and other parameters at 48 hours.

 

Option B. Imrie Score > 6 - INCORRECT The Imrie score (Glasgow score) defines severe pancreatitis as ≥3 criteria present, not >6. The Glasgow criteria include 8 parameters total, similar to the Ranson criteria but assessed at different timepoints.

 

Option D. ROME Score > 3 - INCORRECT The ROME Score is not a validated or recognized scoring system for acute pancreatitis severity assessment. The primary scoring systems used in clinical practice include Ranson, Glasgow, APACHE II, BISAP, and modified Marshall scoring systems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe acute pancreatitis is defined by persistent organ failure (>48 hours) and can be predicted using several scoring systems, with APACHE II score >8 being an important threshold for identifying high-risk patients.

questions.text: Which of the following leukotrienes is not a vasoconstrictor? ( NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Leukotriene B4

 

Explanation: 

 

Leukotriene B4 (LTB4) is primarily a potent chemotactic agent and activator of neutrophils, causing aggregation and adhesion of neutrophils to venular endothelium. Unlike the other leukotrienes listed (C4, D4, and E4), LTB4 does not function as a vasoconstrictor in the inflammatory response. Instead, it primarily mediates leukocyte recruitment and activation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leukotriene C4 - This is a cysteinyl-containing leukotriene that causes intense vasoconstriction, bronchospasm, and increased permeability of venules. It is part of the slow-reacting substance of anaphylaxis (SRS-A).

 

Option B. Leukotriene D4 - Similar to LTC4, it is a cysteinyl-containing leukotriene that functions as a vasoconstrictor and bronchospasm inducer. It is also part of SRS-A and contributes to increased vascular permeability.

 

Option C. Leukotriene E4 - This is also a cysteinyl-containing leukotriene with vasoconstriction properties similar to LTC4 and LTD4. It is part of SRS-A and contributes to the inflammatory response.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Leukotriene B4 differs from LTC4, LTD4, and LTE4 in that it primarily functions as a chemotactic agent for leukocytes rather than causing vasoconstriction, making it a key mediator in leukocyte recruitment during inflammation.

questions.text: Which cytokine is responsible for activating macrophages and converting them into giant cells? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) IFN-gamma.

 

Explanation: 

 

IFN-gamma (Interferon gamma) is produced by T-lymphocytes and natural killer cells and is a critical cytokine for macrophage activation. It induces classical activation of macrophages, enhancing their microbicidal activity and promoting granuloma formation, which includes the fusion of macrophages to form multinucleated giant cells like Langhans giant cells. IFN-gamma is particularly important in immune responses against intracellular pathogens, especially mycobacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IL-12 - Though IL-12 is involved in the immune response, it primarily functions to stimulate the development of Th1 cells and the production of IFN-gamma. It plays an indirect role in macrophage activation by promoting IFN-gamma production, but doesn't directly convert macrophages into giant cells.

 

Option B. IL-7 - This interleukin is primarily involved in lymphoid proliferation and development. It stimulates the proliferation of B, T, and NK cell progenitors, but does not directly activate macrophages or contribute to giant cell formation.

 

Option C. IFN-alpha - While IFN-alpha (Interferon alpha) has antiviral activities and is produced by leukocytes, it doesn't play a significant role in macrophage activation or giant cell formation. Its primary function is interfering with viral DNA and RNA synthesis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

IFN-gamma is the key cytokine responsible for classical macrophage activation, which can lead to the formation of giant cells in granulomatous inflammation, particularly in response to persistent intracellular pathogens like mycobacteria.

questions.text: Which site is most commonly used for the initial biopsy to confirm a diagnosis of systemic amyloidosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Abdominal fat

 

Explanation: 

 

Abdominal fat aspiration is commonly used as an initial biopsy site to diagnose systemic amyloidosis. The procedure is minimally invasive with low complication rates compared to other tissue biopsies. Examination of abdominal fat aspirates stained with Congo red can be used for the diagnosis of systemic amyloidosis. While the test is quite specific, its sensitivity is lower than more invasive biopsies, but it is still preferred as an initial diagnostic approach due to its safety profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gingiva - While gingival biopsy can be used to diagnose amyloidosis, it is not typically the first-line approach. Gingival tissue is a possible site for biopsy in patients suspected of having systemic amyloidosis, but it is less commonly used than abdominal fat aspiration.

 

Option B. Kidney - Kidney biopsy is performed when there are renal manifestations of amyloidosis but is not used as the initial diagnostic procedure due to its invasive nature and potential complications. It is usually reserved for cases where kidney involvement is the primary concern or when less invasive methods are inconclusive.

 

Option C. Rectal mucosa - Rectal mucosa biopsy can be used to diagnose systemic amyloidosis, but like gingival biopsy, it is not the first-line approach. It is more invasive than abdominal fat aspiration but may be performed when other sites yield inconclusive results.

 

Educational Objective:
