Abdominal fat aspiration is the preferred initial diagnostic procedure for systemic amyloidosis due to its minimal invasiveness, relative safety, and good specificity, although other tissue sites including kidney, rectal mucosa, and gingiva may be biopsied depending on clinical presentation and when fat aspiration is inconclusive.

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies is diagnostic for mixed connective tissue disease? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. U1-RNP antibody

 

Explanation: 

 

Mixed connective tissue disease is characterized by high titers of antibodies to U1 ribonucleoprotein (U1-RNP). This antibody is considered diagnostic for the condition, which presents with clinical features that overlap with those of SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. Patients typically present with synovitis of the fingers, Raynaud phenomenon, myositis, and renal involvement, which usually responds well to corticosteroids, at least in the short term.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-nuclear antibody - While anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs) are present in mixed connective tissue disease, they are not specific for this condition. ANAs are found in many autoimmune diseases including SLE, systemic sclerosis, and Sjögren syndrome, so their presence alone cannot differentiate mixed connective tissue disease from other connective tissue disorders.

 

Option B. SCL-70 antibody - SCL-70 antibody (anti-DNA topoisomerase I) is associated with systemic sclerosis (scleroderma), particularly the diffuse cutaneous form with increased risk of pulmonary fibrosis and peripheral vascular disease. It is not characteristic of mixed connective tissue disease.

 

Option D. Anti-CCP antibody - Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies are highly specific for rheumatoid arthritis. They are not typically found in mixed connective tissue disease and are used to differentiate rheumatoid arthritis from other forms of inflammatory arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High titres of antibodies to U1 ribonucleoprotein (U1-RNP) are the serological hallmark and diagnostic marker for mixed connective tissue disease, a condition with overlapping features of several autoimmune disorders including SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis.

questions.text: Keratoderma Blennorrhagicum is most commonly associated with: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Reactive Arthritis

 

Explanation: 

 

Keratoderma blennorrhagicum is a characteristic skin manifestation of Reactive Arthritis. Reactive Arthritis (formerly known as Reiter's syndrome) typically presents with a triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis, often following gastrointestinal or genitourinary infections. Keratoderma blennorrhagicum appears as pustular skin lesions that resemble psoriasis, typically on the palms and soles. It is considered part of the characteristic clinical presentation of reactive arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid Arthritis - RA is characterized by symmetric polyarthritis, morning stiffness, and systemic manifestations. Skin manifestations in RA include rheumatoid nodules, but not keratoderma blennorrhagicum, which is specific to reactive arthritis.

 

Option B. Psoriatic Arthritis - While psoriatic arthritis does have skin manifestations (primarily psoriatic plaques), keratoderma blennorrhagicum specifically refers to the pustular lesions seen in reactive arthritis. Though they can appear similar to pustular psoriasis, they are distinct clinical entities.

 

Option D. Ankylosing Spondylitis - AS primarily affects the axial skeleton, causing sacroiliitis and spinal fusion. While it shares genetic associations (HLA-B27) with reactive arthritis, keratoderma blennorrhagicum is not a typical manifestation of ankylosing spondylitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keratoderma blennorrhagicum, characterized by pustular skin lesions resembling psoriasis on the palms and soles, is a distinctive cutaneous manifestation of Reactive Arthritis, which typically occurs following gastrointestinal or genitourinary infections.

questions.text: The deletion of a single alpha globin gene on one chromosome is best described as: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Alpha Thalassemia silent carrier.

 

Explanation: 

 

The deletion of a single alpha globin gene on one chromosome (represented as α/α -/-) is classified as alpha thalassemia silent carrier state. Normally, there are four alpha globin genes in total (two on each chromosome 16). The silent carrier state results from the deletion of just one alpha globin gene, causing a barely detectable reduction in alpha-globin chain synthesis. Individuals with this condition are completely asymptomatic but might have slight microcytosis (small red cells). This represents the mildest form of alpha thalassemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hb Barts - This is incorrect. Hemoglobin Barts is a tetrameric gamma globin chain (γ4) that forms when there is severe alpha chain deficiency. It is associated with the complete absence of alpha globin genes (hydrops fetalis) or the deletion of three alpha globin genes (HbH disease), not with the loss of a single gene.

 

Option B. Alpha thalassemia major - This is incorrect. Alpha thalassemia major (hydrops fetalis) results from the deletion of all four alpha globin genes (--/--), causing severe intrauterine anemia and typically resulting in death in utero or shortly after birth without intervention.

 

Option C. Alpha thalassemia trait - This is incorrect. Alpha thalassemia trait results from the deletion of two alpha globin genes, either both from the same chromosome (--/αα) or one from each chromosome (-α/-α). This causes mild microcytic anemia without significant clinical symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha thalassemia silent carrier state is caused by the deletion of a single alpha globin gene, resulting in minimal hematological changes without clinical symptoms, representing the mildest form in the spectrum of alpha thalassemia disorders.

questions.text: Heavy chain disease associated with the presence of kappa light chains in the urine: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia.

 

Explanation: 

 

Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia (also called lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma) is characterized by production of IgM monoclonal protein and is associated with the presence of kappa light chains. In this condition, light chain (kappa) is produced in the same quantity as heavy chain (mu), which contrasts with other heavy chain diseases where there is predominant production of heavy chain antibody. The disease presents as an M spike of IgM type and commonly manifests with hyper viscosity syndrome due to the large size of IgM molecules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mu chain disease - This is incorrect. Mu (μ) chain disease is a rare heavy chain disease associated with CLL rather than with the presence of kappa light chains in urine. It involves the production of abnormal μ heavy chains without associated light chains.

 

Option B. Sezary disease - This is incorrect. Sezary syndrome is not a heavy chain disease but a variant of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma characterized by erythroderma, lymphadenopathy, and neoplastic T cells (Sezary cells) with cerebriform nuclei in the blood.

 

Option C. Franklin disease - This is incorrect. Franklin disease (gamma heavy chain disease) is characterized by the production of gamma (γ) heavy chains without associated light chains. It presents with fever, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and is associated with rheumatoid arthritis, but not specifically with kappa light chains in urine.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia is distinguished from other heavy chain diseases by the production of intact IgM molecules with balanced synthesis of heavy and light chains (including kappa light chains), often leading to hyper viscosity syndrome due to high levels of the large IgM protein.

questions.text: Alder-Reilly bodies are found in: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Mucopolysaccharidosis.

 

Explanation: 

 

Alder-Reilly bodies are azurophilic, metachromatic granules found in leukocytes (neutrophils, eosinophils, basophils, monocytes, and lymphocytes) in patients with mucopolysaccharidosis. These abnormal inclusions represent accumulations of mucopolysaccharides (glycosaminoglycans) within the cytoplasm of these cells. Mucopolysaccharidoses are a group of inherited lysosomal storage disorders characterized by defective degradation of glycosaminoglycans due to enzyme deficiencies, leading to their accumulation in various tissues including blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Large platelets - This is incorrect. Large platelets are associated with several conditions including Bernard-Soulier syndrome, May-Hegglin anomaly, and immune thrombocytopenic purpura, but these do not feature Alder-Reilly bodies.

 

Option C. Alport's syndrome - This is incorrect. Alport's syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive kidney disease, hearing loss, and eye abnormalities. It's caused by mutations in genes coding for type IV collagen and does not involve the formation of Alder-Reilly bodies.

 

Option D. Chediak-Higashi syndrome - This is incorrect. While Chediak-Higashi syndrome does involve abnormal granules in leukocytes, these are giant lysosomal granules rather than Alder-Reilly bodies. Chediak-Higashi syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by partial albinism, recurrent infections, and giant granules in leukocytes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Alder-Reilly bodies are distinctive azurophilic granular inclusions found in leukocytes of patients with mucopolysaccharidosis, representing accumulated glycosaminoglycans due to defective lysosomal enzyme function.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions, inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, is characterized by the presence of large platelets and Döhle bodies in neutrophils? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. May-Hegglin Anomaly

 

Explanation: 

 

May-Hegglin anomaly is an autosomal dominant inherited disorder characterized by the presence of large platelets (thrombocytopenia) and Döhle bodies in neutrophils. Döhle bodies are small, blue-gray inclusions found in the periphery of neutrophil cytoplasm. They are composed of rough endoplasmic reticulum. This condition is classified under qualitative disorders of platelet function, specifically within the category of storage pool disorders that affect platelet function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alder-Reilly bodies - These are large, dark-purple granules found in neutrophils and other leukocytes in patients with mucopolysaccharidosis. This is not associated with large platelets and is not autosomal dominant.

 

Option B. Mucopolysaccharidosis - This is a group of metabolic disorders caused by the absence or malfunctioning of lysosomal enzymes needed to break down glycosaminoglycans. It is typically autosomal recessive and characterized by Alder-Reilly bodies in leukocytes, not Döhle bodies or large platelets.

 

Option D. Chediak-Higashi syndrome - This is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by partial albinism, recurrent infections, and large peroxidase-positive granules in neutrophils. It is not associated with large platelets or Döhle bodies.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

May-Hegglin anomaly is an autosomal dominant inherited disorder characterized by thrombocytopenia with large platelets and Döhle bodies (blue-gray cytoplasmic inclusions) in neutrophils, representing a distinct qualitative platelet function disorder.

questions.text: Transformation of CLL/SLL into DLBCL is referred to as which of the following? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Richter syndrome

 

Explanation: 

 

Richter syndrome refers to the transformation of chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL) into diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). This transformation occurs in approximately 5-10% of CLL/SLL patients and is often heralded by the development of a rapidly enlarging mass within a lymph node or the spleen. Richter syndrome is frequently associated with acquisition of new abnormalities involving TP53 or MYC genes and represents an ominous event, with most patients surviving less than 1 year after transformation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Evans syndrome - This is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the simultaneous or sequential occurrence of autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) and immune thrombocytopenia (ITP). It has no relation to the transformation of CLL/SLL to DLBCL.

 

Option C. Li-Fraumeni syndrome - This is an inherited cancer predisposition syndrome associated with germline mutations in the TP53 tumor suppressor gene. It is characterized by a high risk of developing various cancers but is not related to CLL/SLL transformation.

 

Option D. Kostmann syndrome - This is a rare congenital disorder characterized by severe neutropenia, leading to recurrent infections. It is unrelated to CLL/SLL transformation and represents a disorder of granulocyte production.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Richter syndrome represents the clinically aggressive transformation of CLL/SLL into DLBCL, characterized by rapidly enlarging masses, new genetic abnormalities, and poor prognosis with survival usually less than one year.

questions.text: Which of the following inclusion bodies are seen in Alzheimer's Disease? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Hirano bodies

 

Explanation: 

 

Hirano bodies are eosinophilic rod-shaped intraneuronal inclusion bodies found in Alzheimer's disease. They represent actin aggregates found within neurons, particularly in the hippocampus. These inclusions are one of the characteristic microscopic findings in Alzheimer's disease, along with the more prominent neurofibrillary tangles (composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein) and amyloid plaques (composed of Aβ peptide). Hirano bodies are not specific to Alzheimer's disease but are commonly observed in this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bunina bodies - These are small eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions found in motor neurons in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). They are not characteristic of Alzheimer's disease.

 

Option B. Lewy bodies - These are eosinophilic intracytoplasmic neuronal inclusions composed of α-synuclein. They are the hallmark of Parkinson's disease and Lewy body dementia, not Alzheimer's disease. They appear as round eosinophilic inclusions in the substantia nigra and other regions.

 

Option D. Lafora bodies - These are intracytoplasmic inclusions composed of polyglucosan found in Lafora body disease, a rare form of progressive myoclonic epilepsy. They are not associated with Alzheimer's disease.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hirano bodies are actin-containing eosinophilic rod-shaped inclusions found in neurons in Alzheimer's disease, particularly in the hippocampus, representing one of several characteristic microscopic findings alongside the more diagnostically significant neurofibrillary tangles and amyloid plaques.

questions.text: On a histopathological slide of an atherosclerotic plaque, what does the presence of needle-shaped empty spaces indicate? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Cholesterol Cleft

 

Explanation: 

 

In atherosclerotic plaques, the characteristic needle-shaped empty spaces observed on histopathology represent cholesterol clefts. These spaces form when cholesterol crystals are dissolved during routine tissue processing, leaving behind characteristic empty clefts. They are typically found in the necrotic core of the atherosclerotic plaque, alongside foam cells, necrotic debris, fibrin, and other plasma proteins. These crystalline cholesterol deposits contribute to the "grumous" (soft and friable) nature of the lipid core in advanced atheromas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foam Cells - These are lipid-laden macrophages and smooth muscle cells found in atherosclerotic plaques, but they appear as cells with foamy cytoplasm due to accumulated lipid droplets, not as empty needle-shaped spaces. Foam cells are a key feature of atherosclerotic lesions, particularly in early fatty streaks.

 

Option C. Smooth Muscle Cells - These cells are present in atherosclerotic plaques, particularly in the fibrous cap, but they appear as spindle-shaped cells with nuclei, not as empty spaces. Smooth muscle cells play an important role in plaque stabilization through ECM production.

 

Option D. Glycogen - Glycogen deposits appear as clear spaces within cell cytoplasm but have a different morphology than cholesterol clefts and are not typically a prominent feature of atherosclerotic plaques. Glycogen is more commonly observed in glycogen storage diseases or in certain liver pathologies.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cholesterol clefts, appearing as characteristic needle-shaped empty spaces in histopathology, are hallmark features of advanced atherosclerotic plaques, representing crystalline cholesterol deposits that have been dissolved during tissue processing.

choices.text: Owl’s Eye Appearance on Transverse Section

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Anitschkow cells is not true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Owl’s Eye Appearance on Transverse Section

 

Explanation: 

 

Anitschkow cells (also spelled Anitschkow) are a characteristic finding in rheumatic heart disease. These cells are activated macrophages (histiocytes) found in Aschoff bodies, which are pathognomonic for rheumatic fever. Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. This characteristic nuclear appearance gives them the name "caterpillar cells" due to their resemblance to a caterpillar on longitudinal section. The "owl's eye" appearance is not associated with Anitschkow cells but is typically seen in cytomegalovirus infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Modified Cardiac Histocytes - This is correct. Anitschkow cells are plump activated macrophages (histiocytes) that appear in the myocardium as part of the inflammatory response in rheumatic heart disease.

 

Option B. Caterpillar Appearance on Longitudinal Section - This is correct. The centrally condensed chromatin appears as a slender, wavy ribbon, giving Anitschkow cells their characteristic "caterpillar" appearance.

 

Option D. Pathognomonic of Rheumatic Heart Disease - This is correct. Anitschkow cells are found in Aschoff bodies, which are pathognomonic for rheumatic fever and rheumatic heart disease. These lesions represent a characteristic inflammatory response in the myocardium.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Anitschkow cells are distinctive activated macrophages with a "caterpillar" nuclear appearance (not "owl's eye") that are pathognomonic for rheumatic heart disease, typically found within Aschoff bodies in the myocardium.

questions.text: Which region of the liver is most vulnerable to ischemic injury? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Centrilobular

 

Explanation: 

 

The centrilobular region (Zone 3) is most vulnerable to ischemic injury because it is located farthest from the blood supply. Blood flows from portal tracts (containing branches of portal vein and hepatic artery) toward the central vein, creating an oxygen gradient. Hepatocytes in the centrilobular region receive blood that has already passed through other zones, making them most susceptible to hypoxia during compromised circulation. Left-sided cardiac failure or shock may lead to hepatic hypoperfusion and hypoxia, causing ischemic coagulative necrosis of hepatocytes in the central region of the lobule (centrilobular necrosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Periportal - The periportal region (Zone 1) is closest to the incoming blood supply from both portal vein and hepatic artery branches. It receives blood with the highest oxygen concentration, making it most resistant to ischemic injury.

 

Option B. Midzonal - The midzonal region (Zone 2) lies between periportal and centrilobular areas. It has intermediate vulnerability to ischemic injury, becoming affected after the centrilobular region but before the periportal region.

 

Option D. Perihepatic - This is not a standard term in liver lobular architecture. The liver lobule is divided into centrilobular, midzonal, and periportal regions based on proximity to central veins and portal tracts.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The centrilobular region is most vulnerable to ischemic injury due to its location farthest from the blood supply, making it the first area to suffer during hypoxic conditions like cardiac failure or shock.

questions.text: Alzheimer type II astrocytes are not typically found in: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Alzheimer’s disease

 

Explanation: 

 

Alzheimer type II astrocytes are not found in Alzheimer's disease, despite the confusing similarity in names. These specialized astrocytes are characterized by enlarged, pale nuclei with prominent nucleoli and margination of chromatin. They develop in response to metabolic insults, particularly hyperammonemia. Alzheimer's disease instead shows neurofibrillary tangles, amyloid plaques, and neuritic plaques as its characteristic pathological findings, along with diffuse cerebral atrophy affecting the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatic encephalopathy - This condition is characterized by the presence of Alzheimer type II astrocytes. These astrocytic changes occur in response to elevated ammonia levels that cannot be properly metabolized due to liver dysfunction, resulting in cerebral toxicity.

 

Option C. Wilson's Disease - This inherited disorder of copper metabolism affects both the liver and brain. The liver damage leads to increased ammonia levels, which can cause formation of Alzheimer type II astrocytes in the brain as a secondary phenomenon.

 

Option D. Urea Cycle Disorders - These genetic disorders impair the body's ability to eliminate ammonia, leading to hyperammonemia. The elevated ammonia affects the brain and causes the development of Alzheimer type II astrocytes as a pathological response.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Despite their name, Alzheimer type II astrocytes are not found in Alzheimer's disease but are instead characteristic of metabolic encephalopathies associated with hyperammonemia, such as hepatic encephalopathy, Wilson's disease, and urea cycle disorders.

questions.text: Zellballen pattern is not typically observed in which of the following tumors? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Glioblastoma

 

Explanation: 

 

Zellballen pattern refers to a characteristic histological arrangement seen in paraganglionic tumors where neoplastic cells are arranged in nests or clusters separated by highly vascular fibrous septa. This is a hallmark finding in pheochromocytomas and paragangliomas. Pheochromocytomas are described as being "composed of polygonal to spindle-shaped chromaffin cells and their supporting cells, compartmentalized into small nests by a rich vascular network" - this describes the Zellballen pattern. Paragangliomas occurring at sites like the carotid body share similar features, as they derive from paraganglionic tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pheochromocytoma - This is incorrect because pheochromocytomas do exhibit the Zellballen pattern. Pheochromocytomas are characterized by "polygonal to spindle-shaped chromaffin cells and their supporting cells, compartmentalized into small nests by a rich vascular network," which describes the classic Zellballen arrangement.

 

Option B. Carotid Body Tumor - This is incorrect because carotid body tumors are paragangliomas that occur in the carotid body, a paraganglionic structure. These tumors show the same characteristic Zellballen pattern as pheochromocytomas because they derive from similar neural crest-derived tissue.

 

Option D. Paraganglioma - This is incorrect because these tumours can demonstrate a pattern resembling Zellballen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Zellballen pattern (nest-like arrangement of cells with rich intervascular stroma) is a characteristic histological feature of paraganglionic tumors like pheochromocytoma and carotid body tumors, but not of glioblastoma, which shows pseudopalisading necrosis and microvascular proliferation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the hallmark of "shock lung"? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Diffuse alveolar damage

 

Explanation: 

 

Diffuse alveolar damage (DAD) is the hallmark histopathological finding in shock lung, also known as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or hyaline membrane disease. ARDS is characterized by acute respiratory failure with bilateral pulmonary opacities caused by non-cardiac pulmonary edema. Histologically, DAD is characterized by the formation of hyaline membranes (made of fibrin and dead epithelial cells) lining the alveolar ducts, along with capillary congestion, necrotic alveolar epithelial cells, interstitial and intra alveolar edema, and inflammatory cell infiltration. This pattern develops in response to various insults including sepsis, trauma, pneumonia, and other conditions causing acute lung injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alveolar proteinosis - This is characterized by the accumulation of surfactant-like lipo proteinaceous material in the alveoli. It is not associated with shock lung or ARDS but occurs in primary or secondary pulmonary alveolar proteinosis.

 

Option B. Bronchiolitis obliterans - This refers to inflammation and fibrosis of bronchioles leading to their obstruction. It's associated with chronic conditions like chronic rejection in lung transplants or connective tissue diseases, not with acute shock lung.

 

Option C. Desquamative interstitial pneumonia - This is a type of smoking-related interstitial pneumonia characterized by accumulation of pigmented macrophages within alveolar spaces. It is not the pattern seen in shock lung/ARDS.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Diffuse alveolar damage characterized by hyaline membrane formation is the pathological hallmark of acute respiratory distress syndrome ("shock lung"), representing the common endpoint of various forms of acute lung injury.

questions.text: Langerhans cell histiocytosis is distinguished by which of the following histological features? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Linear grooves in the nuclei

 

Explanation: 

 

Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is characterized by proliferation of Langerhans cells, which have a distinctive nuclear morphology featuring linear grooves. These nuclear grooves are often described as having a "coffee bean" appearance and represent a key diagnostic feature of LCH. S-100 is a positive marker for Langerhans cell histiocytosis, which is listed alongside melanoma and schwannoma (referenced as "MaSaLa"). The disease is also notable for its association with BRAF V600E mutations, which can be targeted with BRAF inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S-100 negativity - This is incorrect because Langerhans cell histiocytosis is actually S-100 positive. S-100 is a marker for "Melanoma, Schwannoma, Langerhans cell histiocytosis (MaSaLa)."

 

Option B. CD-21 positivity - This is incorrect. CD21 is not a marker for Langerhans cell histiocytosis. CD21 is actually a receptor used by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) to infect B cells.

 

Option C. Basophilic Cytoplasm - This feature is not characteristic of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. The distinctive morphologic feature of LCH cells is their nuclear appearance, not cytoplasmic staining properties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langerhans cell histiocytosis is characterized by cells with distinctive nuclear grooves and positivity for S-100; it has been found to frequently harbor BRAF V600E mutations, making it potentially responsive to targeted therapy with BRAF inhibitors.

questions.text: Rokitansky protuberance is most commonly associated with which of the following tumors? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Teratoma

 

Explanation: 

 

Rokitansky protuberance is a characteristic feature of mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts) of the ovary. It refers to a solid, nodular projection from the wall of the cyst that often contains teeth and/or hair. The mature teratomas typically contain a mixture of tissues including skin, hair, cartilage, and sebaceous glands. They are described as having a ball of hair and a nodular projection from which teeth may protrude, which precisely describes the Rokitansky protuberance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sex cord-stromal tumors - These tumors arise from the specialized gonadal stroma and include granulosa-theca cell tumors, Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors, and fibroma-thecomas. They don't form cystic structures with Rokitansky protuberances but instead have their own distinctive morphologic patterns, often related to their hormone-producing capabilities.

 

Option C. Dysgerminoma - This is the ovarian counterpart of testicular seminoma and is described as the most common malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary. Dysgerminomas are typically solid rather than cystic tumors. They don't form Rokitansky protuberances but instead show characteristic histologic features with polyhedral cells, distinct cell membranes, and watery cytoplasm.

 

Option D. Yolk sac tumor - Also called endodermal sinus tumor, this is described as the second most common malignant germ cell tumor in the ovary and the most common malignant ovarian tumor in girls under 4 years of age. Histologically, it's characterized by Schiller-Duval bodies/glomeruloid bodies, not Rokitansky protuberances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rokitansky protuberance is a pathognomonic feature of mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts) of the ovary, representing a solid nodular area within the cyst that typically contains differentiated tissues such as teeth, bone, cartilage, and hair.

questions.text: Keratoderma Blennorrhagicum is most commonly associated with: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Reactive Arthritis

 

Explanation: 

 

Keratoderma blennorrhagicum is a characteristic skin manifestation associated with reactive arthritis. Reactive arthritis is part of the "PAIR" group of conditions associated with HLA-B27. Reactive arthritis typically follows an infection, particularly those caused by certain bacteria like Chlamydia or enteric pathogens. The condition is characterized by the classic triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis, with keratoderma blennorrhagicum being a distinctive skin lesion that can appear on the palms and soles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid Arthritis - This is an autoimmune disease associated with HLA-DR4, not HLA-B27. Rheumatoid arthritis typically presents with symmetric polyarthritis affecting small joints but doesn't feature keratoderma blennorrhagicum.

 

Option B. Psoriatic Arthritis - While psoriatic arthritis is part of the HLA-B27 associated group (PAIR), keratoderma blennorrhagicum is not a typical manifestation. Psoriatic arthritis is associated with psoriatic skin lesions, not keratoderma blennorrhagicum.

 

Option D. Ankylosing Spondylitis - Although ankylosing spondylitis is also part of the HLA-B27 associated group (PAIR), it primarily affects the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints) and doesn't typically present with keratoderma blennorrhagicum.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Keratoderma blennorrhagicum is a characteristic skin manifestation of reactive arthritis, which is part of the HLA-B27 associated spondyloarthropathies (PAIR: Psoriatic arthritis, Ankylosing spondylitis, IBD-associated arthritis, and Reactive arthritis).

choices.text: Vitamin B12 and Folic acid deficiency

questions.text: Which type of anemia is associated with an elevated Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV) and a normal Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin Concentration (MCHC)? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12 and Folic acid deficiency

 

Vitamin B12 and folate deficiencies are classic causes of macrocytic anemia with elevated MCV (typically >100 fL) and normal MCHC. These deficiencies impair DNA synthesis while RNA and protein synthesis continue, resulting in nuclear-cytoplasmic asynchrony and the production of larger red blood cells. The peripheral blood smear shows macrocytes that are often oval-shaped (macro-ovalocytes).

 

Evidences:            

 

  • Macrocytic anemias show MCV values >100 fL
  • Polychromasia describes red cells that are slightly larger than normal with a grayish-blue color on Wright-Giemsa stain
  • B12 deficiency affects myelination of the central nervous system while folate deficiency primarily affects rapidly dividing cells

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Sideroblastic anemia: Characterized by ringed sideroblasts in the bone marrow and typically presents with microcytosis or normocytosis, not macrocytosis.
  • Option C. Beta thalassemia: Associated with microcytosis (low MCV), hypochromia, and target cells. The MCHC is typically decreased.
  • Option D. Iron deficiency anemia: Presents with microcytosis (MCV <80 fL) and hypochromia (low MCHC). The peripheral blood smear shows small, pale red cells with increased central pallor.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Vitamin B12 and folate deficiencies impair DNA synthesis leading to megaloblastic changes with macrocytosis (elevated MCV) but normal MCHC, distinguishing them from other nutritional anemias.

questions.text: Which of the following anemias is associated with a hypoplastic marrow? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fanconi's Anemia

 

Fanconi's anemia is a constitutional form of aplastic anemia associated with hypoplastic bone marrow. It is an inherited disorder characterized by pancytopenia with bone marrow hypocellularity. Fanconi anemia typically presents in early childhood and is often accompanied by characteristic physical anomalies. The disease is caused by mutations in genes involved in DNA repair, leading to genomic instability and progressive bone marrow failure.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH): PNH is an acquired clonal stem cell disorder characterized by intravascular hemolysis. While PNH can be associated with bone marrow failure, it typically presents with a cellular bone marrow rather than hypoplasia. PNH is classified under "Pancytopenia with Cellular Bone Marrow."
  • Option C. Hypersplenism: Hypersplenism refers to the premature destruction or sequestration of blood cells by an enlarged spleen. It is a peripheral cause of cytopenia rather than a primary bone marrow disorder. Hypersplenism is classified under pancytopenia with cellular bone marrow and secondary to systemic diseases.
  • Option D. Myelofibrosis: In myelofibrosis, the bone marrow becomes replaced by fibrous tissue, but it is generally classified as a myeloproliferative disorder with a cellular (not hypoplastic) marrow before the development of fibrosis. Myelofibrosis is listed under pancytopenia with cellular bone marrow.

     

Educational Objective: 

 

Fanconi anemia is a constitutional form of aplastic anemia with hypoplastic bone marrow, while other causes of pancytopenia like PNH, hypersplenism, and myelofibrosis typically present with normal or increased marrow cellularity.

questions.text: Which of the following myeloproliferative disorders is least likely to be associated with massive splenomegaly? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Essential Thrombocytosis (ET)

 

Essential thrombocytosis is the myeloproliferative disorder least likely to be associated with massive splenomegaly. While patients with ET may develop splenomegaly, it is typically mild to moderate in size. The pathophysiology of ET primarily involves excess platelet production rather than the extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis that leads to massive splenomegaly in other MPNs. ET patients can present with erythromelalgia (burning pain and redness in extremities) and thrombotic or hemorrhagic complications, but splenomegaly, when present, is generally modest. The clinical focus in ET is typically on managing thrombotic risk rather than symptoms of splenomegaly.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML):  Splenomegaly is a hallmark physical finding in CML, occurring in 20-70% of patients. Many patients present with moderate to massive splenomegaly that can extend well below the costal margin, sometimes filling the left side of the abdomen and causing early satiety and abdominal discomfort.
  • Option B. Polycythemia Vera (PV):  PV commonly presents with splenomegaly due to expanded myeloproliferation and increased blood flow. The spleen enlargement can be substantial and is an important clinical feature of the disease, often used in monitoring disease progression.
  • Option D. Primary Myelofibrosis (PMF):  PMF is characterized by progressive, often massive splenomegaly due to extramedullary hematopoiesis. The enlarged spleen in PMF frequently causes significant symptoms including abdominal pain, early satiety, and mechanical discomfort. Spleen size in PMF typically increases as the disease progresses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among the myeloproliferative neoplasms, essential thrombocytosis typically presents with the least pronounced splenomegaly, while PMF and CML are most strongly associated with massive splenomegaly.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to be associated with secondary hemochromatosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)

 

Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria is least likely to be associated with secondary hemochromatosis because it is characterized by chronic intravascular hemolysis with persistent hemoglobinuria, which actually causes significant iron loss from the body. The hemoglobin released into the urine carries iron away from the body, requiring iron replacement rather than causing iron overload. Only PNH patients receiving long-term blood transfusions while on eculizumab treatment may develop iron overload.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Thalassemia Major: Strongly associated with secondary hemochromatosis due to two mechanisms: regular blood transfusions and ineffective erythropoiesis. Even without transfusions, patients with thalassemia major develop iron overload as ineffective erythropoiesis disrupts hepcidin-mediated regulation of iron absorption, leading to increased intestinal iron uptake.
  • Option B. Sickle Cell Anemia: Patients with severe sickle cell disease often require chronic transfusion therapy, leading to iron overload. The repeated transfusions to manage the disease contribute to secondary hemochromatosis over time.
  • Option C. Hereditary Spherocytosis: While less severe than thalassemia, hereditary spherocytosis involves chronic extravascular hemolysis. When patients require regular transfusions, they can develop iron overload. Even after splenectomy, transfusion-dependent patients remain at risk for hemochromatosis.

     

Educational Objective: 

 

Intravascular hemolysis with hemoglobinuria in PNH causes iron loss, making it the least likely condition to be associated with secondary hemochromatosis, while conditions requiring chronic transfusions (thalassemia major, sickle cell anemia) or causing ineffective erythropoiesis are highly associated with iron overload.

questions.text: Which of the following is the least common feature of Multiple Myeloma? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperviscosity syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

In multiple myeloma, the paraproteins are typically IgG or light chains, which cause hyperviscosity only at extremely high concentrations. Most multiple myeloma patients do not develop serum paraprotein levels high enough to cause clinical hyperviscosity syndrome, making it the least common feature among those listed.

 

Other Options: 

 

  • Option A. Bone pain: Incorrect. Bone pain is one of the most common presenting symptoms of multiple myeloma, affecting approximately 70% of patients at diagnosis. The pain results from osteolytic lesions and pathologic fractures caused by increased osteoclast activity.
  • Option B. Normocytic Normochromic Anemia: Incorrect. Anemia is present in about 70% of newly diagnosed multiple myeloma patients. The anemia is typically normocytic and normochromic, resulting from bone marrow infiltration by plasma cells and inhibition of erythropoiesis.
  • Option C. Susceptibility to bacterial infection: Incorrect. Increased susceptibility to infections is a hallmark feature of multiple myeloma due to hypogammaglobulinemia of normal immunoglobulins and impaired immune function. Patients commonly experience recurrent bacterial infections, particularly with encapsulated organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While bone pain, anemia, and increased infection risk represent cardinal features of multiple myeloma present in most patients, hyperviscosity syndrome occurs relatively rarely and requires extremely high paraprotein levels to become clinically significant.

choices.text: Increased FDP, decreased PT, increased antithrombin III
Increased FDP, prolonged PT, reduced platelets

questions.text: Which of the following is a finding seen in Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased FDP, prolonged PT, reduced platelets.

 

DIC is characterized by widespread intravascular fibrin formation that leads to consumption of clotting factors and platelets. Laboratory evidence of DIC includes prolonged PT/aPTT, thrombocytopenia, and elevated levels of fibrin degradation products (FDPs). These findings reflect the underlying pathophysiology: excessive thrombin generation leads to fibrin formation and consumption of clotting factors (prolonging PT), platelet activation and consumption (reduced platelet count), and secondary fibrinolysis (increased FDPs) as the body attempts to break down the widespread clots.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Increased fibrinogen, increased antithrombin III:  Because DIC typically features decreased fibrinogen due to consumption during widespread clotting. Plasma fibrinogen levels diminish acutely in severe cases of DIC. Similarly, antithrombin III levels are reduced in DIC (not increased), with high-grade DIC associated with antithrombin III activity <60% of normal.
  • Option B. Increased fibrinogen-antithrombin III complexes: While these complexes might form during coagulation, they are not a standard diagnostic marker for DIC. The diagnosis relies on more established markers like PT, platelet count, and FDPs.
  • Option C. Increased FDP, decreased PT, increased antithrombin III: This is incorrect because in DIC, the PT is prolonged (not decreased) due to consumption of clotting factors. Additionally, antithrombin III levels are typically decreased in DIC, not increased.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The laboratory diagnosis of DIC involves a constellation of findings that reflect both excessive coagulation (prolonged PT, thrombocytopenia) and increased fibrinolysis (elevated FDPs) - representing the "consumptive coagulopathy" that defines this disorder.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman presents with thrombocytopenia (platelet count < 50,000) and fragmented RBCs in a peripheral smear. Which of the following is the least likely differential diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Evan's syndrome.

 

Evan's syndrome is characterized by the combination of autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) with immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) and would be the least likely diagnosis in this case. Evan's syndrome features both conditions simultaneously but does not typically present with fragmented RBCs, which are characteristic of microangiopathic hemolytic anemias. The peripheral smear in Evan's syndrome would show spherocytes from the autoimmune hemolytic component rather than schistocytes (fragmented RBCs).

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP): TTP is characterized by thrombocytopenia and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia with schistocytes (fragmented RBCs). The pentad of TTP includes microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, renal failure, neurologic findings, and fever. Pregnancy can be a triggering factor for TTP, making this a very plausible diagnosis in this clinical scenario.
  • Option B. Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC):  DIC is a common complication in pregnancy, particularly with obstetric complications like abruptio placentae, amniotic fluid embolism, and retained dead fetus syndrome. DIC presents with thrombocytopenia and fragmented RBCs (schistocytes) due to microvascular thrombi. The condition involves abnormal activation of coagulation processes, consumption of clotting factors, and secondary fibrinolysis.
  • Option C. HELLP syndrome: HELLP (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets) syndrome is a serious pregnancy complication that features microangiopathic hemolytic anemia with fragmented RBCs and thrombocytopenia. It typically occurs in the third trimester and is considered part of the spectrum of preeclampsia, making it a highly likely diagnosis in this pregnant patient.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fragmented RBCs (schistocytes) on peripheral blood smear indicate a microangiopathic hemolytic process (as seen in TTP, DIC, and HELLP), whereas Evan's syndrome presents with spherocytes due to its autoimmune hemolytic component without microangiopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most reliable marker for diagnosing Acute STEMI specifically in athletes? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Troponin T or I

 

Cardiac troponins (specifically troponin I and T) are the most sensitive and specific markers for myocardial necrosis in acute coronary syndromes, including STEMI. Troponin I and T are the preferred biomarkers for diagnosing myocardial injury, with Troponin I having slightly higher cardiac specificity than Troponin T. These biomarkers remain the diagnostic standard regardless of patient population, including athletes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CK-MB: While CK-MB is a cardiac marker, it is less sensitive than troponin. It returns to baseline in 48-72 hours and serves better as a marker for re-infarction rather than initial diagnosis. It's problematic in athletes specifically because skeletal muscle damage from exercise can elevate CK-MB, reducing its diagnostic specificity.

Option C. C-reactive Protein: CRP is a general inflammatory marker but lacks specificity for cardiac damage. It has no established role in the primary diagnosis of STEMI.

 

Option D. LDH: LDH is characterized as a "Late Cardiac Marker" that undergoes an "LDH flip" (LDH1 > LDH2) in MI. However, it rises too late in the course of myocardial injury to be useful for early diagnosis, and has poor specificity for cardiac damage compared to troponins.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Troponin I and T remain the gold standard biomarkers for diagnosing myocardial infarction, including STEMI, due to their high cardiac specificity and sensitivity, even in athletic populations where other markers may be elevated from exercise.

questions.text: Which of the following is not typically used in the initial treatment of acute, life-threatening cardiogenic pulmonary edema? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Digoxin

 

Digoxin is not part of the initial treatment for acute, life-threatening cardiogenic pulmonary edema. The initial management of acute heart failure with pulmonary edema follows the mnemonic "LMNOP" - Loop diuretics, Morphine, Nitrates, Oxygen, and Position (fowler's position). Digoxin has no role in the acute management of cardiogenic pulmonary edema and is generally relegated to therapy for patients with chronic heart failure who remain profoundly symptomatic despite optimal neurohormonal blockade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Morphine:  Morphine is included in the "LMNOP" mnemonic (the "M") for treating acute heart failure with pulmonary congestion. It helps reduce anxiety, preload, and afterload in the setting of acute pulmonary edema.

 

Option C. Furosemide: Loop diuretics like furosemide are the "L" in the "LMNOP" mnemonic and are essential first-line agents to address congestion in acute heart failure with pulmonary edema. They promote rapid diuresis and venodilation.

 

Option D. Non-invasive Positive Pressure Ventilation: This is represented by "O" for oxygen in the "LMNOP" mnemonic. Non-invasive ventilation is a key component of the initial management of acute pulmonary edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The acute management of cardiogenic pulmonary edema focuses on immediate relief of congestion and respiratory distress using the "LMNOP" approach (Loop diuretics, Morphine, Nitrates, Oxygen/non-invasive ventilation, and Positioning), while digoxin is reserved for chronic heart failure management in specific situations.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to be associated with Infective Endocarditis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Small ASD.

 

Isolated atrial septal defect (ASD) is specifically excluded from cardiac conditions predisposing to infective endocarditis. When evaluating endocarditis risk factors, conditions that create turbulent blood flow with high-velocity jets are most concerning, as they damage endothelial surfaces and provide locations for bacterial adherence. Small ASDs typically create minimal hemodynamic disturbance and lack the significant turbulent flow pattern that promotes vegetation formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Small VSD: Ventricular septal defects, even small ones, create abnormal blood flow patterns with higher-velocity jets that can damage endothelium, creating a nidus for bacterial adherence. While repaired VSDs have lower risk, unrepaired VSDs remain a predisposing condition for endocarditis.

 

Option C. Mild MR: Mitral regurgitation represents a valvular abnormality with regurgitant flow that predisposes to endocarditis. The turbulent flow across the abnormal valve creates conditions favorable for bacterial adherence and vegetation formation, even when the regurgitation is mild.

 

Option D. Mild TR: Tricuspid regurgitation, like mitral regurgitation, creates turbulent flow patterns that can damage endothelium and facilitate bacterial adhesion. Valvular regurgitation at any valve is a recognized risk factor for infectious endocarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While most valvular and structural cardiac abnormalities increase endocarditis risk through turbulent flow patterns, isolated atrial septal defect stands as a notable exception, carrying minimal risk for infective endocarditis.

questions.text: Which of the following medications has been associated with an increased risk of cardiac mortality? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rofecoxib

 

Rofecoxib (a COX-2 inhibitor) has been associated with increased cardiac mortality. NSAIDs, especially selective COX-2 inhibitors, create a small but definite increased risk of myocardial infarction and mortality in patients with ischemic heart disease. When NSAID use is unavoidable in IHD patients, clinicians should select agents with the lowest cardiovascular risk profile and use them at the lowest effective dose for the shortest duration possible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metoprolol: Metoprolol is a selective β1-blocker that reduces mortality in patients with ischemic heart disease. Beta blockers are first-line therapy for managing stable ischemic heart disease and have demonstrated benefits in reducing mortality and reinfarction rates after myocardial infarction.

 

Option C. Fenofibrate:  Fenofibrate has not been documented as increasing cardiac mortality in IHD patients. It functions primarily to raise HDL cholesterol and lower triglycerides as part of lipid management therapy.

 

Option D. Losartan: Losartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) that is recommended for patients with IHD. ARBs are preferred agents for hypertension control in stable ischemic heart disease patients, especially those with reduced ejection fraction (<50%), diabetes mellitus, or chronic kidney disease.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

NSAIDs, particularly COX-2 inhibitors like rofecoxib, increase cardiovascular risk in patients with ischemic heart disease and should be avoided when possible in this population.

questions.text: A patient experiences sudden breathlessness following a subclavian vein cannulation. Upon examination, there are absent breath sounds and hyper-resonance on percussion on one side of the chest. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iatrogenic Pneumothorax

 

Latrogenic pneumothorax is a type of traumatic pneumothorax that occurs following medical procedures. The clinical presentation of sudden breathlessness after subclavian vein cannulation with absent breath sounds and hyper-resonance on percussion is classic for pneumothorax. The leading causes of iatrogenic pneumothorax include transthoracic needle aspiration, thoracentesis, and the insertion of central intravenous catheters.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malposition of central venous catheter: While catheter malposition can cause complications, it would not produce the physical exam findings of absent breath sounds and hyper-resonance characteristic of air in the pleural space.

 

Option C. Air embolism via air embolus: Air embolism would present with different symptoms including neurological deficits, cardiovascular collapse, or pulmonary symptoms like dyspnea, but would not cause absent breath sounds with hyper-resonance on percussion.

 

Option D. Cardiac Arrhythmia: Arrhythmias can occur during central line placement but would present with palpitations, dizziness, or hemodynamic instability without the characteristic respiratory exam findings noted in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Iatrogenic pneumothorax is a common complication of central venous catheterization, particularly with the subclavian approach, presenting with sudden breathlessness, absent breath sounds, and hyper-resonance on percussion of the affected side.

choices.text: The presence of contralateral mediastinal lymph nodes precludes surgical resection
For patients over 70 years with advanced disease, single-agent chemotherapy is preferred
Among the Asian population, squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of NSCLC
Gefitinib shows the highest efficacy in female smokers with adenocarcinoma

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding Non-Small Cell Lung Carcinoma (NSCLC) are accurate, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Among the Asian population, squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of NSCLC

 

In Asian populations, adenocarcinoma (not squamous cell carcinoma) is the most common histologic type of NSCLC. This demographic pattern is important because it correlates with the higher prevalence of EGFR mutations observed in Asian patients, which has significant implications for treatment selection and response to targeted therapies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The presence of contralateral mediastinal lymph nodes precludes surgical resection: Contralateral mediastinal lymph node involvement (N3 disease) indicates stage IIIB disease, which is generally considered unresectable. This represents locally advanced disease where surgery would not provide survival benefit.

 

Option B. For patients over 70 years with advanced disease, single-agent chemotherapy is preferred: For elderly patients (>70 years) with advanced NSCLC, single-agent chemotherapy is often preferred due to reduced toxicity while maintaining modest efficacy. This approach provides a better risk-benefit ratio in this population.

 

Option D. Gefitinib shows the highest efficacy in female smokers with adenocarcinoma: This statement is incorrect. Gefitinib, an EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor, shows highest efficacy in female NON-smokers with adenocarcinoma histology. Smoking status is a critical negative predictor of response to EGFR inhibitors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The epidemiology of NSCLC varies by population, with adenocarcinoma being the predominant subtype in Asian populations, associated with higher rates of EGFR mutations that impact therapeutic approaches and response to targeted therapies.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with generalized edema and hypertension. Urine examination reveals subnephrotic proteinuria (<2g/day) and microscopic hematuria. Serum complement levels are low, and the patient tests positive for anti-hepatitis C antibodies. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mixed Cryoglobulinemia

 

This patient presents with the classic triad of mixed cryoglobulinemia: hepatitis C infection, low complement levels, and glomerular involvement manifesting as subnephrotic proteinuria and hematuria. Mixed cryoglobulinemia is strongly associated with hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection. The condition involves circulating cryoglobulins (immune complexes that precipitate at cold temperatures) that deposit in glomerular capillaries, causing a membranoproliferative pattern of injury with hypocomplementemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post-streptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN): While PSGN presents with low complement levels (especially C3), hematuria, and proteinuria, it follows streptococcal pharyngitis or impetigo, not hepatitis C infection. PSGN typically has ASO titer elevation and/or other evidence of streptococcal infection, which isn't mentioned here.

 

Option C. Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis (MPGN): This is a histologic pattern that can occur in hepatitis C infection, but cryoglobulinemic glomerulonephritis is the more specific diagnosis with hepatitis C. In fact, cryoglobulinemic glomerulonephritis often presents with an MPGN pattern on biopsy, making this a less specific diagnosis.

 

Option D. Focal Segmental Glomerular Sclerosis (FSGS): FSGS typically presents with nephrotic-range proteinuria (>3.5g/day), and complement levels are usually normal. While secondary FSGS can occur with viral infections, hepatitis C is not a common cause. The subnephrotic proteinuria and hypocomplementemia make this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mixed cryoglobulinemia should be strongly considered in any patient with hepatitis C infection who presents with renal manifestations, particularly when accompanied by hypocomplementemia and subnephrotic proteinuria.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with widespread edema, skin ulcers, and high blood pressure. Urine analysis reveals subnephrotic proteinuria (<2g/day) and microscopic hematuria. Serum complement levels are reduced, and she tests positive for anti-hepatitis C antibodies. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Essential Mixed Cryoglobulinemia

 

Explanation: 

 

Essential mixed cryoglobulinemia is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. The patient presents with the classic triad of purpura (skin ulcers), arthralgia, and weakness. This condition is strongly associated with hepatitis C infection, which the patient tests positive for. The presence of hypocomplementemia (reduced serum complement levels) along with mild proteinuria and hematuria further supports this diagnosis. Mixed cryoglobulinemia typically involves a vasculitic process that can present with skin lesions and kidney manifestations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post-streptococcal Glomerulonephritis: While post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis can present with hypocomplementemia and hematuria, it typically occurs after streptococcal infections, not hepatitis C. It generally affects children and young adults, and the patient's age (60) makes this less likely. Additionally, it doesn't typically cause the widespread edema and skin ulcers described.

 

Option C. Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis (MPGN): MPGN can be associated with hepatitis C and low complement levels. However, MPGN typically presents with more significant proteinuria (often nephrotic range) than described in this case. While MPGN can be secondary to cryoglobulinemia, the clinical presentation more directly points to cryoglobulinemia as the primary diagnosis.

 

Option D. Focal Segmental Glomerular Sclerosis (FSGS): FSGS is not typically associated with hepatitis C infection or hypocomplementemia. It usually presents with significant proteinuria (often nephrotic range) without the systemic manifestations seen in this patient (skin ulcers, vasculitis).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hepatitis C virus infection is strongly associated with mixed cryoglobulinemia, which can manifest with skin lesions, arthralgia, weakness, hypocomplementemia, and kidney involvement with subnephrotic proteinuria and microscopic hematuria.

choices.text: Failure to acidify urine to a pH of < 5
Increased risk of formation of urinary stones

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Type 1 Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA) is incorrect? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Associated with Hyperkalemia

 

Type 1 RTA (distal RTA) is characterized by hypokalemia, not hyperkalemia. The classic distal RTA presents with hypokalemia, a non-AG metabolic acidosis, low urinary NH4+ excretion (positive UAG, low urine [NH4+]), and inappropriately high urine pH (pH > 5.5). Hyperkalemia is instead a characteristic feature of Type 4 RTA, which involves generalized distal nephron dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Associated with nephrolithiasis: Type 1 RTA patients typically have hypocitraturia and hypercalciuria, which lead to nephrolithiasis, nephrocalcinosis, and bone disease. The reduced urinary citrate and increased calcium excretion create an environment favorable for stone formation.

 

Option B. Failure to acidify urine to a pH of < 5:  A hallmark of Type 1 RTA is the inability to acidify urine below pH 5.5 despite systemic acidosis. This occurs due to a defect in H+ secretion in the distal tubule, leading to persistently elevated urine pH even when blood pH is low.

 

Option C. Increased risk of formation of urinary stones:  The combination of hypocitraturia (reduced urinary citrate, which normally inhibits stone formation) and hypercalciuria (increased calcium excretion) in Type 1 RTA significantly increases the risk of calcium phosphate stone formation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Type 1 (distal) RTA is characterized by hypokalemia, non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, inappropriately high urine pH (>5.5), hypocitraturia, and hypercalciuria, which contribute to the development of nephrolithiasis and nephrocalcinosis. Hyperkalemia is instead a feature of Type 4 RTA.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome two years ago now presents with facial edema and proteinuria. What is the most likely finding on their renal biopsy? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Minimal Change Disease

 

Minimal Change Disease (MCD) is the most likely finding on renal biopsy in this patient with recurrent nephrotic symptoms. MCD frequently follows a relapsing and remitting course. After initial treatment and remission, approximately 70-75% of adults with MCD will experience relapses, characterized by the return of proteinuria and edema. The facial edema mentioned is typical of nephrotic syndrome due to hypoalbuminemia and resultant decreased oncotic pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amyloid Nephropathy: Amyloid nephropathy typically causes a progressive decline in renal function rather than a relapsing-remitting course. It involves deposition of amyloid fibrils (AL or AA type) in glomeruli, leading to proteinuria. However, amyloidosis usually presents with a more indolent, progressive course with multi-system involvement, not the relapsing pattern suggested in this case.

 

Option C. Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN): RPGN is characterized by rapid deterioration of renal function over days to weeks, with hematuria, proteinuria, and red cell casts. It typically presents with a nephritic rather than nephrotic picture. The clinical history of previous nephrotic syndrome with relapse after two years is inconsistent with the acute, aggressive nature of RPGN.

 

Option D. Crescentic Glomerulonephritis: Crescentic glomerulonephritis, characterized by the formation of cellular crescents in Bowman's space, represents severe glomerular injury. Like RPGN, it presents with rapidly deteriorating renal function and a primarily nephritic picture, not the recurrent nephrotic presentation described in this case.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Minimal Change Disease should be considered in patients with relapsing nephrotic syndrome, as it characteristically demonstrates a pattern of remissions and relapses over time.

choices.text: It typically follows an episode of hemorrhagic colitis
Fever is usually mild or absent
Serotonin plays no role in its pathogenesis

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) is the least accurate? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The condition is often self-limiting

 

HUS is a serious form of thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA) characterized by endothelial cell injury, platelet and hyaline thrombi formation, and resultant organ damage. The evidence indicates HUS requires specific therapeutic interventions based on its variant type, with significant potential for morbidity and mortality, particularly related to acute kidney injury. This contradicts the notion that it's typically self-limiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It typically follows an episode of hemorrhagic colitis: This is accurate for STEC HUS (also known as D+ HUS), where diarrhea, often bloody, precedes microangiopathic hemolytic anemia within 1 week in >80% of cases. This gastrointestinal prodrome is characteristic of Shiga toxin-producing E. coli infection.

 

Option C. Fever is usually mild or absent: This statement is correct. The clinical presentation typically includes abdominal pain, cramping, and vomiting, while fever is notably absent in most cases of classic HUS.

 

Option D. Serotonin plays no role in its pathogenesis: The pathogenesis of HUS involves Shiga toxins binding to glycolipid receptors (Gb3) on renal microvascular cells, triggering inflammatory cascades with cytokines and chemokine receptors that result in microvascular thrombosis. Serotonin is not implicated in this pathogenic pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HUS represents a serious disease process requiring variant-specific management approaches, with treatment potentially including supportive care, antimicrobial considerations, plasma therapies, or complement inhibition depending on the subtype.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is used for the treatment of constipation-predominant Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS-C)? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lubiprostone

 

Lubiprostone is specifically indicated for the treatment of IBS-C (IBS with constipation). It functions as a prosecretory agent that activates intestinal chloride channels, increasing intestinal fluid secretion and promoting bowel movements. This mechanism makes it particularly effective for constipation-predominant IBS, helping to alleviate both the constipation and associated discomfort in affected patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cholestyramine: Cholestyramine is a bile acid sequestrant primarily used to treat bile acid malabsorption (BAM). While it can affect bowel function, it is not indicated for IBS-C treatment and may actually worsen constipation in some patients. It's mainly used when excess bile acids are contributing to diarrhea.

 

Option C. Alosetron: Alosetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist that has a constipating effect and is used in specific cases of severe diarrhea-predominant IBS (IBS-D) in women who have failed conventional therapy. It would be contraindicated in IBS-C as it would worsen constipation.

 

Option D. Rifaximin: Rifaximin is a non-absorbable antibiotic used in IBS-D (diarrhea-predominant IBS), not IBS-C. It targets bacterial overgrowth in the small intestine which may contribute to IBS-D symptoms. It has no established therapeutic role in treating constipation-predominant IBS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of IBS should be targeted to the predominant symptom pattern. Lubiprostone specifically addresses constipation in IBS-C by increasing intestinal fluid secretion, whereas other agents like rifaximin are indicated for diarrhea-predominant IBS (IBS-D).

questions.text: A patient undergoing treatment with ketoconazole for a fungal infection develops symptoms of Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD). Which of the following medications should be avoided? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cisapride

 

Cisapride is the correct answer because it's contraindicated in patients taking ketoconazole. Ketoconazole is a potent inhibitor of CYP3A4 enzyme, which metabolizes cisapride. When used together, cisapride levels can increase dramatically, resulting in QT prolongation and potentially fatal cardiac arrhythmias including torsades de pointes. This dangerous drug interaction necessitates avoiding cisapride in patients on ketoconazole therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Itopride: Unlike cisapride, itopride is not significantly metabolized by CYP450 enzymes, making it safer to use with ketoconazole. It's primarily eliminated via renal excretion, reducing the risk of drug-drug interactions.

 

Option C. Metoclopramide: Metoclopramide is primarily metabolized through different pathways and has minimal interaction with CYP3A4 inhibitors like ketoconazole. It remains a safe prokinetic option for GERD management in patients on antifungal therapy.

 

Option D. Domperidone: While domperidone has some CYP3A4 metabolism and caution is advised, it doesn't have the same level of life-threatening interaction profile as cisapride does with ketoconazole.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cisapride is absolutely contraindicated with CYP3A4 inhibitors like ketoconazole due to the risk of potentially fatal cardiac arrhythmias; alternative prokinetics should be selected for GERD management in such patients.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin deficiencies is most commonly seen in short bowel syndrome with ileal resection? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B12 (Cyanocobalamin)

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency is most commonly seen in short bowel syndrome with ileal resection because vitamin B12 (cobalamin) absorption occurs exclusively in the terminal ileum. B12 requires binding to intrinsic factor (produced by gastric parietal cells) and this B12-IF complex is then absorbed only in the terminal ileum. When this portion of the bowel is resected, patients inevitably develop B12 deficiency regardless of dietary intake, as there is no alternative absorption site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Thiamine is primarily absorbed in the duodenum and jejunum, not the ileum. Short bowel syndrome with ileal resection would not typically cause thiamine deficiency unless the proximal small bowel is also affected.

 

Option C. Folic Acid: Folate is primarily absorbed in the jejunum, not the ileum. While folate deficiency may occur in short bowel syndrome, it's not specifically associated with ileal resection. Folate absorption can still occur in other parts of the small intestine.

 

Option D. Vitamin K: While vitamin K can be malabsorbed in conditions affecting fat absorption (since it's fat-soluble), vitamin K is primarily absorbed in the jejunum and ileum. Additionally, vitamin K is also produced by intestinal bacteria, providing an alternative source. B12 deficiency would be more directly and severely affected by ileal resection specifically.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Terminal ileum is the exclusive site for vitamin B12 absorption, which requires intrinsic factor binding; therefore, ileal resection consistently causes B12 deficiency requiring parenteral supplementation.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin deficiencies is most likely to occur in short bowel syndrome? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B12

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency is most likely to occur in short bowel syndrome since B12 absorption occurs exclusively in the terminal ileum. When portions of the small intestine are surgically removed or functionally impaired, B12 absorption is significantly compromised. Malnutrition due to inadequate caloric intake is exceedingly rare with short bowel syndrome, but specific micronutrient deficiencies can develop. B12 deficiency may be secondary to impaired absorption or diminished oral intake, resulting in megaloblastic anemia and neurologic symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Biotin: Biotin is absorbed throughout the small intestine and can also be synthesized by intestinal bacteria. Therefore, biotin deficiency is less common in short bowel syndrome compared to B12 deficiency.

 

Option C. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Thiamine is primarily absorbed in the jejunum. While thiamine deficiency can occur in malabsorptive states, it's less specific to short bowel syndrome than B12 deficiency.

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K is both absorbed in the small intestine and synthesized by colonic bacteria. Unless there is extensive small bowel and colonic resection, vitamin K deficiency is less common than B12 deficiency in short bowel syndrome.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Vitamin B12 absorption occurs exclusively in the terminal ileum, making its deficiency a hallmark of short bowel syndrome, especially when the terminal ileum is resected or diseased.

questions.text: A man presents with a history of hematemesis involving approximately 500 ml of blood. On examination, his spleen is palpable 5 cm below the left costal margin. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Portal Hypertension

 

The patient presents with hematemesis (vomiting blood) and splenomegaly (enlarged spleen palpable 5 cm below the costal margin). These two findings strongly suggest portal hypertension as the most likely diagnosis. Portal hypertension is defined as an elevation of hepatic venous pressure gradient >5 mmHg and is directly responsible for variceal hemorrhage, a major complication that can present with hematemesis. The combination of splenomegaly and upper GI bleeding in the form of hematemesis is characteristic of portal hypertension.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Isolated splenic vein thrombosis: While this can cause localized portal hypertension with splenomegaly, it typically causes gastric rather than esophageal varices. The pattern of bleeding would be different, and it's much less common than generalized portal hypertension.

 

Option C. Drug-induced gastritis: This can cause hematemesis but doesn't explain the significant splenomegaly. Gastritis alone would not cause spleen enlargement of this magnitude (5 cm below costal margin).

 

Option D. Mallory-Weiss tear: This is a mucosal laceration at the gastroesophageal junction typically occurring after forceful vomiting. While it can cause hematemesis, it would not explain the splenomegaly, which is a key finding in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of significant hematemesis and splenomegaly strongly suggests portal hypertension with variceal bleeding, which is one of the major life-threatening complications of cirrhosis requiring prompt management.

questions.text: Which of the following is classified as a 'Small Vessel Vasculitis'? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microscopic Polyangiitis

 

Microscopic polyangiitis is classified as a small vessel vasculitis in the Chapel classification of vasculitis (2012). It primarily affects capillaries, venules, and arterioles, which are the defining vessels involved in small vessel vasculitis. MPA is characterized by pauci-immune necrotizing vasculitis that frequently manifests with glomerulonephritis and pulmonary capillaritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN): PAN is classified as a medium vessel vasculitis. It predominantly affects medium and small muscular arteries, particularly at vessel bifurcations. Unlike small vessel vasculitides, PAN does not typically involve arterioles, capillaries, or venules.

 

Option C. Giant Cell Vasculitis: This is a large vessel vasculitis that primarily affects the aorta and its major branches, particularly the extracranial branches of the carotid artery. Its predilection for temporal arteries has given it the alternative name of temporal arteritis.

 

Option D. Takayasu's Disease: Takayasu arteritis is classified as a large vessel vasculitis. It primarily affects the aorta and its branches, with a strong predilection for the aortic arch and its major branches. Subclavian artery involvement is most common (93% of cases).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microscopic polyangiitis is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by necrotizing vasculitis affecting small vessels with few or no immune complexes. It commonly presents with glomerulonephritis and pulmonary capillaritis, and is frequently associated with p-ANCA (anti-MPO) antibodies, distinguishing it from other vessel-specific vasculitides.

questions.text: Which of the following is not typically associated with Type I Cryoglobulinemia? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Strongly Positive Rheumatoid factor

 

Type I cryoglobulinemia is characterized by the presence of monoclonal immunoglobulins (usually IgM or IgG) that precipitate in cold temperatures. Type I cryoglobulinemia features include monoclonal Ig (usually IgM), hyperviscosity, thrombosis, and normal complement levels. Unlike Types II and III (mixed cryoglobulinemias), Type I cryoglobulinemia is not associated with rheumatoid factor activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperviscosity: This is incorrect as an answer because hyperviscosity is a key feature of Type I cryoglobulinemia. The monoclonal paraproteins in Type I can lead to symptoms of hyperviscosity, including visual disturbances, headaches, and neurological symptoms.

 

Option B. Monoclonal IgM paraprotein: This is incorrect as an answer because monoclonal immunoglobulins, particularly IgM, are the defining characteristic of Type I cryoglobulinemia, typically associated with plasma cell dyscrasias.

 

Option C. Normal complement levels: This is incorrect as an answer because Type I cryoglobulinemia is indeed associated with normal C3/C4 complement levels, unlike the hypocomplementemia seen in Type II mixed cryoglobulinemia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Type I cryoglobulinemia is characterized by monoclonal immunoglobulins, hyperviscosity, and normal complement levels, but lacks the rheumatoid factor activity that is characteristic of mixed cryoglobulinemias (Types II and III).

choices.text: Sleep EEG studies have shown disruption in REM sleep
SPECT studies have shown reduced blood flow to the thalamus

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Fibromyalgia is accurate? (NEET PG 2016)
