questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sleep EEG studies have shown disruption in REM sleep

 

Fibromyalgia (FM) is characterized by chronic widespread musculoskeletal pain and tenderness with associated neuropsychological symptoms including fatigue, unrefreshing sleep, cognitive dysfunction, anxiety, and depression. Sleep disturbance is one of the key neuropsychological symptoms reported by FM patients. Sleep EEG studies in fibromyalgia patients consistently demonstrate interruption of deep sleep patterns by intrusion of alpha waves, which leads to disruption in REM sleep. This sleep architecture disturbance contributes to the unrefreshing sleep and persistent fatigue reported by patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. More common in males: This is incorrect. Fibromyalgia is far more common in women than in men, with a ratio of ~9:1 in clinical settings. Even in population-based surveys, the female-to-male ratio is 2-3:1. The epidemiological data clearly demonstrates a strong female predominance in this condition.

 

Option C. Increased cortisol response to stress: This is incorrect. Fibromyalgia is not associated with increased cortisol response to stress. In fact, fibromyalgia is often associated with dysregulation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis, but this typically manifests as a blunted cortisol response rather than an increased response.

 

Option D. SPECT studies have shown reduced blood flow to the thalamus: This is incorrect. While central nervous system involvement is key in fibromyalgia pathophysiology, there is no established evidence showing SPECT studies with reduced blood flow to the thalamus as a consistent finding in this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sleep disturbance is a core feature of fibromyalgia, with objective EEG abnormalities showing alpha wave intrusion into deeper sleep stages and REM disruption, contributing to the unrefreshing sleep and persistent fatigue that characterize this condition.

questions.text: The occurrence of hyperthyroidism following the administration of supplemental iodine to individuals with endemic iodine deficiency goiter is known as: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Jod-Basedow effect

 

The Jod-Basedow effect refers to hyperthyroidism that occurs when individuals with preexisting thyroid disease (particularly those with endemic iodine deficiency goiter) receive supplemental iodine. In patients with long-standing iodine deficiency, the thyroid glands develop autonomous nodules that produce excess thyroid hormone when suddenly exposed to iodine supplementation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wolff-Chaikoff Effect: This is the transient inhibition of thyroid hormone synthesis that occurs in response to high iodine intake. In normal glands, this effect is temporary (9-10 days) as the thyroid "escapes" from this inhibition. It causes hypothyroidism, not hyperthyroidism.

 

Option C. Pendred's syndrome: This is a genetic disorder characterized by congenital sensorineural hearing loss and goiter. It's not related to iodine administration causing hyperthyroidism.

 

Option D. De Quervain's thyroiditis: This is another name for subacute granulomatous thyroiditis, which is a painful inflammatory condition of the thyroid, typically following a viral infection. It's not directly related to iodine administration.

 

Educational Objective: The Jod-Basedow effect represents paradoxical hyperthyroidism following iodine administration in patients with preexisting iodine deficiency, as their thyroid glands have adapted to produce hormones even with minimal iodine availability.

questions.text: What is the lowest detection limit for third-generation TSH assays? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.004 mIU/L

 

The third-generation TSH immunochemiluminometric assays (ICMAs) have extremely high sensitivity, capable of detecting very low TSH levels. Extremely sensitive assays can detect TSH levels ≤0.004 mIU/L, though for practical clinical purposes, assays sensitive to ≤0.1 mIU/L are generally sufficient. This high sensitivity is what allows these modern assays to discriminate between the lower limit of the normal range and the suppressed values seen in thyrotoxicosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.04 mIU/L: This value is incorrect as it is 10 times higher than the actual detection limit of third-generation TSH assays, which can detect levels down to 0.004 mIU/L.

 

Option B. 0.1 mIU/L: This represents the practical sensitivity threshold that is considered sufficient for most clinical purposes, but is not the actual detection limit of third-generation assays.

 

Option D. 0.0044 mIU/L: This value is incorrect. The detection limit for extremely sensitive third-generation TSH assays is 0.004 mIU/L.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Third-generation TSH immunochemiluminometric assays can detect TSH levels as low as 0.004 mIU/L, which is essential for discriminating between the lower limit of the normal reference range and the suppressed values found in thyrotoxicosis, though for most clinical applications, assays with sensitivity to 0.1 mIU/L are adequate.

questions.text: Which of the following agents is not typically used in the management of chronic hypocalcemia? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Etidronate.

 

Etidronate, a bisphosphonate, is not used in treating chronic hypocalcemia. Bisphosphonates are primarily antiresorptive agents that inhibit osteoclast activity and are indicated for conditions like osteoporosis, Paget's disease, and hypercalcemia. In fact, bisphosphonates can worsen hypocalcemia by reducing bone resorption and calcium release from bone, which is counterproductive in chronic hypocalcemic states.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiazides: This is incorrect because thiazides are actually used in chronic hypocalcemia management. Thiazides reduce urinary calcium excretion (↓Uca) and help increase serum calcium levels (↑S.ca), making them beneficial in hypocalcemic states.

 

Option C. Elemental calcium: This is incorrect because calcium supplementation is the cornerstone of managing chronic hypocalcemia. Oral calcium (carbonate or citrate) is a fundamental component in the treatment regimen for patients with persistent hypocalcemia.

 

Option D. Vitamin D analogs: This is incorrect because vitamin D analogs, particularly calcitriol (1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D), are essential in hypocalcemia management. Calcitriol enhances intestinal calcium absorption and is typically administered alongside calcium supplements.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The management of chronic hypocalcemia centers on calcium replacement (oral calcium), optimization of intestinal calcium absorption (vitamin D analogs/calcitriol), and reduction of urinary calcium excretion (thiazides), while bisphosphonates are contraindicated as they can worsen hypocalcemia.

choices.text: Subacute Combined Degeneration of the Spinal Cord

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy arrives at the outpatient clinic with a history of progressively worsening difficulty in walking and frequent episodes of falling. Physical examination shows an ataxic gait with absent deep tendon reflexes. The Babinski sign is negative, and the plantar reflex demonstrates an extensor response. Which diagnosis is most likely? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Friedreich's Ataxia

 

Friedreich's ataxia is characterized by progressive cerebellar ataxia, absent deep tendon reflexes, and pyramidal signs. The clinical presentation of a 12-year-old boy with progressively worsening gait difficulty, ataxia, and absent deep tendon reflexes strongly suggests this diagnosis. Friedreich's ataxia typically presents in childhood or adolescence (before age 25) and affects the posterior columns, spinocerebellar tracts, and corticospinal tracts, leading to the combination of sensory ataxia and pyramidal signs. The loss of deep tendon reflexes reflects peripheral sensory neuronopathy, while extensor plantar responses indicate corticospinal tract involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option Subacute Combined Degeneration: While this also affects posterior columns and corticospinal tracts, it's caused by vitamin B12 deficiency and typically presents in adults. It would show increased, not absent, deep tendon reflexes.

 

Option Becker's Muscular Dystrophy: This dystrophinopathy presents with proximal muscle weakness rather than ataxia. Reflexes would be preserved until late in the disease, and there would be no sensory involvement or extensor plantar responses.

 

Option Tabes Dorsalis: This manifestation of tertiary syphilis is extremely rare in children. While it causes sensory ataxia and areflexia, it lacks pyramidal signs (would not have extensor plantar responses) and would be highly unusual in a 12-year-old.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The combination of progressive ataxia, absent deep tendon reflexes, and extensor plantar responses in an adolescent is the classic presentation of Friedreich's ataxia, reflecting the disease's characteristic involvement of multiple spinal cord pathways.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman visits the outpatient clinic complaining of pain, fatigue, and weakness in both lower limbs. She reports a history of childhood paralysis affecting both lower limbs, from which she had a good functional recovery. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Post-Polio Syndrome

 

Post-Polio Syndrome (PPS) is characterized by new weakness, fatigue, and pain that develops decades after an initial episode of paralytic poliomyelitis from which the patient had at least partial recovery. The patient's history of childhood paralysis affecting both lower limbs with good functional recovery, followed by new symptoms of pain, fatigue, and weakness in the same distribution decades later (now at age 45) is the classic presentation of PPS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polymyositis: Polymyositis typically presents with subacute onset of symmetric proximal muscle weakness without a prior history of paralysis. It does not follow a pattern of recurrence after decades of stability. The inflammatory myopathies like polymyositis are characterized by elevated muscle enzymes, characteristic EMG findings, and muscle biopsy showing inflammation, which are not mentioned in this case. The history of childhood paralysis with good recovery followed by late deterioration is not consistent with polymyositis.

 

Option C. Muscular Dystrophy: Muscular dystrophies are inherited disorders with progressive weakness that typically begins in childhood or early adulthood. They do not present with an episode of paralysis followed by recovery and then delayed deterioration decades later. Most muscular dystrophies show a pattern of continuous progression rather than the biphasic course described in this patient.

 

Option D. Neuropathy: Peripheral neuropathies typically present with distal weakness, sensory symptoms, and often absent reflexes. While some neuropathies can affect the lower limbs predominantly, the history of childhood paralysis with recovery followed by late deterioration is not characteristic of most neuropathies. Additionally, neuropathies often have sensory symptoms which aren't prominent in this case.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Post-polio syndrome presents as new weakness, fatigue, and pain occurring decades after recovery from acute paralytic poliomyelitis, typically affecting the same muscle groups that were originally involved.

questions.text: A patient with traumatic paraplegia due to injury at the thoracic cord level of T3 is found to have a blood pressure of 210/120 mm Hg. What should be the initial management? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nifedipine

 

This patient is exhibiting autonomic dysreflexia, a life-threatening emergency seen in patients with spinal cord injuries at or above T6. The T3 level injury in this patient has disrupted descending inhibitory pathways that normally regulate sympathetic outflow. When a noxious stimulus occurs below the level of injury (often bladder distention, bowel impaction, or skin irritation), there is massive sympathetic discharge resulting in severe hypertension. Immediate blood pressure control with a rapidly-acting antihypertensive agent like nifedipine is essential to prevent complications such as stroke, seizures, or myocardial infarction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subcutaneous LMWH: While deep venous thrombosis prophylaxis is important in spinal cord injury patients, LMWH does not address the immediate life-threatening hypertension from autonomic dysreflexia.

 

Option B. Steroids: Steroids have no role in the acute management of autonomic dysreflexia. They were previously used in acute spinal cord injury but are not indicated for this hypertensive emergency.

 

Option D. Normal saline/Dextrose: Intravenous fluids would not help and may worsen hypertension in autonomic dysreflexia. Blood pressure reduction, not volume expansion, is the priority.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency in patients with spinal cord injuries at or above T6 requiring immediate blood pressure control with rapid-acting antihypertensives while simultaneously identifying and removing the triggering stimulus.

questions.text: What part of the brain is primarily damaged in cases of chorea? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Striatum

 

Chorea is characterized by involuntary, rapid, irregular, and purposeless movements that flow from one body part to another. The primary pathological changes in chorea involve the striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen). In Huntington's disease, the most well-known cause of chorea, there is selective degeneration of medium spiny neurons in the striatum, with progressive atrophy of the caudate nucleus and putamen visible on neuroimaging. This striatal degeneration disrupts the normal inhibitory output to the globus pallidus, ultimately leading to disinhibition of the thalamus and excessive movement manifestations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subthalamus: While the subthalamic nucleus plays an important role in the basal ganglia circuitry and movement control, it is not the primary site of pathology in chorea. Damage to the subthalamic nucleus typically results in hemiballismus, which involves more violent, flinging movements than chorea.

 

Option B. Globus pallidus: The globus pallidus is affected secondarily in chorea due to altered inputs from the diseased striatum. Primary globus pallidus lesions more commonly result in parkinsonian features or dystonia rather than chorea.

 

Option C. Substantia nigra: The substantia nigra is the primary site of degeneration in Parkinson's disease, leading to dopamine deficiency and hypokinetic movement disorders. It is not the primary site of pathology in choretic disorders.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Chorea primarily results from pathology in the striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen), which disrupts the normal basal ganglia circuitry and leads to disinhibition of thalamic nuclei, resulting in the characteristic random, flowing involuntary movements.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is the most resistant to antiseptics? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Prions

 

Explanation:

 

Prions are the most resistant structures to antiseptics and disinfectants. Prions require specific and extreme sterilization methods compared to other microorganisms. The recommended methods for prion sterilization are particularly aggressive: autoclaving at 134°C for 1 to 1.5 hours, treatment with 1 N NaOH for 1 hour, or using 0.5% sodium hypochlorite for 2 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spores - While bacterial spores are highly resistant to many antiseptics, they are less resistant than prions. Spores can be killed by proper autoclaving (121°C for 15 minutes) or using strong disinfectants like glutaraldehyde (2% for 10-14 hours).

 

Option C. Cysts - Cysts of protozoa are moderately resistant to antiseptics but less resistant than both spores and prions. They don't require the extreme conditions needed for prion inactivation.

 

Option D. Fungi - Fungi are generally susceptible to intermediate-level disinfectants. Intermediate-level disinfectants including alcohols, phenolics, and halogens are effective against fungi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prions require the most extreme sterilization conditions of all infectious agents, including extended high-temperature autoclaving (134°C for 1-1.5 hours) or strong chemical treatment (1N NaOH or concentrated hypochlorite), making them the most resistant structures to antiseptics and disinfection methods.

questions.text: A five-year-old child presents with pustular lesions on the lower legs. The culture from the lesions shows hemolytic gram-positive cocci. Which test would best aid in the provisional diagnosis of Group A streptococcal pyoderma? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Bacitracin sensitivity

 

Explanation:

 

Bacitracin sensitivity is the most appropriate test for identifying Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) from the pustular lesions. Group A streptococci are characteristically sensitive to bacitracin, which serves as a key identifying feature in the laboratory. This susceptibility pattern helps differentiate S. pyogenes from other beta-hemolytic streptococci, particularly Group B streptococci which are typically resistant to bacitracin. In the clinical context of a child with pustular skin lesions and isolation of beta-hemolytic gram-positive cocci, the bacitracin sensitivity test is an essential diagnostic tool.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catalase positive test - This is incorrect because streptococci, including Group A Streptococcus, are catalase negative. The catalase test is primarily used to differentiate staphylococci (catalase positive) from streptococci (catalase negative). While Staphylococcus species can cause pustular skin lesions, the question specifically asks about diagnosing Group A streptococcal pyoderma.

 

Option B. Optochin sensitivity - This is incorrect because optochin sensitivity is used specifically for identifying Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococci). Group A streptococci are not characteristically sensitive to optochin. This test helps differentiate pneumococci from other alpha-hemolytic streptococci but is not useful for identifying beta-hemolytic Group A streptococci.

 

Option C. Bile solubility - This is incorrect because the bile solubility test is specific for Streptococcus pneumoniae. Pneumococci are soluble in bile while other streptococci, including Group A Streptococcus, are not. This test is not used in the identification of beta-hemolytic streptococci causing skin infections.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bacitracin sensitivity testing is a critical diagnostic tool for the presumptive identification of Group A Streptococcus (S. pyogenes) in clinical specimens, with sensitivity to bacitracin differentiating it from other beta-hemolytic streptococci, particularly Group B streptococci which are typically resistant.

questions.text: The endotoxin of which gram-negative bacterium does not play a role in the pathogenesis of the disease it causes? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Vibrio cholerae

 

Explanation:

 

Vibrio cholerae is the correct answer because unlike typical Gram-negative infections, the pathogenesis of cholera is primarily mediated by an exotoxin (cholera toxin) rather than its endotoxin. Cholera toxin activates adenylate cyclase in intestinal epithelial cells, leading to massive secretion of water and electrolytes, resulting in the characteristic profuse, watery "rice-water" diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E. coli - The endotoxin (lipopolysaccharide) of E. coli plays a significant role in its pathogenesis, particularly in septic shock. The endotoxin activates inflammatory pathways, complement cascades, and can lead to fever, hypotension, and disseminated intravascular coagulation.

 

Option B. Klebsiella - The endotoxin of Klebsiella is a major virulence factor in its pathogenesis. During infection, Klebsiella's endotoxin contributes to the inflammatory response, potential septic shock, and tissue damage.

 

Option D. Pseudomonas aeruginosa - Endotoxin plays an important role in Pseudomonas infections. The lipopolysaccharide component of P. aeruginosa activates inflammatory responses contributing to tissue damage and systemic effects during infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While all Gram-negative bacteria contain endotoxin (lipopolysaccharide) in their cell walls, the relative importance of this component in disease pathogenesis varies. For Vibrio cholerae, the exotoxin (cholera toxin) is the primary virulence factor responsible for the characteristic clinical manifestations.

questions.text: The effects of cholera toxin are mediated through which of the following second messengers? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. cAMP

 

Explanation:

 

Cholera toxin mediates its effects through cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) as the second messenger. The toxin consists of A and B subunits, where the B subunit binds to GM1 ganglioside receptors on intestinal epithelial cells, allowing the entry of the A subunit. Once inside the cell, fragment A activates adenylate cyclase, resulting in increased intracellular cAMP levels. Elevated cAMP then activates protein kinase A, which phosphorylates the CFTR chloride channels, leading to massive secretion of chloride ions and water into the intestinal lumen while inhibiting sodium absorption. This mechanism is responsible for the characteristic profuse watery diarrhea seen in cholera.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. cGMP - This is incorrect because cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) is not the primary second messenger involved in cholera toxin's mechanism of action. While cGMP is an important second messenger in other systems (particularly in smooth muscle relaxation and visual signal transduction), it is not the pathway utilized by cholera toxin.

 

Option C. Ca²⁺-calmodulin - This is incorrect because calcium-calmodulin signaling is not the primary mechanism used by cholera toxin. Calcium as a second messenger is involved in many cellular processes including muscle contraction and neurotransmitter release, but cholera toxin specifically targets the cAMP pathway.

 

Option D. IP3/DAG - This is incorrect because inositol trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG) signaling pathway is not utilized by cholera toxin. The IP3/DAG pathway is typically activated by G protein-coupled receptors linked to phospholipase C, resulting in calcium release from intracellular stores, but this is not how cholera toxin exerts its effects.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cholera toxin causes profuse secretory diarrhea by increasing intracellular cAMP levels through ADP-ribosylation of G proteins, which leads to constitutive activation of adenylate cyclase and subsequent massive fluid secretion into the intestinal lumen.

questions.text: Which of the following Vibrio species is most commonly linked to ear infections? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Vibrio alginolyticus

 

Explanation:

 

Vibrio alginolyticus is the Vibrio species most commonly linked to ear infections. This halophilic (salt-loving) Vibrio is the most salt-tolerant of the species, capable of growing at salt concentrations greater than 10%. V. alginolyticus is specifically associated with eye and ear infections, including otitis externa and otitis media. These infections typically occur after exposure to seawater, making this organism a significant concern for swimmers and those engaged in water activities in marine environments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vibrio parahaemolyticus - This species primarily causes food-borne gastroenteritis following consumption of undercooked seafood, particularly oysters. While it can occasionally cause otitis and wound infections as extraintestinal manifestations, it is not the Vibrio species most commonly associated with ear infections.

 

Option C. Vibrio vulnificus - This species is known for causing severe, potentially fatal infections, particularly in individuals with liver disease or immunocompromised states. It primarily causes primary sepsis in high-risk individuals and wound infections. V. vulnificus is notable for being the only Vibrio that ferments lactose, but it is not typically associated with ear infections.

 

Option D. Vibrio fluvialis - This is a less common Vibrio species that can cause gastroenteritis. It is not particularly associated with ear infections compared to V. alginolyticus, which has a strong association with otitis externa and otitis media.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Vibrio alginolyticus is the most salt-tolerant Vibrio species and has a particular tropism for causing eye and ear infections (otitis externa and otitis media), making it an important pathogen to consider in patients with ear infections following exposure to seawater.

questions.text: What is the infective dose range for Salmonella Typhi? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 10² to 10⁵ bacilli

 

Explanation:

 

The infective dose for Salmonella Typhi falls within the range of 10² to 10⁵ bacilli. This is a relatively low infectious dose compared to many other enteric pathogens, which explains why typhoid fever can be transmitted through contaminated food or water even with modest bacterial loads.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. One bacillus: This is incorrect because a single bacterial cell of S. Typhi is insufficient to cause infection. Even highly virulent pathogens typically require multiple organisms to establish infection and overcome host defenses.

 

Option B. 1 to 10 bacilli: This is incorrect because this range is too low for S. Typhi to establish infection. While S. Typhi has a relatively low infectious dose, it still requires more than 10 organisms.

 

Option D. 10⁸ to 10¹⁰ bacilli: This is incorrect because this range is too high. Such a high bacterial load would be required for organisms with low pathogenicity, unlike S. Typhi which can cause infection with a much lower dose (10² to 10⁵).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Salmonella Typhi has a moderate infectious dose requirement (10² to 10⁵ bacilli), which contributes to its efficiency as a pathogen and explains why typhoid fever can spread relatively easily through contaminated water and food supplies.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic infection associated with Nocardia Asteroides? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Brain abscess

 

Explanation:

 

Brain abscess is a characteristic infection associated with Nocardia asteroides. In cases of disseminated nocardiosis, the brain is the most common site of extrapulmonary infection. Nocardia species, including N. asteroides, initially cause pulmonary infection in most cases, but then can spread hematogenously to distant sites. When this dissemination occurs, brain abscess formation is the most frequently observed extrapulmonary manifestation. These brain abscesses are often multiple, have a high mortality rate, and are particularly common in immunocompromised patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diarrhea - This is incorrect because Nocardia species typically cause respiratory tract infections, subcutaneous infections, or disseminated disease, but are not characteristically associated with gastrointestinal manifestations like diarrhea. Nocardia primarily affects the lungs, brain, and skin rather than the digestive tract.

 

Option B. Secondary dissemination to the liver - While Nocardia can disseminate to various organs from primary pulmonary infection, liver involvement is not specifically identified as a characteristic or common site of Nocardia infection. The brain, skin, kidneys, bone, and muscle are more typical sites of dissemination.

 

Option D. Colonic diverticulosis - This is incorrect because colonic diverticulosis is not an infectious condition caused by Nocardia or any other microorganism. Diverticulosis refers to the presence of diverticula (small pouches) in the colon wall, which is typically related to age, diet, and genetic factors rather than infection.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Nocardia asteroides characteristically causes pulmonary infections that can disseminate hematogenously, with brain abscess being the most common manifestation of extrapulmonary nocardiosis, especially in immunocompromised hosts.

questions.text: A Gram stain of periorbital exudate in a case of severe panophthalmitis with cellulitis in an elderly diabetic patient reveals irregular, broad, aseptate branching hyphae. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Apophysomyces sp

 

Explanation:

 

The microscopic finding of irregular, broad, aseptate branching hyphae in a periorbital exudate is characteristic of zygomycosis (mucormycosis/phycomycosis). Zygomycetes (including Apophysomyces species) feature broad, ribbon-like, non-septate (or sparsely septate) hyphae that often show irregular branching. This infection commonly presents as rhinocerebral (rhino-orbito-cerebral) form, affecting the nose, nasal sinuses, and orbit, especially in patients with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus as seen in this elderly diabetic patient with panophthalmitis and cellulitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida: Incorrect because Candida appears as oval or spherical budding cells (yeast) with pseudohyphae, not as broad aseptate hyphae. Candida forms are typically Gram-positive yeast cells with or without pseudohyphae.

 

Option B. Aspergillus: Incorrect because Aspergillus species produce narrow (2-10 μm), septate, hyaline hyphae with dichotomous branching at acute angles. The hyphae described in the question are aseptate, not the septate hyphae characteristic of Aspergillus.

 

Option C. Penicillium: Incorrect because Penicillium, like Aspergillus, produces septate hyphae, not the aseptate hyphae seen in this case. Penicillium has septate hyphae with branched conidiophores resembling a brush.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rhinocerebral zygomycosis (mucormycosis) is a life-threatening opportunistic infection that typically presents with broad, aseptate hyphae on microscopic examination and has a strong association with diabetes mellitus with ketoacidosis. Rapid diagnosis and treatment are essential due to its high mortality rate.

questions.text: A farmer from the sub-Himalayan region presents with multiple ulcers on the leg. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Sporothrix schenckii

 

Explanation:

 

The case describes a patient from the sub-Himalayan region with multiple ulcers on the leg. This clinical presentation strongly suggests sporotrichosis, which is caused by Sporothrix schenckii. Sporotrichosis is frequently encountered in gardeners, forest workers and manual laborers, with the sub-Himalayan hilly areas being an endemic region in India. The disease typically manifests as noduloulcerative lesions that develop following traumatic implantation, such as from a thorn prick, which is common in agricultural workers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichophyton rubrum: Incorrect because T. rubrum is a dermatophyte that causes superficial mycoses like tinea (ringworm) infections. It typically presents with circular, dry, erythematous, scaly, and itchy lesions rather than ulcers. Dermatophytoses don't typically progress to form multiple ulcers as described in this case.

 

Option B. Cudotrichum species: This genus is not a known human pathogen causing subcutaneous or cutaneous infections with the presentation described.

 

Option D. Aspergillus: Incorrect because Aspergillus species predominantly cause respiratory infections (allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, aspergilloma, or invasive aspergillosis) or superficial infections like otomycosis. They don't typically cause multiple cutaneous ulcers in immunocompetent individuals, especially not in the pattern described for this farmer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Sporotrichosis is a chronic subcutaneous mycosis caused by Sporothrix schenckii that frequently affects agricultural workers and presents as noduloulcerative lesions along lymphatics (lymphocutaneous form) following minor trauma, with the sub-Himalayan region being an endemic area for this infection in India.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics is not common to both B cells and T cells? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Class I MHC Expression


Explanation:


T cells express Class I MHC on their surface (to present antigens to CD8+ T cells), but B cells do not express Class I MHC. B cells are more involved in antibody production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positive Selection During Development: Both undergo positive selection in the thymus for T cells and bone marrow for B cells to ensure they can recognize self-MHC molecules

 

Option C. Antigen-Specific Receptors - This IS common to both. T cells possess T cell receptors (TCR) while B cells have surface immunoglobulins, both serving as antigen recognition units.

 

Option D. All of the above - This is incorrect because options B and C represent features shared by both cell types.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

T cells express Class I MHC on their surface (to present antigens to CD8+ T cells), but B cells do not express Class I MHC. B cells are more involved in antibody production.

choices.text: Abnormal Expression of MHC Class II Molecule

questions.text: Epstein-Barr virus induces autoimmunity through which of the following mechanisms? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Polyclonal B Cell Activation

 

Explanation:


Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is specifically known to induce autoimmunity through polyclonal B cell activation. This mechanism involves direct stimulation of multiple B cell clones without antigen specificity, leading to excessive antibody production including autoantibodies. EBV can bypass the normal antigen-specific activation pathway, stimulating many B cell clones simultaneously and resulting in hypergammaglobulinemia with potential self-reactive antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Molecular Mimicry - This mechanism involves microorganisms sharing antigenic determinants with self-antigens, causing cross-reactive immune responses. While this is a legitimate mechanism of autoimmunity (examples include Shigella flexneri and HLA B27), it's not the primary mechanism by which EBV induces autoimmunity.

 

Option B. Release of Sequestered Antigen - This occurs when normally hidden self-antigens (like spermatozoa or ocular antigens) are released following tissue injury, triggering an immune response. EBV does not primarily operate through this mechanism.

 

Option C. Abnormal Expression of MHC Class II Molecule - While alterations in MHC expression can contribute to autoimmunity, this is not the characteristic mechanism by which EBV induces autoimmune responses.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

EBV contributes to autoimmunity primarily through polyclonal B cell activation, which results in excessive production of antibodies, including potentially self-reactive ones, independent of specific antigenic stimulation.

questions.text: A child presents with recurrent episodes of respiratory infections, primarily caused by bacteria with polysaccharide-rich capsules. Which immunoglobulin subclass deficiency is most likely to be responsible for these infections? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. IgG2

 

Explanation:


IgG2 antibody is specifically directed against polysaccharide antigens and is the most important defense against encapsulated bacteria. When a child has a deficiency in this particular IgG subclass, they become highly susceptible to recurrent infections with polysaccharide-encapsulated bacteria, which commonly cause respiratory infections. These include pathogens like Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and other bacteria with prominent polysaccharide capsules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgA - While IgA deficiency is the most common immunodeficiency and can lead to respiratory infections, it primarily affects mucosal immunity rather than specific defense against encapsulated bacteria. IgA deficiency typically manifests as increased susceptibility to sinopulmonary infections and diarrhea.

 

Option B. IgG1 - This is the most abundant IgG subclass (65% of total IgG) and responds primarily to protein antigens, not polysaccharide capsules. A deficiency would cause broad susceptibility to infections but not specifically to encapsulated bacteria.

 

Option D. IgG3 - This subclass typically responds to protein antigens rather than polysaccharides. IgG3 deficiency would not specifically predispose to infections with encapsulated bacteria.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

IgG2 is the critical immunoglobulin subclass for defense against encapsulated bacteria with polysaccharide-rich capsules, making its deficiency the most likely cause of recurrent respiratory infections with these specific pathogens.

choices.text: The most common mechanism involves the production of neutralizing enzymes by bacteria.
Plasmid-mediated resistance is transmitted exclusively through vertical transmission.
The complete elimination of the target binding site may contribute to vancomycin resistance in some enterococci.
Alteration of the target binding site contributes to antibiotic resistance in Streptococcus pneumoniae.

questions.text: Regarding antibiotic resistance, which of the following statements is NOT true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Plasmid-mediated resistance is transmitted exclusively through vertical transmission.

 

Explanation:


Plasmid-mediated resistance is NOT transmitted exclusively through vertical transmission. This statement is false because plasmids are primarily transferred horizontally between bacteria through conjugation (direct cell-to-cell contact), transduction (via bacteriophages), or transformation (uptake of DNA from the environment). This horizontal transfer is what makes plasmid-mediated resistance particularly problematic in clinical settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The most common mechanism involves the production of neutralizing enzymes by bacteria - This is true. Many bacteria produce enzymes like beta-lactamases that can degrade or modify antibiotics, rendering them ineffective. This is a major mechanism of resistance against beta-lactam antibiotics.

 

Option C. The complete elimination of the target binding site may contribute to vancomycin resistance in some enterococci - This is true. Vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) can alter peptidoglycan precursors so they no longer contain the D-Ala-D-Ala terminal sequences to which vancomycin binds.

 

Option D. Alteration of the target binding site contributes to antibiotic resistance in Streptococcus pneumoniae - This is true. S. pneumoniae can develop resistance to penicillins through alterations in penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs), which are the target binding sites for beta-lactam antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plasmid-mediated resistance is primarily spread through horizontal gene transfer mechanisms (conjugation, transduction, and transformation), making it particularly efficient at spreading resistance genes within bacterial populations and between different bacterial species.

questions.text: The principle underlying vaccination is based on: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Immunologic Memory

 

Explanation:


Vaccination fundamentally relies on establishing immunologic memory in the body. When a vaccine is administered, it triggers a primary immune response that generates not only effector cells but crucially, memory B and T cells. These memory cells persist long after the primary response has subsided and enable a faster, stronger secondary immune response upon subsequent exposure to the same pathogen. This rapid recall response provides protection against the actual disease-causing organism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Agglutination - This is merely an antigen-antibody reaction where particulate antigens clump together in the presence of specific antibodies. While this may occur as part of immune responses following vaccination, it is not the fundamental principle underlying vaccination's protective effect.

 

Option B. Phagocytosis - This refers to the process by which cells engulf and digest foreign particles. Though phagocytosis plays a role in immune responses including those triggered by vaccines, it is not the core principle of vaccination.

 

Option D. Clonal detection - This is not a standard immunological concept. If referring to clonal selection theory, this describes how lymphocytes with receptors for specific antigens are selected to proliferate, but it's a mechanism rather than the underlying principle of vaccination.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Vaccination's effectiveness is rooted in immunologic memory - the ability of the adaptive immune system to "remember" previously encountered antigens and mount rapid, robust responses upon re-exposure, providing long-term protection against pathogens.

questions.text: The anteroposterior diameter of the skull is smallest in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Brachycephaly

 

Explanation:

 

Brachycephaly (short-headed) is characterized by a skull that has a short anteroposterior diameter compared to its width. This is reflected in the cephalic index formula:

Cephalic Index = (Maximum transverse breadth of skull / Maximum anteroposterior length of skull) × 100

 

Brachycephalic skulls have a cephalic index of 80-85 and are found in Mongoloids. This high index value indicates that the width is large relative to a shorter anteroposterior length.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dolichocephaly (Incorrect) Dolichocephalic (long-headed) skulls have a cephalic index of 70-75. This indicates a longer anteroposterior diameter relative to width, not shorter.

 

Option B. Mesocephaly (Incorrect) Mesaticephalic (medium-headed) skulls have a cephalic index of 75-80. This represents an intermediate anteroposterior diameter.

 

Option D. Trigonocephaly (Incorrect) Trigonocephaly refers to a condition where the skull has a triangular appearance when viewed from above due to premature fusion of the metopic suture. It's not directly classified in the cephalic index system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cephalic index measures the ratio between skull width and length - the higher the index (as in brachycephaly), the shorter the anteroposterior diameter relative to width.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is commonly used to visualize and detect blood stains, even after they have been washed out? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Luminol test

 

Explanation:

 

The luminol spray test is specifically designed for detecting invisible blood stains including those on cleaned surfaces where blood has been washed out. Luminol (aminophthalhydrazide) produces a blue-white to yellowish-green chemiluminescent glow when it reacts with the peroxidase activity in blood, even in minute quantities. This test is particularly useful for locating and defining areas of blood on cleaned floors and old blood stains, and is considered the most sensitive among presumptive blood tests.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Infrared photography - Used for enhancing visualization of ink differences in documents, gunshot residues, or bruises under skin—not suitable for detecting washed-away blood stains.

 

Option C. Ultraviolet light - UV light is useful for detecting fluorescent substances, especially seminal stains, saliva, or urine. Blood does not fluoresce under UV and may actually absorb UV light, appearing as dark areas. Washed-out blood will not be detectable under UV.

 

Option D. Magnifying lens - Merely magnifies visible stains, offers no utility in detecting stains that are washed out or invisible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The luminol spray test is the most sensitive presumptive tool for detecting latent or washed-out blood stains. It produces a blue-white glow in darkness due to a chemiluminescent reaction with the heme group in blood. Though highly sensitive, it is not confirmatory and may react with non-blood oxidizing substances, necessitating confirmatory tests afterward.

choices.text: Imprisonment for one year and/or a fine of Rs. 1000
Imprisonment for two years and/or a fine of Rs. 5000
Imprisonment for 1 month and/or a fine of Rs. 500

questions.text: A person "X" strikes another individual "Y" with a wooden stick after being provoked, resulting in a bruise measuring 3x3 cm on the forearm. No additional injuries are observed. Which of the following statements accurately reflects the potential punishment? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Imprisonment for 1 month and/or a fine of Rs. 500

 

Explanation:

 

The situation described involves a case of simple hurt. Person X has caused a 3×3 cm bruise on Y's forearm with a wooden stick after provocation, with no additional injuries. This constitutes a case of simple hurt under Section 323 IPC, which specifies imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to five hundred rupees, or with both.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Imprisonment for one year and/or a fine of Rs. 1000 This punishment is excessive for simple hurt. This level of punishment would typically be associated with more serious offenses or aggravated forms of hurt.

 

Option B: Imprisonment for two years and/or a fine of Rs. 5000 This punishment is significantly excessive for simple hurt. This would be more appropriate for grievous hurt under Section 325 IPC, but the described injury (single bruise) does not qualify as grievous hurt.

 

Option D: Rigorous Imprisonment for six months the punishment is disproportionate to the offense described. Rigorous imprisonment for six months would be applicable for more serious offenses, not for causing a simple bruise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The above question is as per old laws. It is not applicable as per new laws.

questions.text: Disclosure of the identity of a rape victim is protected under which section of the Indian Penal Code (IPC)? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Section 228A

 

Explanation:

 

Section 228A of the Indian Penal Code specifically deals with disclosing the identity of rape victims. This section prohibits the publication or broadcasting of a rape victim's name or any information that could reveal their identity. The offense is punishable with imprisonment of up to 2 years. This legal provision exists to protect the privacy, dignity, and safety of sexual assault survivors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A (Section 292A): This section does not relate to protecting rape victim identities. The IPC sections dealing with sexual offenses are clearly enumerated, and 292A is not listed among the relevant provisions for victim protection.

 

Option C (Section 376A): Section 376 and its subsections deal with the sexual offenses themselves, specifically defining rape and its punishment. These sections address the criminal act rather than the protection of victim identity.

 

Option D (Section 225A): This section is not related to rape victims or identity protection. It does not appear in the compilation of sexual offense statutes in the IPC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The above question is as per old laws. It is not applicable as per new laws.

questions.text: Which of the following tools is used to determine the rupture of the hymen and whether the rupture is recent or old in rape victims? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Glaister Keene Rod

 

Explanation:

 

The Glaister-keen rod is specially designed for examining the hymen in sexual assault victims. It consists of a glass rod with one end expanded into a globe (1-2.5 cm diameter). When inserted gently behind the hymen, it displays the hymen edges over the glass, allowing small tears and nicks to be visualized clearly by smoothing out folds and indentations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gahn Rod - This instrument is not recognized in forensic medicine for hymen examination.

 

Option C. Carm Rod - This is not a valid tool for hymen examination in sexual assault cases.

 

Option D. Cylinder Rod - While rod-shaped instruments may be used in medical examinations, this specific tool is not used for hymen assessment in forensic cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Glaister-keen rod is an essential forensic tool that enables accurate documentation of hymen tears by providing proper visualization of the hymen edges, helping distinguish between recent tears (with sharp, red, bleeding edges) and older injuries.

choices.text: Relative constriction of the shaft of the penis

questions.text: An accused in a sodomy case is brought for a medical examination. Upon questioning, he reveals that he is the active agent and a regular participant. Which of the following findings is unlikely to be present during his examination? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Presence of smegma

 

Explanation:

 

In a habitual active agent of sodomy, smegma would be unlikely to be present. Smegma is a thick, cheesy secretion that accumulates under the prepuce and around the corona glandis. This substance gets rubbed off during sexual intercourse and takes approximately 24 hours to redeposit. Since the question mentions the accused is a "regular participant" as an active agent, the repeated sexual activity would prevent smegma accumulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fecal smell - This is an expected finding in an active agent of sodomy. The forensic examination typically reveals traces of feces and lubricant about the genitalia along with the peculiar smell of anal glands, making this a common finding during examination.

 

Option C. Tear of frenulum - This can be present in an active agent, especially when forceful penetration occurs against resistance. Forceful penetration may produce tears or bruising of the frenulum or prepuce and abrasion of the glans penis.

 

Option D. Relative constriction of the shaft of the penis - This is a characteristic finding in habitual active agents of sodomy. The penis usually becomes twisted with constriction at some distance from the glans due to the constricting force of the sphincter ani during repeated anal intercourse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In sodomy examination, the absence of smegma is significant forensic evidence of recent sexual activity in the active partner, while other physical findings like distinctive odors, penile constriction patterns, and trauma to frenulum are typically present in habitual active agents.

questions.text: For medical termination of pregnancy (MTP), whose consent is required? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Wife

 

Explanation:

 

For medical termination of pregnancy, the consent required is explicitly that of the pregnant mother for all gestational periods. This applies whether the pregnancy is less than 20 weeks, between 20-24 weeks, or beyond 24 weeks. The consent requirements remain consistent - the pregnant woman's consent is always the primary requirement.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Husband - The husband's consent is not required for MTP at any stage. Only the pregnant woman needs to provide consent.
  • Option C. Both Wife and Husband - This is incorrect as only the pregnant woman's consent is mandatory, not both partners' consent.
  • Option D. Either Wife or Husband - This option is wrong because specific consent of the pregnant woman is required, not an either/or situation.

 

Additional consent is only needed from a guardian if the woman is under 18 years or mentally unfit. Medical authorization requirements increase with gestational age - one doctor for <20 weeks, two doctors for 20-24 weeks, and a medical board for >24 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Medical Termination of Pregnancy, the fundamental principle is the pregnant woman's autonomy - her consent alone is sufficient for the procedure, with additional medical oversight increasing with gestational age.

questions.text: The 'Japanese Detergent Suicide Technique' involves the mixing of common household chemicals to produce: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. H₂S and other poisonous gases

 

Explanation:

 

The 'Japanese Detergent Suicide Technique' involves mixing common household chemicals (typically an acid like toilet bowl cleaner with sulfur-containing products) to produce hydrogen sulfide (H₂S) and other toxic gases. H₂S is a highly toxic gas that inhibits cellular respiration by binding to cytochrome oxidase. This method became notorious in Japan where individuals would mix these chemicals in enclosed spaces like cars or small rooms, leading to rapid death by toxic gas inhalation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Deadly foam - The technique does not primarily produce a deadly foam. While some foaming may occur during the chemical reaction, the lethal component is the gaseous hydrogen sulfide released.

 

Option C. Deadly acidic compound - Though acids may be used in the reaction, the deadly element is not the acidic compound itself but rather the gaseous products (primarily H₂S) released from the chemical reaction.

 

Option D. Deadly fluid cyanide compound - The technique does not produce cyanide compounds. Hydrogen sulfide (H₂S) is chemically distinct from cyanide compounds, though both act as cellular asphyxiants by different mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The 'Japanese Detergent Suicide Technique' produces hydrogen sulfide (H₂S) gas, which acts as a cellular poison by inhibiting cytochrome oxidase in the mitochondrial electron transport chain, leading to rapid asphyxiation and death.

questions.text: Forced diuresis with acidification or alkalinization of urine is a common method for the elimination of certain poisons or drugs from the body. The elimination of which of the following drugs is commonly enhanced by alkaline diuresis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Phenobarbitone

 

Explanation:

 

Alkaline diuresis is specifically effective for enhancing the elimination of phenobarbitone. When urine is alkalinized (pH > 7.5), weakly acidic drugs like barbiturates become more ionized, preventing their reabsorption in the renal tubules and enhancing their elimination. The forensic medicine text explicitly lists phenobarbitone among drugs eliminated by alkaline diuresis along with chlorpropamide, methotrexate, and salicylates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amphetamines - Amphetamines are basic compounds that become more ionized in acidic urine. Therefore, their elimination is enhanced by acid diuresis, not alkaline diuresis. The text specifically mentions amphetamines as drugs eliminated by acid diuresis.

 

Option C. Phencyclidine - Phencyclidine (PCP) is similarly eliminated through acid diuresis rather than alkaline diuresis. As a basic drug, its elimination is enhanced in acidic urine environments.

 

Option D. Theophylline - While theophylline can be eliminated through multiple-dose activated charcoal (as indicated by the "These People Drink Charcoal Quickly" mnemonic for drugs like theophylline, thallium, phenobarbital, dapsone, carbamazepine, quinine), it is not specifically mentioned as being effectively eliminated through alkaline diuresis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Alkaline diuresis enhances elimination of weak acids like phenobarbitone, while acid diuresis enhances elimination of weak bases like amphetamines, phencyclidine, and cocaine.

questions.text: Where are lipid rafts typically observed? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Plasma membrane

 

Explanation:


Lipid rafts are specialized microdomains within the plasma membrane that are enriched in cholesterol and sphingolipids. These membrane regions serve as organizing centers for the assembly of signaling molecules and influence membrane fluidity and protein trafficking. When these rafts become infiltrated with caveolin protein, they form flask-shaped membrane depressions called caveolae ("little caves").

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Ribosomes - Ribosomes are cellular structures composed of RNA and protein that function as sites of protein synthesis. They lack the lipid bilayer structure necessary for lipid raft formation.
  • Option b. Mitochondria - While mitochondria have an inner and outer membrane, lipid rafts are specifically located in the cell membrane (plasma membrane), not in mitochondrial membranes.
  • Option d. ER - The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is a membrane-bound organelle involved in protein synthesis and lipid metabolism. Though it contains membranes, lipid rafts are primarily identified and characterized in the plasma membrane.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Lipid rafts are cholesterol and sphingolipid-rich microdomains in the plasma membrane that can develop into caveolae and play important roles in cellular signaling, cholesterol regulation, and transcytosis.

questions.text: Which ion's concentration change has the most significant effect on the excitability of cells through RMP? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. K+

 

Explanation:


Potassium (K+) concentration changes have the most significant impact on cellular excitability. The resting membrane potential is primarily determined by K+ gradients across the membrane. In mild to moderate hyperkalemia, the decreased concentration gradient results in less K+ moving outward, leading to depolarization and increased excitability. Conversely, hypokalemia causes hyperpolarization, moving the membrane potential further from threshold and decreasing excitability.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option b. Na+ - While sodium is essential for action potential generation, changes in external Na+ concentration primarily affect the amplitude of action potentials rather than the resting membrane potential. Na+ has little effect on the baseline excitability of cells.
  • Option c. Cl- - Chloride primarily influences inhibitory post-synaptic potentials through influx causing hyperpolarization. Its concentration changes affect modulation of neuronal responses but don't have the most significant effect on baseline cellular excitability.
  • Option d. Ca+2 - Calcium functions as a membrane stabilizing agent. Hypocalcemia increases excitability by decreasing the depolarization threshold needed to initiate action potentials, while hypercalcemia decreases excitability. However, these effects are not as profound as potassium's direct influence on the resting potential.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Potassium concentration directly determines the resting membrane potential, establishing the baseline excitability state of neurons and muscle cells, making K+ the ion whose concentration changes most significantly affect cellular excitability.

choices.text: Nernst potential for Cl– is –90 mV

questions.text: Which statement is true about the Nernst equation? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Used to calculate equilibrium potential

 

Explanation:


The Nernst equation is fundamentally used to calculate the equilibrium potential for individual ions across a cell membrane. The equation expresses the relationship between the equilibrium potential (E) of an ion and its concentration gradient across the membrane. This mathematical tool determines the membrane potential at which the electrical gradient exactly balances the concentration gradient for a specific ion, resulting in no net movement of that ion.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option b. Calculated for non-ionic solutions - The Nernst equation specifically applies to ions and ionic solutions, not non-ionic solutions. It calculates the potential difference created by concentration differences of specific charged particles.
  • Option c. Nernst potential for Cl– is –90 mV - This is incorrect. The equilibrium potential for Cl- in mammalian spinal neurons is approximately -70 mV, not -90 mV. The value of -90 mV is actually the equilibrium potential for K+ ions.
  • Option d. All are correct - This cannot be true as options b and c contain incorrect information.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Nernst equation is a fundamental tool in cell physiology that calculates the equilibrium potential for a specific ion across a membrane, representing the electrical potential at which diffusional and electrical forces acting on that ion are in balance.

choices.text: Concentration of K+ is greater in ECF
Concentration of Cl– is greater in ICF
Total ions are more in ICF

questions.text: As a result of the Donnan-Gibbs effect, which of the following is true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Total ions are more in ICF

 

Explanation:


The Donnan-Gibbs effect describes the unequal distribution of ions across a semipermeable membrane when one ion (typically charged proteins) cannot cross the membrane. In cells, the non-diffusible ions are primarily the negatively charged proteins (Prot-) trapped inside. This creates an electrical imbalance that affects the distribution of all permeable ions, ultimately resulting in more total osmotically active particles (ions) inside the cell than outside. This ion imbalance contributes to the osmotic pressure that would make cells swell and potentially rupture if not counterbalanced by the Na, K ATPase pump.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Concentration of K+ is greater in ECF - This is false. K+ concentration is significantly higher in the intracellular fluid (approximately 140 mEq/L) compared to extracellular fluid (approximately 4.5 mEq/L). The Donnan effect actually contributes to this concentration difference.
  • Option b. Concentration of Cl– is greater in ICF - Cl- is higher in ECF than in ICF, it is not the primary consequence of the Donnan-Gibbs effect. The key result is the overall ionic imbalance with more total ions in ICF.
  • Option d. All are true - This cannot be correct since option a is false.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Donnan-Gibbs equilibrium results in an asymmetric distribution of ions across cell membranes with more total ions accumulating in the intracellular compartment due to the presence of non-diffusible, negatively charged proteins.

choices.text: It moves against the concentration gradient

questions.text: Which statement is true about facilitated diffusion? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. It requires a carrier

 

Explanation:

 

Facilitated diffusion is a form of passive transport that requires specific carrier proteins to move substances across the cell membrane. These carrier proteins bind molecules and then change their configuration, facilitating the movement of the bound substance across the membrane. This type of transport is characterized by several key properties: it requires specific carrier proteins, exhibits saturation kinetics, shows specificity for the transported substance, and can demonstrate competition between similar molecules for the same carrier.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. It is active - False. Facilitated diffusion is classified as passive transport, not active transport. It moves substances down their concentration or electrical gradient without requiring energy input.
  • Option c. It requires ATP - False. Unlike primary active transport, facilitated diffusion does not require ATP or other energy sources. The movement occurs due to the existing concentration gradient.
  • Option d. It moves against the concentration gradient - False. Facilitated diffusion only moves substances down their concentration gradient (from high to low concentration), never against it. Moving substances against their concentration gradient requires active transport mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Facilitated diffusion is a passive transport process requiring specific carrier proteins (such as GLUT for glucose) that enables the movement of substances down their concentration gradient across cell membranes at a faster rate than would occur by simple diffusion alone.

questions.text: Which ion primarily drives the depolarization phase of action potential in cardiac muscles? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Na+

 

Explanation:


The action potential in cardiac muscles is initiated by the rapid influx of sodium ions (Na+) during Phase 0, the phase of rapid depolarization. This sudden influx results from the opening of fast sodium channels, which causes a sharp rise in the membrane potential towards a positive value. This process is crucial for initiating the sequence of electrical events that lead to muscle contraction. Sodium's role is pivotal in setting the fast response of cardiac myocytes, which differentiates cardiac muscle action potential from those in other types of muscle cells.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. K+: While potassium ions (K+) play significant roles in the initial repolarization (Phase 1) and final repolarization (Phase 3) by exiting the cell, they do not initiate the action potential.
  • Option c. Ca+2: Calcium ions contribute mainly to the Plateau phase (Phase 2) of the cardiac action potential by entering the cell through slow voltage-gated channels, sustaining the depolarization longer than in other muscle cells, but they are not the primary trigger.
  • Option d. Cl: Chloride ions have minimal direct involvement in the generation or progression of cardiac action potentials.

 

Educational objective:


The initiation of the action potential in cardiac muscle cells is primarily driven by the influx of Na+ ions during the rapid depolarization phase, critical for the subsequent phases of the cardiac cycle.

questions.text: Which protein is responsible for connecting the Z-lines to the M-lines within a myofibril? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Titin

 

Explanation:

 

Titin is the largest known protein in the human body with a molecular mass of approximately 3,000,000 Da. It plays a critical structural role in the sarcomere by connecting the Z-lines to the M-lines, thereby providing essential scaffolding for the entire sarcomeric structure. Titin also contributes significantly to muscle elasticity through its folded domains that can unfold during initial stretching (providing low resistance) and then offer increasing resistance with further stretch to protect sarcomere integrity.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Kinin: Kinins are inflammatory mediators and not structural proteins of muscle fibers. They have no role in connecting sarcomeric components.
  • Option b. Desmin: While desmin is an important structural protein, it functions by adding structure to the Z-lines through binding them to the plasma membrane. It does not connect Z-lines to M-lines.
  • Option d. Actin: Actin forms the thin filaments of the sarcomere and does not serve as a connecting protein between Z-lines and M-lines. It interacts with myosin during muscle contraction but does not have a structural scaffolding role between these components.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Titin functions as a molecular spring providing both elasticity and structural integrity to the sarcomere by forming a continuous filament from Z-line to M-line, making it essential for proper muscle function and sarcomere stability.

choices.text: Covers the active site on actin

questions.text: Which attribute accurately describes myosin within muscle fibers? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Exhibits ATPase activity

 

Explanation:

 

Myosin forms the thick filaments in muscle and possesses ATPase activity in its globular head region. The myosin head contains both an actin-binding site and a catalytic site that hydrolyzes ATP. This ATPase activity is essential for the power stroke during muscle contraction, as ATP hydrolysis provides the energy needed for the conformational change in the myosin head that generates force.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Component of thin filaments: Myosin constitutes the thick filaments, not the thin filaments. The thin filaments are composed of actin, tropomyosin, and troponin.
  • Option b. Covers the active site on actin: This is the function of tropomyosin, not myosin. Tropomyosin covers the myosin-binding sites on actin during muscle relaxation, and is displaced when calcium binds to troponin C.
  • Option d. Calcium-binding protein: Calcium binding is the function of troponin C, not myosin. Troponin C contains specific binding sites for calcium that initiate the contractile process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myosin's ATPase activity is fundamental to muscle contraction as it hydrolyzes ATP to generate the energy needed for the power stroke, which creates movement by changing the angle of the myosin head while attached to actin.

questions.text: In which muscles are white fibers predominantly found? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Hand muscles

 

Explanation:


White fibers correspond to Type IIB/Fast Glycolytic muscle fibers. These fibers have high glycolytic capacity but low oxidative capacity. They are characterized by fast contraction speed, high myosin ATPase activity, and rapid fatigue. Hand muscles predominantly contain these white (Type IIB) fibers to facilitate precise, rapid movements required for fine motor skills.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Calf muscle: Calf muscles (particularly soleus) predominantly contain Type I and Type IIA fibers, which are red in color due to higher myoglobin content and greater capillary density. The soleus specifically is noted for containing Type IIA fibers (Fast Oxidative Glycolytic).
  • Option b. Back muscles: Back muscles primarily contain Type I (Slow Oxidative) fibers that appear red due to high myoglobin content. These muscles are responsible for maintaining posture and require sustained contractions rather than rapid, powerful ones.
  • Option c. Gluteal muscles: While gluteal muscles contain a mixture of fiber types, they don't predominantly feature white Type IIB fibers. They have a significant proportion of Type I and Type IIA fibers to support both postural maintenance and powerful movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type IIB/Fast Glycolytic (white) muscle fibers predominate in hand muscles and other muscles requiring rapid, precise movements with short bursts of activity, reflecting their high glycolytic capacity, fast contraction speed, and quick fatigue properties.

choices.text: Increased Fat content of the cells

questions.text: What is the definition of hypertrophy?  (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Increased in size of cells

 

Explanation:

 

Hypertrophy refers specifically to an increase in the size of existing cells without an increase in cell number. From Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, this is confirmed when discussing muscle adaptations: "Increased activity can lead to muscle cell hypertrophy, which allows for increase in contractile strength." The key characteristic of hypertrophy is the enlargement of individual cells, not their multiplication.

 

Other Options: 

 

  • Option a. Increased Fat content of the cells - This describes lipid accumulation within cells, which is a different cellular change unrelated to hypertrophy. Hypertrophy involves growth of functional cellular components, not fat storage.
  • Option c. Increase in number of cells  - This defines hyperplasia, not hypertrophy. Hyperplasia involves cell multiplication through division, whereas hypertrophy involves enlargement of existing cells.
  • Option d. None of the above - This is incorrect since option b correctly defines hypertrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypertrophy is the increase in cell size that enhances functional capacity without cell multiplication, as observed in skeletal muscle adaptation to increased workload.

questions.text: Baroreceptors are associated with which vessel? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Internal carotid artery

 

Explanation:


Baroreceptors are stretch receptors located in the walls of blood vessels that monitor blood pressure. The carotid sinus is a small dilation of the internal carotid artery just above the bifurcation of the common carotid into external and internal carotid branches. These baroreceptors are specifically located in the adventitial layer of the vessel wall within this dilation. They sense changes in arterial pressure and transmit this information via the carotid sinus nerve (branch of glossopharyngeal nerve) to the medulla.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option b. External carotid artery: Baroreceptors are not located in the external carotid artery. They are specifically found in the carotid sinus, which is a dilation at the beginning of the internal carotid artery.
  • Option c. Subclavian artery: No baroreceptors are documented in the subclavian artery. The main locations of baroreceptors are the carotid sinus and the aortic arch.
  • Option d. Brachiocephalic trunk: While this vessel branches off the aortic arch, it is not specifically identified as containing baroreceptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Baroreceptors are primarily located in two key areas: the carotid sinus (a dilation of the internal carotid artery) and the aortic arch. These pressure sensors are crucial for the short-term regulation of blood pressure via the baroreceptor reflex.

choices.text: Air in lung after normal expiration
Maximum air that can be expired after normal inspiration
Maximum air that can be expired after maximum inspiration
Maximum air in lung after end of maximal inspiration

questions.text: Which of the following best defines vital capacity? (NEET pg 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Maximum air that can be expired after maximum inspiration

 

Explanation:


Vital capacity (VC) is defined as the maximum amount of air that can be expired after a maximal inspiratory effort. It represents the sum of tidal volume (TV), inspiratory reserve volume (IRV), and expiratory reserve volume (ERV). In healthy adults, VC typically measures around 3.5 L, though this varies based on factors like gender, age, and body size.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Air in lung after normal expiration This definition describes Functional Residual Capacity (FRC), which equals ERV + RV (approximately 2.5 L). FRC represents the volume remaining in the lungs after a normal expiration.
  • Option b. Maximum air that can be expired after normal inspiration This describes Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) only, which is approximately 1 L. ERV is just one component of vital capacity.
  • Option d. Maximum air in lung after end of maximal inspiration This defines Total Lung Capacity (TLC), which includes VC plus the residual volume (RV). TLC = IRV + TV + ERV + RV (approximately 5 L).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vital capacity is the maximum volume of air that can be expelled from the lungs after a maximum inspiration, representing the sum of IRV, TV, and ERV, and is a key measurement in pulmonary function testing.

choices.text: Decreases affinity of O2 by increase in PCO2
Left shift of Hb-O2 dissociation curve
It is due to increased H+

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Bohr effect is NOT true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Left shift of Hb-O2 dissociation curve

 

Explanation:

 

The Bohr effect is characterized by a right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, which decreases the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen when blood pH decreases or PCO2 increases. This physiological phenomenon facilitates oxygen unloading in metabolically active tissues where CO2 production is high and pH is lower. The "BohR" effect (with the helpful mnemonic "R" for Right shift) occurs in peripheral tissues where oxygen release is needed.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Decreases affinity of O2 by increase in PCO2 - This is a true statement. When PCO2 increases, it forms carbonic acid, lowering pH and causing hemoglobin to release oxygen more readily (decreased affinity), which is the Bohr effect.
  • Option c. It is due to increased H+ - This is correct. The Bohr effect occurs because deoxygenated hemoglobin binds H+ more actively than oxygenated hemoglobin. The increased H+ concentration (lower pH) is the primary mechanism behind the Bohr effect.
  • Option d. All are true - Since option b is incorrect, not all statements are true.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bohr effect represents a physiological adaptation that facilitates oxygen unloading in tissues by causing a right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve in response to increased PCO2 and decreased pH, while the opposite effect (left shift) occurs in the lungs, known as the Haldane effect.

choices.text: Dissociation of O2 on addition of CO2

questions.text: What does the Haldane effect describe? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Dissociation of CO2 on oxygenation

 

Explanation:


The Haldane effect describes the increased capacity of oxygenated hemoglobin to release CO2 compared to deoxygenated hemoglobin. When hemoglobin binds oxygen in the lungs, it simultaneously reduces its affinity for CO2, facilitating CO2 release from the blood into the alveoli. This physiological mechanism enhances CO2 elimination in pulmonary circulation, complementing the Bohr effect which occurs in peripheral tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Effect of 2,3–BPG - This is incorrect. 2,3-BPG (2,3-diphosphoglycerate) binds to deoxyhemoglobin and decreases hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, shifting the oxygen dissociation curve to the right. While important for oxygen transport, this is distinct from the Haldane effect.
  • Option c. Dissociation of O2 on addition of CO2 - This actually describes the Bohr effect, not the Haldane effect. The Bohr effect is the opposite process where increased CO2 leads to reduced oxygen affinity and enhanced O2 release from hemoglobin.
  • Option d. Chloride shift - This refers to the movement of chloride ions into red blood cells in exchange for bicarbonate ions during CO2 transport. While part of the CO2 transport system, it is not the Haldane effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Haldane effect and Bohr effect are complementary physiological mechanisms: Haldane effect facilitates CO2 unloading in the lungs when hemoglobin becomes oxygenated (left shift of the curve), while the Bohr effect facilitates O2 unloading in tissues when CO2 levels increase (right shift of the curve).

questions.text: Which type of neurons is responsible for transmitting dull visceral pain? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. C fibers

 

Explanation:

 

C fibers are specifically responsible for transmitting dull visceral pain. These unmyelinated fibers create what's known as "slow" or "protopathic" pain, which is characterized as deep, visceral, aching, and diffuse. This type of pain is poorly localized and often shows radiation and referral to other body areas. C fibers use Substance P as their primary neurotransmitter alongside glutamate, and they conduct impulses at very slow rates (0.5-2 m/s).

 

Other Options:
