  • Option 1: A gamma - These fibers innervate intrafusal muscle fibers within muscle spindles and are involved in motor function, not sensory pain transmission.
  • Option 2: A alpha - These large myelinated fibers are primarily involved in motor function and proprioception, not pain transmission.
  • Option 4: B fibers - These myelinated fibers transmit touch, pressure, and vibration sensations rather than dull visceral pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

C fibers are the slow-conducting unmyelinated nociceptive neurons responsible for the dull, diffuse, poorly localized pain sensations from visceral structures, producing what's termed "second pain" after injury.

questions.text: Which gas is primarily used to measure the diffusing capacity of the lungs? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. C) CO

 

Explanation:

 

Carbon monoxide (CO) is the primary gas used to measure the diffusing capacity of the lungs, known as DLCO (Diffusion capacity of Lung for CO). CO is ideal for this measurement because it has approximately 210 times greater affinity for hemoglobin than oxygen. This extremely high affinity ensures that the rate-limiting step in CO uptake is the diffusion across the alveolar-capillary membrane, not blood flow or binding to hemoglobin, making it an excellent gas for assessing membrane diffusion properties.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. O2 - Oxygen is not used for measuring diffusing capacity because its uptake is affected by both diffusion and perfusion. Additionally, as oxygen binds to hemoglobin, the pressure gradient decreases, making measurements less reliable.
  • Option B. CO2 - Carbon dioxide's transfer is much faster than oxygen (20 times more diffusible) and is primarily limited by ventilation and blood flow rather than membrane properties, making it unsuitable for diffusion capacity measurements.
  • Option D. N2O - Nitrous oxide is used in some pulmonary function tests but is not used for measuring diffusing capacity. It is primarily used in ventilation/perfusion assessments rather than membrane diffusion properties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The DLCO test uses carbon monoxide because its extremely high affinity for hemoglobin creates a steep concentration gradient that remains constant during the test, making the diffusion process across the alveolar-capillary membrane the primary limitation to gas transfer.

questions.text: Where are Nissl's granules located within a nerve cell? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Body

 

Explanation:


Nissl's granules are basophilic granular bodies found within the cell body (soma) of neurons. They represent rough endoplasmic reticulum with associated ribosomes that are responsible for protein synthesis in the neuron. These granules are abundant in the cell body where metabolic activity is highest, supporting the neuron's structural and functional needs.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Axon hillock: This is the transitional zone between the cell body and axon where action potentials are initiated. It lacks Nissl substance.
  • Option b. Axons: Axons are specialized for signal conduction, not protein synthesis. They don't contain Nissl granules as this would interfere with their conduction function.
  • Option c. Node of Ranvier: These are gaps in the myelin sheath of myelinated axons that allow for saltatory conduction. They also lack Nissl substance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nissl granules (rough endoplasmic reticulum with ribosomes) are exclusively found in the neuronal cell body, reflecting the compartmentalization of protein synthesis within neurons, with the soma being the primary site for manufacturing cellular components.

questions.text: Where are stereocilia located? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Hair cells

 

Explanation:

 

Stereocilia are specialized microvilli-like projections found on the apical surface of hair cells in the inner ear. These projections (30-150 per cell) have cores composed of parallel filaments of actin. Stereocilia are mechanosensitive structures essential for transduction of sound and balance information in the cochlea and vestibular apparatus.

Visual Support: In the inner ear, hair cells have one large kinocilium (true cilium) and multiple stereocilia arranged in a distinctive pattern where they increase progressively in height toward the kinocilium. When these stereocilia are deflected by fluid movement, tip links connecting adjacent stereocilia open mechanically-sensitive cation channels, initiating sensory transduction.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Taste buds - Taste receptor cells have microvilli (not stereocilia) that project into the taste pore where they contact tastants dissolved in saliva.
  • Option c. Retina - The retina contains photoreceptors (rods and cones) with specialized outer segments containing discs of membrane with photopigments, but these are not stereocilia.
  • Option d. Nose - Olfactory sensory neurons possess cilia (not stereocilia) that extend into the mucus layer where they bind odorant molecules.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stereocilia are unique actin-rich projections found exclusively on hair cells of the inner ear that function as mechanosensitive structures essential for hearing and vestibular function.

questions.text: How does the Bohr effect operate in myoglobin compared to hemoglobin? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. No Bohr effect

 

Explanation:


The Bohr effect refers to the decreased oxygen affinity of hemoglobin when pH falls or PCO₂ rises. This effect occurs because deoxygenated hemoglobin binds H⁺ more actively than oxygenated hemoglobin. The Bohr effect is dependent on hemoglobin's quaternary structure and cooperative binding between its four subunits.

 

Myoglobin, in contrast, has fundamentally different structural and functional properties:

 

  • Contains only one heme group versus hemoglobin's four
  • Exhibits no cooperative binding (rectangular hyperbola curve versus sigmoid)
  • Has higher oxygen affinity than hemoglobin (leftward shifted curve)
  • Lacks the quaternary structure needed for the Bohr effect

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Increased - Incorrect because myoglobin cannot have an increased Bohr effect when it lacks the structural basis for this effect entirely.
  • Option b. Decreased - Incorrect because "decreased" would suggest myoglobin still exhibits some Bohr effect, just to a lesser degree than hemoglobin.
  • Option c. Same - Incorrect because myoglobin's structure (single oxygen-binding site) fundamentally prevents it from exhibiting the same pH-dependent oxygen affinity changes seen in hemoglobin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bohr effect requires a quaternary protein structure with cooperative binding properties as found in hemoglobin; myoglobin's monomeric structure with a single oxygen-binding site prevents it from exhibiting this physiologically important effect.

questions.text: Which is the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the nervous system? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Gamma-amino butyric acid (GABA)

 

Explanation:


GABA is the major inhibitory mediator in the brain, mediating both presynaptic and postsynaptic inhibition. It's formed by decarboxylation of glutamate by the enzyme glutamate decarboxylase (GAD) in nerve endings throughout the brain. GABA mediates inhibition by increasing Cl⁻ conductance through GABAA receptors, producing hyperpolarization, or by activating GABAB receptors which increase K⁺ conductance and inhibit Ca²⁺ influx.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Glutamate - Glutamate is the main excitatory neurotransmitter in the brain and spinal cord, responsible for approximately 75% of the excitatory transmission in the CNS. It produces excitation through AMPA, kainate, and NMDA receptors.
  • Option b. Aspartate - While aspartate can function as a neurotransmitter, it is not a major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system.
  • Option d. Taurine - Taurine is not a major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the nervous system.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

GABA is the principal inhibitory neurotransmitter in the CNS, acting through ionotropic GABAA receptors (which increase Cl⁻ conductance) and metabotropic GABAB receptors (which increase K⁺ conductance and inhibit Ca²⁺ channels).

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is primarily known for its facilitatory presynaptic effects in CNS? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Glutamate

 

Explanation:


Glutamate can function as a facilitatory presynaptic neurotransmitter in the central nervous system. When released, glutamate can act on presynaptic receptors to enhance neurotransmitter release. Presynaptic facilitation occurs when the action potential is prolonged and calcium channels remain open for a longer period, resulting in increased neurotransmitter release. In glutamatergic pathways, this facilitation can enhance synaptic transmission.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. GABA - GABA primarily functions as an inhibitory neurotransmitter. At presynaptic terminals, GABA typically causes inhibition rather than facilitation. GABA acting on GABAB receptors increases K+ conductance and inhibits Ca2+ influx, reducing neurotransmitter release.
  • Option b. Glycine - Glycine is an inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brainstem and spinal cord. Like GABA, glycine acts by increasing Cl- conductance and generally has inhibitory presynaptic effects rather than facilitatory ones.
  • Option d. Aspartate - While aspartate functions as an excitatory neurotransmitter in some pathways (not primary or most common), it has not been established as having significant facilitatory presynaptic effects in comparison to glutamate.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Presynaptic facilitation enhances neurotransmitter release through prolongation of action potentials and increased calcium influx, with glutamate playing a key role in this process within excitatory pathways of the central nervous system.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Papez circuit? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Posterior thalamic nuclei

 

Explanation:


The Papez circuit is a neural pathway within the limbic system that plays a crucial role in memory formation and emotional processing. This circuit forms a closed loop that includes the hippocampus, fornix, mammillary bodies, mammillothalamic tract, anterior thalamic nuclei, cingulate gyrus, and back to the hippocampus via the entorhinal cortex. The posterior thalamic nuclei are not components of this circuit - instead, it's the anterior thalamic nuclei that participate in the Papez pathway.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Hippocampus - This is a key component of the Papez circuit. The hippocampus is essential for memory formation and connects to the mammillary bodies via the fornix, forming a critical segment of the circuit.
  • Option b. Mammillary bodies - These are definite components of the Papez circuit. Located in the hypothalamus, the mammillary bodies receive input from the hippocampus and project to the anterior thalamic nuclei via the mammillothalamic tract.
  • Option c. Cingulate gyrus - This is an integral component of the Papez circuit. The cingulate gyrus receives projections from the anterior thalamic nuclei and connects back to the hippocampus, completing the circuit.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Papez circuit is a fundamental limbic pathway for emotional processing and memory formation that interconnects the hippocampus, mammillary bodies, and cingulate gyrus, but excludes the posterior thalamic nuclei.

questions.text: What is the renal threshold for serum glucose level? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. 200 mg/dL

 

Explanation:


The renal threshold for glucose is the plasma level at which glucose first appears in the urine in more than normal minute amounts. This threshold is approximately 200 mg/dL in arterial plasma, corresponding to about 180 mg/dL in venous blood. At this concentration, the glucose filtered through the glomeruli begins to exceed the maximum tubular reabsorptive capacity.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option 100 mg/dL: This value is too low. Normal plasma glucose ranges around 80-100 mg/dL, and at this level, all filtered glucose is completely reabsorbed by the proximal tubule.
  • Option 300 mg/dL: This represents the theoretical threshold calculated by dividing the transport maximum (TmG) by GFR (375 mg/min ÷ 125 mL/min). However, due to nephron heterogeneity (renal splay), the actual threshold is lower.
  • Option 400 mg/dL: This value greatly exceeds both the actual and theoretical renal thresholds for glucose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The renal threshold for glucose (200 mg/dL) is lower than the theoretical value (300 mg/dL) due to renal splay - the heterogeneity of nephrons in terms of their transport maximum and filtration rates.

questions.text: Which touch receptors are primarily involved in two-point discrimination?  (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Meissner’s corpuscle

 

Explanation

 

Meissner's corpuscles are the primary receptors involved in two-point discrimination. These receptors mediate fine touch and two-point discrimination while also sensing low frequency vibration. They provide excellent spatial discrimination with minimum distinguishable distances of 1-3 mm on fingertips and lips. Meissner corpuscles are the most abundant touch receptors in glabrous (non-hairy) skin, particularly in areas where tactile discrimination is most critical.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Merkel's disc - While Merkel cells contribute to discrimination of edges and points, they primarily function to detect sustained pressure. They're important for sensing texture and form but are not the primary receptors for two-point discrimination.
  • Option B. Ruffini's end organ - Ruffini endings are slowly adapting mechanoreceptors that sense stretch and sustained pressure. These receptors respond to tissue deformation and are not specialized for the fine spatial discrimination required for two-point testing.
  • Option C. Pacinian corpuscle - Pacinian corpuscles detect high frequency vibration and deep pressure. Located deeper in the dermis and having larger receptive fields, they're unsuitable for fine spatial discrimination tasks like two-point discrimination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meissner's corpuscles, concentrated in the fingertips and other areas requiring fine discrimination, are specialized for detecting separate points in close proximity, making them the primary receptors responsible for two-point discrimination.

questions.text: What type of transporter is found in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Na+ –2Cl– -K+ cotransporter

 

Explanation:


In the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, the Na+ K+ 2Cl- transporter (NKC or NKCC) is the primary transport mechanism located on the apical side of the cells. This cotransporter simultaneously moves 1 Na+, 1 K+, and 2 Cl- ions from the tubular lumen into the cell. This transport system is critically important for the creation of the medullary concentration gradient and is the site of action for loop diuretics.

The thick ascending limb contains ROMK channels on the apical side that secrete K+ back into the lumen, and Na+ K+ ATPase channels and Cl- channels (ClC-Kb) on the basal side that move ions into the bloodstream. The Cl- channels require Barttin protein for activation.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Na+ Cl+ cotransporter - This transporter (NCC) is found in the distal convoluted tubule, not the thick ascending limb. Thiazide diuretics block this transporter, and mutations in this transporter result in Gitelman syndrome.
  • Option c. ENaC channel - This is the epithelial sodium channel found in the collecting duct and distal tubule (principal cells), not the thick ascending limb. It is regulated by aldosterone and blocked by amiloride.
  • Option d. Na+ -amino acid cotransporter - This type of cotransporter is found in the proximal convoluted tubule where amino acid reabsorption occurs, not in the thick ascending limb.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thick ascending limb's unique Na+ K+ 2Cl- cotransporter is key for the kidney's concentrating ability and creates the medullary osmotic gradient necessary for water reabsorption in the collecting ducts.

choices.text: Descending limb of loop of Henle
Ascending limb of loop of Henle

questions.text: Which segment of the nephron is known as the diluting segment? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Ascending limb of loop of Henle

 

Explanation:


The ascending limb of the loop of Henle functions as the "diluting segment" because it actively reduces the concentration of the tubular fluid. When fluid reaches the top of the ascending limb, it becomes hypotonic to plasma. This occurs because the ascending limb is relatively impermeable to water while it actively transports Na+, K+, and Cl- out of the tubular lumen via the Na-K-2Cl cotransporter, creating hypotonic fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Proximal convoluted tubule - The PCT reabsorbs 60-70% of filtered water along with solutes, maintaining isotonicity throughout this segment. The tubular fluid remains essentially iso-osmotic until the end of the proximal tubule.
  • Option b. Distal convoluted tubule - While the DCT continues the dilution process, it is not specifically designated as "the diluting segment" in renal physiology.
  • Option c. Descending limb of loop of Henle - The descending limb "drinks the water" and is highly permeable to water via aquaporin-1. It concentrates the filtrate rather than diluting it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ascending limb of the loop of Henle creates hypotonic fluid by actively extruding solutes (Na+, K+, 2Cl-) while remaining impermeable to water, earning its designation as the "diluting segment" of the nephron.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the function of secretin? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Delays gastric emptying

 

Explanation:


Secretin is a hormone produced by S cells in the duodenum in response to acid. Secretin works in conjunction with CCK-PZ, enhancing its action through a positive correlation. Since CCK-PZ inhibits gastric emptying by acting on the pylorus, secretin indirectly delays gastric emptying through this enhancement of CCK-PZ action.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Antagonizes the action of CCK - This is incorrect because secretin promotes rather than antagonizes CCK action. The relationship between secretin and CCK-PZ shows enhancement, not antagonism.
  • Option B. Stimulates gastrin secretion - This is incorrect because secretin inhibits gastrin secretion, which leads to reduced acid secretion. Secretin and gastrin have an inverse relationship in the regulation of gastric acid.
  • Option D. All of the above - Since options A and B are incorrect, "All of the above" cannot be correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secretin delays gastric emptying by enhancing the action of CCK-PZ, which inhibits the pyloric sphincter. Additionally, secretin stimulates bicarbonate-rich pancreatic secretions and inhibits gastrin secretion, contributing to its role in coordinating digestive processes.

choices.text: Increased by decreased renal blood flow

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR)? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Increased in hypoproteinemia

 

Explanation:


In hypoproteinemia, the concentration of plasma proteins, particularly albumin, is decreased. This reduction leads to a decrease in plasma oncotic pressure (πGC), which normally opposes filtration across the glomerular membrane. The glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is determined by the equation GFR = Kf × NFP, where NFP represents net filtration pressure. When oncotic pressure decreases, the net filtration pressure increases, resulting in greater filtration and thus higher GFR. This relationship is a direct application of Starling forces in the glomerular capillaries.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Increased by afferent arteriole constriction - This is incorrect because afferent arteriole constriction reduces blood flow to the glomerulus, decreasing glomerular hydrostatic pressure. Afferent arteriole constriction causes marked decrease in both renal plasma flow (RPF) and GFR.
  • Option b. Increased by decreased renal blood flow - This is incorrect because GFR is directly dependent on renal blood flow. When renal blood flow decreases, less plasma is available for filtration, resulting in decreased GFR. While GFR varies less than RPF, it still follows the same directional change.
  • Option c. Increased in hypotension - This is incorrect because hypotension (low blood pressure) reduces the hydrostatic pressure in the glomerular capillaries (PGC). When mean systemic arterial pressure drops below the autoregulatory range, GFR drops sharply.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GFR increases in hypoproteinemia because the reduction in plasma protein concentration decreases the oncotic pressure opposing filtration, thereby increasing the net filtration pressure across the glomerular membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following locations contains the GLUT-1 glucose transporter? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Placenta

 

Explanation:


GLUT-1 is a glucose transporter protein that facilitates the transport of glucose across cell membranes via facilitated diffusion. This transporter is constitutively expressed and functions independently of insulin. GLUT-1 is highly expressed in the placenta where it plays a critical role in transferring glucose from maternal to fetal circulation, ensuring the developing fetus receives adequate glucose supply throughout pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Skeletal muscle: Skeletal muscle primarily expresses GLUT-4, not GLUT-1. GLUT-4 is an insulin-responsive glucose transporter that translocates from intracellular vesicles to the cell membrane in response to insulin.
  • Option b. Adipose tissue: Similar to skeletal muscle, adipose tissue predominantly expresses GLUT-4, which mediates insulin-stimulated glucose uptake in fat cells.
  • Option c. Jejunum: The jejunum primarily utilizes SGLT (sodium-glucose linked transporter) for glucose absorption across the brush border membrane and GLUT-2 for basolateral transport, not GLUT-1.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

GLUT-1 is a constitutively active glucose transporter that facilitates the passive transport of glucose across plasma membranes in tissues requiring constant glucose supply regardless of insulin levels, with particularly high expression in the placenta, erythrocytes, and blood-brain barrier.

questions.text: Which glucose transporter is primarily affected in diabetes mellitus? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. GLUT-4

 

Explanation:


GLUT-4 is the insulin-dependent glucose transporter predominantly found in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue. In normal physiology, insulin stimulates the translocation of GLUT-4 containing vesicles from intracellular compartments to the plasma membrane, facilitating glucose uptake. In diabetes mellitus, insulin resistance or deficiency disrupts this translocation process, significantly reducing glucose uptake in insulin-sensitive tissues, which contributes to hyperglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. GLUT-2: This bidirectional, low-affinity glucose transporter is primarily found in pancreatic β-cells, liver, intestine, and kidneys. While GLUT-2 function in β-cells is important for glucose sensing, it's not the primary transporter affected in the pathophysiology of diabetes.
  • Option b. GLUT-5: This transporter primarily facilitates fructose transport rather than glucose and is mainly expressed in the small intestine. It plays a minimal role in diabetes pathophysiology.
  • Option d. SGLT-2: This sodium-glucose cotransporter is located in the proximal tubule of the kidney and mediates glucose reabsorption. While SGLT-2 inhibitors are used in diabetes treatment, the transporter itself is not primarily dysfunctional in diabetes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Diabetes mellitus fundamentally affects insulin-mediated glucose disposal, with GLUT-4 dysfunction representing the critical link between insulin resistance and hyperglycemia as its translocation from intracellular vesicles to the plasma membrane is impaired, preventing efficient glucose uptake in muscle and fat tissues.

questions.text: What does the Myenteric plexus in the gastrointestinal tract primarily control? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. GI motility

 

Explanation:


The Myenteric plexus (also known as Auerbach's plexus) is one of two major nerve plexuses in the enteric nervous system. It is located between the longitudinal and circular muscle layers of the gastrointestinal tract. This anatomical position allows it to directly influence the surrounding muscle layers, coordinating their contractions to produce peristalsis and other motility patterns essential for propelling food through the digestive tract.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. GI secretions - This is incorrect because secretion is primarily controlled by the Submucosal plexus (Meissner's plexus), not the Myenteric plexus.
  • Option b. Local blood flow - This is not the primary function of the Myenteric plexus.
  • Option d. All of the above - This is incorrect since the Myenteric plexus primarily controls motility, not all the listed functions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Myenteric plexus (Auerbach's plexus) is specialized for controlling GI tract motility, while the Submucosal plexus (Meissner's plexus) primarily regulates secretory functions.

questions.text: What is the primary function of ghrelin? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Increase appetite

 

Explanation:


Ghrelin functions primarily as an appetite stimulant. It is often referred to as the "hunger hormone" because it signals the brain to increase food intake. Ghrelin levels typically rise before meals and fall after eating, playing a key role in meal initiation. This hormone is produced predominantly by specialized cells in the stomach lining.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Stimulate water absorption - Ghrelin is not involved in water absorption in the gastrointestinal tract. Water absorption is primarily regulated by other mechanisms including osmotic gradients and hormones like aldosterone.
  • Option c. Regulation of temperature - Ghrelin does not play a significant role in thermoregulation. Body temperature is primarily regulated by the hypothalamus and various other hormones.
  • Option d. Stimulate lipogenesis - While ghrelin may have some metabolic effects, stimulating lipogenesis is not its primary function. Hormones like insulin play a much more significant role in promoting fat storage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ghrelin is a peptide hormone that serves as a physiological signal for hunger, working in opposition to satiety hormones like Peptide YY to regulate energy balance and food intake.

questions.text: Through which second messenger system does atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) exert its effects? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. cGMP

 

Explanation:

 

Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) exerts its effects through the G+ protein coupled receptor system which specifically activates cGMP as its second messenger. When ANP binds to its receptor, it activates guanylyl cyclase, leading to increased intracellular cGMP levels. This cGMP then mediates ANP's physiological effects, which include natriuresis, diuresis, and vasodilation.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. cAMP - This is incorrect because cAMP is associated with Gs and Gi protein coupled receptors. Hormones that work via cAMP include ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH, CRH, PTH, MSH, ADH (V2), glucagon, and calcitonin, but not ANP.
  • Option c. JAK-STAT kinase - This pathway is utilized by different hormones. Growth hormone, prolactin (which are called "twin hormones"), and leptin utilize the JAK-STAT pathway, not ANP.
  • Option d. Tyrosine kinase - This signaling pathway is used by insulin and growth factors (IGF, PDGF, NGF, FGF), not by ANP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ANP utilizes the G+ protein-coupled receptor pathway, which activates guanylyl cyclase to increase intracellular cGMP as its second messenger system.

questions.text: Which hormone acts through the IP3–DAG second messenger pathway? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Oxytocin

 

Explanation:


Oxytocin exerts its effects through the IP3-DAG second messenger pathway. When oxytocin binds to its specific G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs), it activates the Gq protein. The activated Gq stimulates phospholipase C, which cleaves PIP2 into inositol trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG). These second messengers then mediate oxytocin's physiological effects on target tissues, including uterine contraction and milk ejection.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. LH - Luteinizing hormone (LH) works through the Gs protein coupled receptor which activates adenylyl cyclase to increase intracellular cAMP levels, not IP3-DAG. LH belongs to the group of hormones that use the cAMP pathway.
  • Option b. FSH - Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), like LH, utilizes the Gs protein pathway leading to increased cAMP production. FSH does not signal through the IP3-DAG pathway.
  • Option c. ADH - While antidiuretic hormone (vasopressin) can act through the IP3-DAG pathway via its V1 receptors, its main physiological effects occur through V2 receptors that signal via cAMP. The V2 receptor of ADH is specifically associated with the Gs-cAMP pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxytocin signals primarily through Gq-protein coupled receptors that activate the IP3-DAG second messenger pathway to mediate its effects on smooth muscle contraction.

questions.text: All are true regarding intracellular receptors except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Fastest acting receptors

 

Explanation:


Intracellular receptors operate through a relatively slow mechanism that involves hormone entry into the cell, binding to cytoplasmic or nuclear receptors, translocation to the nucleus (if initially in cytoplasm), binding to DNA, and ultimately altering gene transcription and protein synthesis. This process typically takes hours to produce physiological effects, making intracellular receptors among the slowest, not fastest, signaling pathways in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Act by regulating gene expression: This is a true characteristic of intracellular receptors. Once activated by their ligands, intracellular receptors bind to specific DNA sequences (hormone response elements) and regulate transcription of target genes.
  • Option c. Glucocorticoid receptors: This is a correct example of intracellular receptors. Glucocorticoid receptors reside in the cytoplasm and, upon binding with their steroid hormone ligands, translocate to the nucleus to modulate gene expression.
  • Option d. DNA contains hormone responsive elements: This is accurate. Hormone responsive elements (HREs) are specific DNA sequences that serve as binding sites for hormone-receptor complexes, allowing for targeted gene regulation by various hormones.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Intracellular receptors function primarily through genomic mechanisms by regulating gene transcription, a process that requires hours to manifest physiological effects, in contrast to membrane-bound receptors which can initiate cellular responses within seconds through non-genomic pathways.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a second messenger? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Protein kinase

 

Explanation:


Second messengers are small, non-protein molecules that rapidly increase in concentration in response to a primary messenger (hormone, neurotransmitter) binding to its receptor. Protein kinases are enzymes that phosphorylate target proteins in response to second messenger activation, rather than being second messengers themselves. Protein kinases serve as downstream effectors in signaling pathways, activated by true second messengers like cAMP or calcium to phosphorylate specific substrate proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. cAMP: Cyclic AMP is a classic second messenger produced when certain hormones activate adenylyl cyclase. It triggers cellular responses by activating protein kinase A, which then phosphorylates various intracellular targets.
  • Option b. NO: Nitric oxide functions as a second messenger in various physiological processes. When produced, it activates soluble guanylyl cyclase to generate cGMP, triggering downstream signaling events in vascular smooth muscle relaxation and other processes.
  • Option c. CO: Carbon monoxide, like NO, acts as a gaseous second messenger in certain biological systems. It can activate guanylyl cyclase, influence ion channels, and modify various cellular functions through similar mechanisms as nitric oxide.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Second messengers are small intracellular molecules that rapidly change in concentration following receptor activation to propagate and amplify signals, while protein kinases are enzymatic effectors that respond to second messengers by phosphorylating downstream targets to execute the cellular response.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true about protein kinase? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. All of the above

 

Explanation:


Protein kinases are regulatory enzymes that add phosphate groups to substrate proteins, modifying their function. They possess all the characteristics listed in the options. Protein kinases can phosphorylate threonine residues (along with serine and tyrosine residues) depending on the specific kinase family. Many are involved in the IP3-DAG signaling pathway, particularly protein kinase C (PKC) which is directly activated by DAG. Additionally, several protein kinases are activated by calcium, including the calcium-calmodulin-dependent protein kinases (CaMKs).

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Phosphorylates threonine residue: This statement alone is correct but incomplete. Protein kinases can indeed phosphorylate threonine residues, but this is just one of their many characteristics.
  • Option b. Involved in IP3–DAG mechanism: This statement is also correct but incomplete. Protein kinase C is specifically activated as part of the IP3-DAG signaling pathway.
  • Option c. Activated by Ca2+: This statement is correct but incomplete. Several protein kinases, particularly the CaMK family, are activated by calcium, often through the calcium-binding protein calmodulin.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Protein kinases serve as critical effectors in cellular signaling pathways by phosphorylating substrate proteins at specific amino acid residues (serine, threonine, or tyrosine), and their activity can be regulated through multiple mechanisms including second messengers such as DAG and calcium.

questions.text: Which enzyme catalyzes the conversion of a compound into IP3 and DAG? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Phospholipase C

 

Explanation:

 

Phospholipase C (PLC) is the enzyme that catalyzes the hydrolysis of phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2) in the cell membrane to generate two important second messengers: inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG). This reaction occurs when a ligand binds to a receptor (either G-protein coupled or tyrosine kinase receptor) that activates PLC. Subsequently, IP3 diffuses to the endoplasmic reticulum where it triggers calcium release, while DAG remains in the membrane to activate protein kinase C.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Adenylyl cyclase: This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of ATP to cyclic AMP (cAMP), not IP3 and DAG. It's activated by stimulatory G-proteins (Gs) after receptor binding and generates cAMP as a second messenger.
  • Option b. Guanylyl cyclase: This enzyme catalyzes the formation of cyclic GMP (cGMP) from GTP. It exists in both membrane-bound and soluble forms, with the latter activated by nitric oxide. It does not produce IP3 or DAG.
  • Option d. Phospholipase A: This enzyme cleaves fatty acids from the sn-2 position of membrane phospholipids, generating arachidonic acid and lysophospholipids. It's involved in the production of eicosanoids but not IP3 or DAG.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The phosphoinositide signaling pathway involves phospholipase C-mediated hydrolysis of PIP2 to generate two distinct second messengers (IP3 and DAG) that work in tandem to increase intracellular calcium and activate protein kinase C, coordinating comprehensive cellular responses.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about thyroxine is NOT true? (NEET PG  2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Decrease rate of respiration

 

Explanation:


Thyroxine (T4) is a major thyroid hormone that increases the metabolic rate of tissues. T4 has a calorigenic effect that increases heat production, oxygen consumption, and basal metabolic rate (BMR). With increased metabolism and oxygen demand, the respiratory rate would naturally increase rather than decrease to supply the additional oxygen needed, making option C incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Increase BMR - This is a true statement. Thyroid hormones have a calorigenic effect that increases heat production and basal metabolic rate. This is one of the primary physiological effects of thyroid hormones.
  • Option b. Increase oxygen consumption - This is a true statement. Thyroid hormones directly increase oxygen consumption in most tissues of the body. This increased oxygen utilization supports the elevated metabolic processes.
  • Option d. Causes lipolysis - This is a true statement. Thyroid hormones promote lipolysis, leading to decreased fat stores and increased utilization of cholesterol and triglycerides. This fat mobilization provides energy substrates for the increased metabolic activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) are catabolic hormones that increase metabolic rate, oxygen consumption, and energy utilization throughout the body, leading to increased (not decreased) respiratory rate to meet elevated oxygen demands.

questions.text: In which phase of the sexual cycle does premature ejaculation occur? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Orgasmic phase

 

Explanation:


Premature ejaculation occurs during the orgasmic phase of the sexual response cycle. This phase is characterized by reflexive pelvic muscle contractions and is the shortest of all the phases. Premature ejaculation refers to the occurrence of ejaculation earlier than desired, either before or shortly after sexual penetration, and it can result in significant distress. It happens specifically during the orgasmic phase because this is the phase in which ejaculation is physiologically triggered. The rapid arrival at orgasm, without adequate time spent in the earlier phases (excitement and plateau), is what defines premature ejaculation.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Excitement phase: This initial phase involves increased blood flow to genital tissues, erection of the penis, and initial secretion of lubricating fluids. Ejaculation does not occur during this early preparatory phase.
  • Option B. Plateau phase: This represents the period of heightened sexual tension before orgasm, with continued vasocongestion and muscle tension building. Ejaculation has not yet occurred at this stage.
  • Option D. Resolution phase: This phase follows orgasm and is characterized by a return to the non-aroused state, with detumescence and relaxation. Ejaculation has already occurred before entering this phase.

 

Educational objective:


Premature ejaculation is defined as ejaculation that occurs earlier than desired during the orgasmic phase, before or shortly after penetration, and with minimal stimulation.

questions.text: How can total body fat be estimated accurately? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Hydrostatic Weighing

 

Explanation:


Hydrostatic weighing is considered the gold standard method for estimating total body fat. This technique measures body density by weighing a person both on land and while completely submerged in water. Since fat tissue is less dense than lean tissue, the overall body density can be used to calculate the percentage of body fat accurately. This method follows similar principles to those used in fluid volume estimation through displacement measurements.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Waist-Hip ratio - This measurement estimates fat distribution pattern (central versus peripheral) rather than total body fat percentage. It indicates risk for certain diseases but is not an accurate measure of total body fat content.
  • Option C. Body mass index - BMI is calculated from height and weight (kg/m²) and provides a general estimate of body composition. However, it doesn't distinguish between fat mass and lean mass, making it unreliable for accurate total body fat estimation, especially in athletes with high muscle mass.
  • Option D. Total body calcium - This measurement relates primarily to bone mineral density assessment, not body fat estimation. Total body calcium correlates with lean body mass rather than fat mass, making it unsuitable for total body fat determination.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hydrostatic weighing provides the most accurate estimation of total body fat by determining body density through the displacement of water when submerged, allowing precise calculation of fat percentage.

questions.text: Which hormone influences potassium ion concentration in the body? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Insulin

 

Explanation:   


Insulin is a key hormone that influences potassium ion concentration in the body. One of insulin's well-documented physiological effects is causing hypokalemia through its action on cell membranes. When insulin is secreted from pancreatic β cells, it produces a biphasic response - the immediate phase leads to glucose uptake into tissues and simultaneously causes hypokalemia as potassium moves into cells. This potassium-lowering effect is an important aspect of insulin's role in maintaining electrolyte homeostasis alongside its metabolic functions.

 

Other Options: 

 

  • Option A. GH (Growth Hormone) - Growth hormone primarily regulates growth and development of organs throughout the body. While it has multiple metabolic effects, it doesn't directly influence potassium ion concentration in any significant way.
  • Option B. FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone) - FSH is a pituitary hormone involved in reproductive function. It works through the cAMP signaling pathway but has no documented role in potassium regulation or transport.
  • Option D. Oxytocin - Oxytocin functions through the IP3-DAG pathway and is primarily involved in uterine contraction and milk ejection. It doesn't participate in potassium homeostasis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulin plays a critical role in electrolyte balance by promoting cellular uptake of potassium, leading to decreased serum potassium levels (hypokalemia) along with its better-known effects on glucose metabolism.

questions.text: What is the postnatal remnant of the distal umbilical artery? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Medial umbilical ligament

 

Explanation:

 

The distal part of the umbilical artery transforms into the medial umbilical ligament postnatally. This occurs as part of the normal circulatory changes following birth when the placental circulation is no longer needed. The proximal portions of the umbilical arteries remain patent and form the superior vesical arteries, while the distal portions become fibrous cords that appear as medial umbilical folds on the inner surface of the anterior abdominal wall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ligamentum teres: This is incorrect. The ligamentum teres is the postnatal remnant of the umbilical vein, not the umbilical artery. It extends from the umbilicus to the porta hepatis and represents the obliterated umbilical vein.

 

Option B. Superior vesical artery: This is incorrect. The superior vesical artery is derived from the proximal portion of the umbilical artery that remains patent after birth, not the distal portion which becomes ligamentous.

 

Option D. Ligamentum arteriosum: This is incorrect. The ligamentum arteriosum is the postnatal remnant of the ductus arteriosus (which connects the pulmonary trunk to the aorta in fetal life), not the umbilical artery.

 

Education Objective:

 

The distal parts of paired umbilical arteries, after cessation of placental circulation at birth, become fibrous cords known as medial umbilical ligaments, while their proximal portions remain patent as the superior vesical arteries.

questions.text: From which germ layer are astrocytes derived? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Neuroectoderm

 

Explanation:

 

Astrocytes are derived from neuroectoderm. Neuroectoderm is a specialized portion of ectoderm that forms the neural tube and neural crest. The neural tube gives rise to the central nervous system, including neurons and neuroglial cells. Astrocytes are a type of neuroglial cell that form within the central nervous system. They develop from glioblasts (also called spongioblasts), which in turn derive from the germinal neuroepithelial cells of the neural tube wall after they cease to produce neuroblasts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option a) Mesoderm - This is incorrect because mesoderm gives rise to structures like bone, cartilage, muscle, blood, connective tissue, and the urogenital system. While mesoderm contributes to the vascular elements in the nervous system and forms microglia (which are mesodermal in origin), it does not form astrocytes.

 

Option c) Endoderm - This is incorrect because endoderm gives rise to the epithelial lining of the respiratory tract, gastrointestinal tract, bladder, and associated glands. Endoderm has no role in forming any components of the central nervous system, including astrocytes.

 

Option d) None - This is incorrect because astrocytes definitely have a germ layer of origin, which is neuroectoderm.

 

Education Objective: 

 

Astrocytes are neuroglial cells that develop from glioblasts derived from the neuroepithelial cells of the neural tube, making them neuroectodermal in origin. This is consistent with most of the cellular elements of the central nervous system which derive from neuroectoderm

questions.text: Identify the ocular component that originates from neural crest cells. (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Choroid

 

Explanation:

 

The choroid is derived from neural crest cells during embryonic development. Neural crest cells are a special population of cells that originate from the neural tube's edges. During eye development, these cells migrate to form various ocular structures including the choroid, which is the vascular layer between the retina and sclera. The choroid is part of the uveal tract and provides nutrients to the outer retinal layers through its rich vascular network.

 

Note - There is a controversy regarding the correct answer of this question. Our answer is based on Gray's Anatomy, 42nd edition which says "The choroid and sclera differentiate as inner vascular and outer fibrous layers, respectively, from the neural crest mesenchyme that surrounds the optic cup"

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Descemet's membrane: This is not derived from neural crest cells but from neural ectoderm. It's the basement membrane of the corneal endothelium and is secreted by the endothelial cells.
  • Option B. Extraocular muscles: These develop from the mesoderm (specifically from prechordal mesoderm and somitomeres), not from neural crest cells. They include the six muscles that control eye movement.
  • Option C. Vitreous body: This clear gel filling the posterior segment of the eye develops primarily from mesenchymal cells of mesodermal origin, not neural crest cells.

 

Education Objective: 

 

Neural crest cells contribute significantly to ocular development, giving rise to the choroid, corneal endothelium, stroma, melanocytes, ciliary body, and iris stroma, but not to structures like Descemet's membrane, extraocular muscles, or the vitreous body.

questions.text: Which nerve innervates the second branchial arch?(NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Facial nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is the nerve that innervates the second branchial arch. This is a fundamental relationship in embryological development where each pharyngeal (branchial) arch has its own specific nerve supply. The second branchial arch is also called the hyoid arch, and all muscles derived from this arch are innervated by the facial nerve, including the stapedius, stylohyoid, posterior belly of digastric, and muscles of facial expression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option a. Mandibular nerve - This is incorrect because the mandibular nerve (branch of trigeminal nerve, CN V3) innervates the first branchial (mandibular) arch, not the second. The first arch derivatives include muscles of mastication, mylohyoid, anterior belly of digastric, tensor tympani, and tensor veli palatini.

 

Option b. Maxillary nerve - This is incorrect because the maxillary nerve (branch of trigeminal nerve, CN V2) is purely sensory and does not innervate any branchial arch musculature. It provides sensory innervation to structures derived from the maxillary process of the first arch.

 

Option d. Vagus nerve - This is incorrect because the vagus nerve (CN X) innervates the fourth and sixth branchial arches through its branches - the superior laryngeal nerve innervates the fourth arch while the recurrent laryngeal nerve innervates the sixth arch. It does not innervate the second arch.

 

Education Objective: 

 

Each branchial arch has a specific cranial nerve associated with it that innervates all muscles derived from that arch. The facial nerve (CN VII) specifically innervates all muscles derived from the second branchial arch, including the muscles of facial expression

questions.text: From which pharyngeal pouch does the crypta magna develop?(NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2nd

 

Explanation:

 

Crypta magna is part of the palatine tonsil which develops from the epithelial lining of the second pharyngeal pouch. The second pouch contributes significantly to the formation of the tonsils, with the crypta magna being a notable structure within them. This correlates with the broader role of the second pouch in contributing to the immune system via the development of tonsillar tissues.

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • a. 1st: Incorrect as the first pouch develops into the epithelial lining of the auditory tube and middle ear cavity.
  • c. 3rd: Incorrect as it contributes to the development of the thymus and inferior parathyroid glands.
  • d. 4th: Incorrect as it forms the superior parathyroid glands and the ultimobranchial body.

 

Educational objective:

 

The crypta magna, a part of the palatine tonsil, develops from the epithelial lining of the second pharyngeal pouch.

choices.text: Small dorsal part of the hypobranchial eminence

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a source of development for the tongue? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: d) 5th pharyngeal arch

 

Explanation:

 

The 5th pharyngeal arch is not a source of development for the tongue. In human embryology, the 5th pharyngeal arch actually disappears during development and does not contribute to any structures. The tongue develops from several other structures: the anterior two-thirds forms from the lingual swellings of the 1st arch and possibly the tuberculum impar, while the posterior one-third develops from the cranial part of the hypobranchial eminence (related to the 3rd arch). The musculature of the tongue derives from occipital myotomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Lingual swellings of the 1st arch - This is a correct source. The lingual swellings (two lateral lingual swellings) of the 1st pharyngeal arch fuse in the midline to form the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, making this answer incorrect as the question asks for what is NOT a source.

 

Option B) Occipital myotomes - This is a correct source. The musculature of the tongue develops from occipital myotomes, which explains why the tongue muscles are innervated by the hypoglossal nerve (XII). This is a true developmental source, making this answer incorrect for the question.

 

Option C) Small dorsal part of the hypobranchial eminence - This is a correct source. The posterior one-third of the tongue develops from the cranial part of the hypobranchial eminence, which is related to the 3rd pharyngeal arch. This is a true developmental source, making this answer incorrect for the question.

 

 

Education Objective: 

 

The tongue has complex embryological origins from multiple structures including the 1st arch lingual swellings, the 3rd arch via the hypobranchial eminence, and occipital myotomes for its musculature, but not from the 5th pharyngeal arch which disappears during development.

questions.text: From which of the following does the posterior part of the tongue develop? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: c) Hypobranchial eminence

 

 

Explanation:

 

The posterior one-third of the tongue develops from the hypobranchial eminence (also called the copula of His). This midline swelling is formed in relation to the medial ends of the second, third, and fourth pharyngeal arches. The cranial part of the hypobranchial eminence, specifically related to the third arch, forms the posterior one-third of the tongue. This explains why this portion of the tongue is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), which is the nerve of the third arch.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Lingual swelling - This is incorrect because the lingual swellings (from the first pharyngeal arch) contribute to the formation of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, not the posterior part. These swellings fuse with each other and possibly with the tuberculum impar to form the oral part of the tongue.

 

Option B) Tuberculum impar - This is incorrect because the tuberculum impar is a midline swelling that appears between the lingual swellings and contributes to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, not the posterior part. Some sources suggest it may not make a significant contribution at all.

 

Option D) Tongue bud - This is incorrect because "tongue bud" is not a standard term used in the embryological development of the tongue. The tongue develops from the lingual swellings, tuberculum impar, and hypobranchial eminence, not from a structure called the tongue bud.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The tongue has dual embryological origins - the anterior two-thirds develops from first arch derivatives (lingual swellings and possibly tuberculum impar), while the posterior one-third develops from the hypobranchial eminence associated with the third pharyngeal arch.

questions.text: What is the source of the kidney parenchyma? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: c. Metanephros

 

Explanation:

 

The kidney parenchyma develops from the metanephros, which is the third and final set of kidneys to develop in the embryo. The metanephros gives rise to the definitive kidneys. The metanephric blastema (metanephric mesoderm), a specialized portion of the intermediate mesoderm, differentiates into the functional units of the kidney - the nephrons, including the glomeruli, proximal and distal convoluted tubules, and loops of Henle. These structures constitute the parenchyma of the kidney.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ureteric bud - This is incorrect because the ureteric bud, which is an outgrowth from the mesonephric duct, forms the collecting system of the kidney - including the collecting tubules, calyces, renal pelvis, and ureter. It does not form the parenchyma (functional tissue) of the kidney.

 

Option B. Mesonephros - This is incorrect because the mesonephros is the second set of embryonic kidneys that degenerates in both males and females. In males, some of its ducts persist to form the efferent ductules, epididymis, and vas deferens. It does not contribute to the permanent kidney parenchyma.

 

Option D. Paramesonephros - This is incorrect because the paramesonephric ducts (Müllerian ducts) develop adjacent to the mesonephric ducts and give rise to female reproductive structures (fallopian tubes, uterus, and upper portion of the vagina). They are not involved in kidney development at all.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The metanephros is the permanent kidney that develops from intermediate mesoderm. It has two components: the metanephric blastema which forms the functional kidney parenchyma, and the ureteric bud which forms the collecting system.

questions.text: From which structure does the female urethra develop? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Urogenital sinus

 

Explanation:

 

The female urethra develops from the urogenital sinus. During embryonic development, the cloaca divides into a posterior anorectal canal and an anterior urogenital sinus. The urogenital sinus further differentiates into three parts: the upper part forms the urinary bladder, the middle part forms the female urethra, and the lower part contributes to the vestibule of the vagina. The female urethra is therefore a direct derivative of the urogenital sinus and is lined by endoderm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mesonephric duct - This is incorrect because the mesonephric duct (Wolffian duct) regresses in females. In males, it develops into the epididymis, vas deferens, ejaculatory duct, and seminal vesicle. The mesonephric duct does not contribute to the female urethra.

 

Option C. Ureteric bud - This is incorrect because the ureteric bud is an outgrowth from the mesonephric duct that induces the development of the metanephric blastema. It forms the collecting system of the kidney including the collecting tubules, calyces, renal pelvis, and ureter, but not the urethra.

 

Option D. Metanephric blastema - This is incorrect because the metanephric blastema is a condensation of intermediate mesoderm that forms the secretory portion of the nephron (glomerulus, proximal and distal tubules, loop of Henle). It forms the functional tissue of the kidney but does not contribute to the urethra.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The female urethra develops from the middle portion of the urogenital sinus, which is an endoderm-lined structure formed by the division of the cloaca. This developmental path explains why the female urethral lining is continuous with the bladder epithelium.

questions.text: What is the germ layer origin of the epithelium of the urinary bladder? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: c) Endoderm

 

Explanation:

 

The epithelium of the urinary bladder is derived from endoderm. The urinary bladder develops from the urogenital sinus, which forms after the cloaca is divided by the urorectal septum into a dorsal anorectal canal and a ventral urogenital sinus. The urogenital sinus is lined by endoderm. As development continues, the upper portion of the urogenital sinus expands to form the urinary bladder, while the lower portion forms the urethra. The endodermal lining of the urogenital sinus differentiates into the transitional epithelium (urothelium) that lines the bladder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option a) Ectoderm - This is incorrect because ectoderm gives rise to the epidermis, nervous system, and various specialized structures like hair, nails, and tooth enamel. It does not contribute to the urinary bladder epithelium.

 

Option b) Mesoderm - This is incorrect because although mesoderm forms the muscular wall (detrusor muscle) and connective tissue of the urinary bladder, it does not form the epithelial lining. Mesoderm forms the middle layer of the trilaminar embryonic disc and gives rise to muscle, bone, connective tissue, kidneys, and gonads.

 

Option d) Neuroectoderm - This is incorrect because neuroectoderm, a specialized portion of ectoderm, forms the neural tube and neural crest cells. It gives rise to the central nervous system, peripheral nervous system, and various neural crest derivatives, but not to the epithelium of the urinary bladder.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The epithelium of the urinary bladder derives from endoderm of the urogenital sinus, while its muscular and connective tissue components are mesodermal in origin, demonstrating how different germ layers contribute to the formation of a single organ.

questions.text: In which lobe of the brain is the supramarginal gyrus located? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Parietal lobe

 

 

Explanation:

 

The supramarginal gyrus is located in the parietal lobe of the cerebral hemisphere. Specifically, it is a part of the inferior parietal lobule. The supramarginal gyrus is situated around the posterior end of the lateral sulcus (Sylvian fissure) and forms the anterior part of the inferior parietal lobule. It plays an important role in language function, particularly in the dominant hemisphere, and is involved in the processing of tactile and visual information to guide actions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option b. Frontal lobe - The frontal lobe contains structures like the precentral gyrus (motor area), premotor area, and prefrontal cortex. It does not contain the supramarginal gyrus.

 

Option c. Temporal lobe - The temporal lobe contains structures such as the superior, middle, and inferior temporal gyri, as well as areas related to auditory processing and memory. The supramarginal gyrus is not part of this lobe.

 

Option d. Occipital lobe - The occipital lobe is primarily concerned with visual processing and contains the visual cortex. The supramarginal gyrus is not located in this lobe.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The supramarginal gyrus is a key component of the inferior parietal lobule in the parietal lobe and plays important roles in language processing, fine finger movements, and tongue movements, with integrated visual, auditory, and proprioceptive functions.

questions.text: From where do climbing fibers originate? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a) Inferior olivary nucleus

 

Explanation:

 

Climbing fibers originate from the inferior olivary nucleus in the medulla oblongata. These fibers form the olivocerebellar tract and enter the cerebellum through the inferior cerebellar peduncle. Each climbing fiber makes extensive excitatory synaptic connections with a single Purkinje cell in the cerebellar cortex, wrapping around the Purkinje cell dendrites like a vine climbing a trellis (hence the name). This powerful one-to-one connection allows the inferior olivary nucleus to strongly influence cerebellar output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Red nucleus - The red nucleus is located in the midbrain and gives rise to the rubrospinal tract, not climbing fibers. It receives input from the cerebellum rather than sending fibers to it.

 

Option C. Caudate nucleus - The caudate nucleus is part of the basal ganglia and has no direct connections with the cerebellum. It is involved in motor control but does not give rise to climbing fibers.

 

Option D. Putamen - Like the caudate nucleus, the putamen is part of the basal ganglia (specifically the lentiform nucleus). It does not project directly to the cerebellum and has no role in producing climbing fibers.

 

Education Objective: 

 

Climbing fibers exclusively originate from the inferior olivary nucleus and form powerful one-to-one excitatory connections with Purkinje cells, providing a critical error-correction signal to the cerebellum.

questions.text: Around which structure does the right recurrent laryngeal nerve loop? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a. Right subclavian artery

 

 

Explanation:

 

The right recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the right subclavian artery. After arising from the vagus nerve in the neck, it winds posteriorly around the first part of the right subclavian artery and then ascends in the tracheo-esophageal groove to reach the larynx. This looping course is due to embryological development - as the heart and great vessels descend during development, they pull the nerves along with them, creating the recurrent course on both sides, but with different looping points.

 

Other Options:

 

Option b. Right axillary artery - The recurrent laryngeal nerve does not loop around the axillary artery. The axillary artery is the continuation of the subclavian artery beyond the lateral border of the first rib.

 

Option c. Right external carotid artery - The recurrent laryngeal nerve does not loop around the external carotid artery. This artery supplies structures of the face and neck.

 

Option d. Right superior thyroid artery - The recurrent laryngeal nerve does not loop around the superior thyroid artery. This is a branch of the external carotid artery that supplies the thyroid gland.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The right recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the right subclavian artery, while the left recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the arch of aorta (specifically the ligamentum arteriosum), creating asymmetry in their courses.

questions.text: Which nerve is responsible for carrying taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue? ( NEET PG  2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: b. Facial nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is responsible for carrying taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Specifically, these taste fibers travel via the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve. The chorda tympani leaves the facial nerve in the facial canal, traverses the middle ear cavity, and joins the lingual nerve (a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve). Through this pathway, taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue reaches the nucleus of the tractus solitarius in the brainstem.

 

Other Options:

 

Option a. Glossopharyngeal nerve - This nerve carries taste sensation from the posterior one-third of the tongue and the vallate papillae, not the anterior two-thirds.

 

Option c. Vagus nerve - This nerve provides taste sensation from the epiglottis and a small area of the pharynx, not from the anterior tongue.

 

Option d. Hypoglossal nerve - This is primarily a motor nerve that supplies the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue. It does not carry taste sensation.

 

Education Objective: 

 

Taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is carried by the facial nerve via its chorda tympani branch, which joins the lingual nerve to reach its destination.

questions.text: Where are the Fissures of Santorini located? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: d. External auditory meatus

 

Explanation:

 

The Fissures of Santorini are located in the external auditory meatus, specifically in the cartilaginous part of the external acoustic meatus. The cartilaginous part is C-shaped in section, and the gap of the 'C' is filled with fibrous tissue. These fissures or deficiencies in the cartilaginous wall are naturally occurring gaps that allow for flexibility of the external auditory canal.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stomach - The stomach doesn't contain Fissures of Santorini. The stomach has rugae (folds) in its mucosa and has several anatomical parts including the cardia, fundus, body, and pylorus, but no structures called Fissures of Santorini.

 

Option B. Rectum - The rectum has transverse folds called rectal valves (of Houston), but not Fissures of Santorini. These valves support the weight of fecal matter and help prevent incontinence.

 

Option C. Thyroid gland - The thyroid gland consists of two lobes connected by an isthmus, with a pyramidal lobe sometimes present, but doesn't contain structures called Fissures of Santorini. You might be confusing this with the thyroglossal duct, which is an embryological structure.

 

Education Objective:

 

Fissures of Santorini are gaps in the cartilaginous wall of the external auditory meatus that provide flexibility to the ear canal and are clinically relevant as potential pathways for infection spread from the external ear to surrounding tissues.

questions.text: Wrist drop is typically a symptom of which type of nerve palsy? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a. Radial nerve palsy

 

Explanation:

 

Wrist drop is a classic sign of radial nerve palsy. The radial nerve supplies all the extensor muscles of the wrist and fingers. When damaged, patients lose the ability to extend the wrist, leading to the characteristic "wrist drop" appearance. The radial nerve can be injured at various sites - in the axilla, spiral groove, or below the radial groove. Injury at the spiral groove, as seen in "Saturday night palsy," causes loss of extension at the wrist and fingers, resulting in wrist drop. The patient is unable to extend their hand at the wrist joint, and the hand hangs limply in a flexed position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior interosseous nerve injury: This is the deep branch of the radial nerve and would cause finger drop (inability to extend fingers) but typically maintains wrist extension, as it supplies the extensor digitorum but not the wrist extensors.

 

Option C. Ulnar nerve palsy: Causes claw hand deformity with hyperextension at metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at interphalangeal joints of the 4th and 5th digits. It does not cause wrist drop.

 

Option D. Carpal tunnel syndrome: Results from compression of the median nerve at the wrist, causing numbness and tingling in the thumb, index, middle fingers and lateral half of the ring finger, with weakness of thumb opposition and abduction. No wrist drop occurs.

 

 

Education Objective: 

 

Wrist drop is the pathognomonic sign of radial nerve injury, caused by paralysis of the wrist extensor muscles, particularly the extensor carpi radialis longus and brevis.

questions.text: Which clinical sign is associated with median nerve injury? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a. Pointing index


Explanation:

 

 

Pointing index sign occurs due to median nerve injury resulting in paralysis of the flexor digitorum profundus muscle in the index and middle fingers. When the patient attempts to make a fist, the index finger remains extended or "pointing" while other fingers flex normally. This occurs because the median nerve supplies the lateral half of the flexor digitorum profundus (affecting the index and middle fingers) through its anterior interosseous branch. This characteristic deformity is also known as Ochsner's clasp test and is a classic sign of median nerve injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wrist drop: This is associated with radial nerve injury, occurring when the extensor muscles of the wrist are paralyzed, causing the hand to hang in flexion at the wrist.

 

Option C. Wartenberg's sign: This is seen in ulnar nerve palsy, where the little finger remains abducted and cannot be adducted due to paralysis of the palmar interossei muscles with unopposed action of the extensor digiti minimi.

 

Option D. Regimental badge sign: This refers to the sensory loss over the lower half of the deltoid muscle in a badge-like area due to axillary nerve injury, which commonly occurs with shoulder dislocations or fractures of the surgical neck of the humerus.

 

Education Objective: 

 

Pointing index is a characteristic sign of median nerve injury where the index finger fails to flex properly during grip formation, remaining extended while other fingers flex normally.

questions.text: What forms the lateral border of the cubital fossa? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a) Brachioradialis

 

Explanation:

 

The lateral border of the cubital fossa is formed by the medial border of the brachioradialis muscle. The cubital fossa is a triangular depression located at the anterior aspect of the elbow joint. Its boundaries are well-defined, with the brachioradialis forming the lateral boundary as this muscle courses from its origin at the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus downward toward the styloid process of the radius. This muscle is easily palpable when the forearm is flexed against resistance in the mid-prone position.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pronator teres: This muscle forms the medial boundary of the cubital fossa, not the lateral boundary. It runs from the medial epicondyle of the humerus to the middle of the lateral aspect of the radius.

 

Option C. Flexor carpi radialis: While located in the anterior compartment of the forearm, it does not form any boundary of the cubital fossa. It lies medial to the pronator teres.

 

Option D. Triceps: This is a posterior compartment muscle of the arm that inserts into the olecranon process of the ulna. It is not related to the boundaries of the cubital fossa, which is an anterior structure.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The cubital fossa is bounded laterally by brachioradialis, medially by pronator teres, with its apex formed by the meeting of these two muscles, and its base represented by an imaginary line connecting the humeral epicondyles.

questions.text: Which muscle segments the axillary artery into three distinct parts? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a. Pectoralis minor

 

Explanation:

 

The pectoralis minor muscle divides the axillary artery into three parts as the artery passes through the axilla. The first part extends from the outer border of the first rib to the upper border of pectoralis minor. The second part lies posterior (deep) to the pectoralis minor muscle. The third part extends from the lower border of pectoralis minor to the lower border of teres major muscle, where the axillary artery continues as the brachial artery. This relationship is clinically important for describing branches of the axillary artery and for surgical approaches to the axilla.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pectoralis major: This larger muscle forms part of the anterior wall of the axilla but does not divide the axillary artery into segments. It overlies the pectoralis minor and forms the anterior axillary fold.

 

Option C. Serratus anterior: This muscle forms the medial wall of the axilla and has no direct relationship with segmentation of the axillary artery. It originates from the upper ribs and inserts on the medial border of the scapula.

 

 

Option D. Scalenus anticus: This is a neck muscle that divides the subclavian artery into three parts, not the axillary artery. The subclavian artery becomes the axillary artery at the outer border of the first rib.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The pectoralis minor muscle serves as an important anatomical landmark that divides the axillary artery into three parts, which helps in describing the branches of the axillary artery systematically.

questions.text: Which nerve root is primarily associated with weakness of the Extensor Hallucis Longus?(NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a) L5

 

Explanation:

 

Extensor hallucis longus is primarily innervated by the L5 nerve root. This muscle belongs to the anterior compartment of the leg and is supplied by the deep peroneal nerve which has root value L4, L5, and S1. The myotome chart clearly indicates that extensor hallucis longus has a predominant L5 innervation, making weakness of this muscle a key clinical sign in L5 radiculopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. L4: While L4 contributes to the deep peroneal nerve, it primarily supplies tibialis anterior and tibialis posterior. L4 is more associated with ankle dorsiflexion but not specifically with great toe extension.

 

Option C. S1: S1 primarily innervates the gastrocnemius, soleus, peronei, and extensor digitorum brevis. It's more associated with plantar flexion and foot eversion rather than great toe extension.

 

Option D. S2: S2 primarily innervates intrinsic foot muscles, flexor digitorum longus, and flexor hallucis longus. It has no significant contribution to extensor hallucis longus innervation.

 

Education Objective: 

 

L5 is the predominant nerve root for extensor hallucis longus, making great toe extension weakness a classic clinical finding in L5 radiculopathy.

questions.text: What is a common element of both the medial and lateral plantar arches? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: b) Plantar fascia

 

Explanation:

 

The plantar fascia is a common element supporting both the medial and lateral longitudinal arches of the foot. This thick, fibrous band of tissue extends from the calcaneal tuberosity anteriorly to the metatarsal heads, serving as a crucial passive support structure. The plantar fascia acts like a bowstring, tensing during weight-bearing to maintain both longitudinal arches. When the toes are extended, it tightens through the windlass mechanism, increasing arch height and providing stability to both medial and lateral aspects of the foot.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Flexor digitorum brevis - This muscle primarily supports the medial longitudinal arch rather than both arches. It originates from the medial tubercle of the calcaneus and inserts into the middle phalanges of the lateral four toes.

 

Option C) Spring ligament (plantar calcaneonavicular ligament) - This ligament specifically supports the head of the talus and the medial longitudinal arch. It does not contribute significantly to the lateral arch support.

 

Option D) Deltoid ligament - This ligament attaches to the medial malleolus of the tibia and provides medial stability to the ankle joint. While it helps support the medial arch, it has minimal contribution to the lateral arch.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The plantar fascia is a critical passive support structure for both the medial and lateral longitudinal arches of the foot, functioning as a tension band that provides dynamic support during weight-bearing and movement.

questions.text: Which nerve is responsible for innervating the cremaster muscle? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: b. Genitofemoral nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The cremaster muscle receives its motor innervation from the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve (L1). The cremaster muscle consists of muscle fasciculi embedded in the cremasteric fascia. These fasciculi form superficial loops from the middle one-third of the upper surface of the inguinal ligament and deep loops from the pubic tubercle, pubic crest, and conjoint tendon. The muscle is fully developed only in males and forms a sac-like cremasteric fascia around the spermatic cord and testis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iliohypogastric nerve - This nerve (L1) supplies the skin of the anterior abdominal wall and becomes cutaneous about 2.5 cm above the superficial inguinal ring. It does not innervate the cremaster muscle.
