Option C. Obturator nerve - This nerve supplies the adductor muscles of the thigh and provides sensory innervation to the medial aspect of the thigh. It has no role in innervating the cremaster muscle.

 

Option D. Femoral nerve - This nerve supplies the anterior compartment muscles of the thigh and provides sensory innervation to the anterior thigh and medial leg. It does not supply the cremaster muscle.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The cremaster muscle, which can elevate the testis and helps close the superficial inguinal ring during increased intra-abdominal pressure, is innervated by the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve (L1) and its reflex contraction (cremasteric reflex) indicates the integrity of the L1 spinal segment.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is NOT innervated by the superior gluteal nerve? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: b. Gluteus maximus

 

Explanation:

 

The superior gluteal nerve innervates the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae muscles. Gluteus maximus is instead innervated by the inferior gluteal nerve. The superior gluteal nerve arises from the sacral plexus (L4, L5, S1) and exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen above the piriformis muscle. It then runs between the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles and supplies both these muscles along with the tensor fasciae latae.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gluteus medius - This muscle is correctly innervated by the superior gluteal nerve. It functions primarily as a hip abductor and helps stabilize the pelvis during walking.

 

Option C. Gluteus minimus - This is indeed supplied by the superior gluteal nerve. Like the gluteus medius, it acts as a hip abductor and medial rotator of the thigh.

 

Option D. Tensor fasciae latae - This muscle receives innervation from the superior gluteal nerve. It functions to tense the fascia lata and assists in hip flexion, abduction, and medial rotation.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1) innervates three muscles: gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae, while the gluteus maximus receives its innervation from the inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2).

questions.text: What is the function of the popliteus muscle? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Unlocking of knee joint

 

Explanation:

 

The popliteus muscle plays a crucial role in unlocking the knee joint. When the knee is in full extension, the femur undergoes Medial rotation in relation to the tibia (known as the "screw-home mechanism"), which locks the knee joint in place for stability during standing. The popliteus muscle initiates knee flexion by first rotating the femur laterally to unlock this mechanism. This unlocking action is essential before the hamstring muscles can effectively flex the knee joint. The popliteus is a triangular muscle located in the posterior aspect of the knee.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Locking of knee joint - This is incorrect. The locking mechanism of the knee is primarily a passive mechanism involving the medial rotation of the femur on the tibia in full extension, not an active muscular function of the popliteus. The quadriceps muscle group is responsible for extending the knee and contributing to the locking mechanism.

 

Option C. Medial rotation of femur on tibia - Popliteus rotates femur laterally and not medially

 

Option D. None of the above - This is incorrect as option B accurately describes the primary function of the popliteus muscle.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The popliteus muscle is essential for initiating knee flexion by unlocking the knee joint through lateral rotation of the femur on the tibia, reversing the "screw-home mechanism" that locks the knee in full extension.

questions.text: Which structure constitutes the base of the heart? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: d) Left atrium

 

Explanation:

 

The base of the heart is formed mainly by the left atrium with a small contribution from the right atrium. The base is also called the posterior surface of the heart. It faces posteriorly toward the vertebral column and forms the posterior boundary of the heart. This base is separated from the vertebral column by the pericardium, the right pulmonary veins, the esophagus, and the aorta. The posterior surface receives the four pulmonary veins (two right and two left) which open into the left atrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left ventricle: The left ventricle forms the apex of the heart, not the base. It constitutes most of the left border, part of the sternocostal surface, and the inferolateral surface of the heart.

 

Option B. Right ventricle: The right ventricle forms the inferior border and most of the sternocostal surface of the heart. It does not contribute to the base of the heart.

 

Option C. Right atrium: While the right atrium does contribute to the base of the heart, it forms only a small part (approximately one-third), with the left atrium forming the major component (approximately two-thirds) of the base.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The base or posterior surface of the heart is predominantly formed by the left atrium (two-thirds) with a smaller contribution from the right atrium (one-third).

questions.text: A fracture that involves the epiphysis, physis, and metaphysis is classified as which type of Salter-Harris fracture? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Type IV

 

Salter-Harris Type IV fracture involves a vertical fracture line that extends from the articular surface through the epiphysis, across the growth plate (physis), and into the metaphysis. This is a complete fracture that traverses all three components - epiphysis, physis, and metaphysis. These fractures require precise anatomical reduction, usually through open reduction and internal fixation, as they have a high risk of growth disturbance if not properly aligned.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I: This fracture involves only the growth plate (physis) with complete separation of the epiphysis from the metaphysis. The fracture line runs horizontally through the physis without involving either the epiphysis or metaphysis.

 

Option B. Type II: This fracture extends through the physis and partially into the metaphysis (creating the Thurston-Holland fragment), but does not involve the epiphysis. The epiphyseal surface remains intact.

 

Option C. Type III: This fracture extends vertically through the epiphysis and physis but stops at the metaphysis. It involves the articular surface but does not extend into the metaphysis, differentiating it from Type IV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Salter-Harris Type IV fractures are the only type that involve all three anatomical components (epiphysis, physis, and metaphysis) and therefore have a high risk of growth disturbance, requiring accurate reduction to prevent long-term complications.

questions.text: The classic Unhappy Triad (O' Donoghue's Triad) involves injuries to all of the following structures, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Posterior Cruciate Ligament (PCL)

 

O'Donoghue's Triad, also known as the "Unhappy Triad," consists of three specific knee structures that are commonly injured together in sports: the Medial Collateral Ligament (MCL), Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL), and Medial Meniscus. The PCL is not part of this classic injury pattern. This triad typically occurs when a valgus force is applied to the knee while it's in a flexed position with external rotation, commonly during contact sports.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial Meniscus - This is incorrect because the medial meniscus is actually part of O'Donoghue's Triad. It is often damaged alongside the ACL and MCL when the knee experiences a valgus force with rotation.

 

Option B. Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) - This is incorrect because the ACL is an essential component of O'Donoghue's Triad. It prevents anterior translation of the tibia and is commonly torn in this injury pattern.

 

Option C. Medial Collateral Ligament (MCL) - This is incorrect because the MCL is a key component of O'Donoghue's Triad. It resists valgus forces at the knee joint and is typically the first structure damaged in this injury pattern.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

O'Donoghue's Triad consists of injuries to the ACL, MCL, and medial meniscus (often remembered as MAM), while the PCL is not included in this classic injury pattern.

questions.text: In children, which of the following tumors most commonly arises in the epiphysis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Chondroblastoma

 

Chondroblastoma is the most common epiphyseal tumor in children before skeletal maturity. The epiphyseal region is predominantly affected by chondroblastoma followed by giant cell tumor (which typically occurs after skeletal maturity). Chondroblastoma is often referred to as Codman's tumor and characteristically presents with calcification within the epiphysis. It typically appears as a well-defined lytic lesion surrounded by a zone of sclerosis with areas of calcification giving it a mottled appearance radiographically.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aneurysmal Bone Cyst (ABC) - This is primarily a metaphyseal lesion that occurs in the 2nd decade of life. ABC is multiloculated, eccentric and expansile in nature, commonly affecting the tibia. On MRI, it shows characteristic "fluid-fluid levels" due to its multiple septae.

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma - Osteosarcoma characteristically affects the metaphysis of long bones, particularly around the knee (lower femur, upper tibia). It rarely crosses the growth plate into the epiphysis and presents with aggressive features like periosteal reaction and Codman's triangle.

 

Option D. Unicameral Bone Cyst - Also known as Simple Bone Cyst (SBC), this lesion occurs in the metaphysis of long bones, most commonly in the proximal humerus. It typically presents in the 1st decade of life with a central, single cavity containing straw-colored fluid.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Chondroblastoma is the most common epiphyseal tumor in children before skeletal maturity, while after skeletal maturity, Giant Cell Tumor becomes the predominant epiphyseal tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves does not lie in close contact with the humerus? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Musculocutaneous Nerve

 

The musculocutaneous nerve does not lie in close contact with the humerus along its course. This nerve originates from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus (C5-C7) and travels through the anterior compartment of the arm. Importantly, it pierces the coracobrachialis muscle and then passes between the biceps and brachialis muscles, staying within the soft tissue compartments without establishing a close relationship with the humeral bone.

The musculocutaneous nerve supplies the muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm (coracobrachialis, biceps brachii, and brachialis) and continues as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm for sensory distribution.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Axillary Nerve - This nerve does lie in close contact with the humerus, specifically at the surgical neck. It courses around the neck of the humerus in the quadrangular space, making it vulnerable to injury in proximal humeral fractures and anterior shoulder dislocations.

 

Option B. Radial Nerve - This nerve has an intimate relationship with the humerus as it travels in the spiral groove (radial groove) on the posterior aspect of the humerus. This close relationship makes it the most commonly injured nerve in humeral shaft fractures, especially in the middle and lower third.

 

Option D. Ulnar Nerve - The ulnar nerve comes into close contact w`ith the humerus at the medial epicondyle. At the elbow, it passes behind the medial epicondyle in the cubital tunnel, making it vulnerable to injury at this site (cubital tunnel syndrome).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Nerves that lie in close contact with bones are more susceptible to injury during fractures, and the musculocutaneous nerve is relatively protected as it travels through soft tissue compartments without establishing close contact with the humerus, unlike the axillary, radial, and ulnar nerves.

choices.text: Fracture of the head of radius

questions.text: Nursemaid’s Elbow refers to which of the following? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Subluxation of proximal radioulnar joint

 

Nursemaid's Elbow refers to a subluxation of the proximal radioulnar joint where the annular ligament partially slips over the radial head. This typically occurs in young children (ages 1-4) when the arm is suddenly pulled longitudinally, such as when an adult pulls a child's hand to prevent falling or to lift them. The partial displacement of the annular ligament causes pain and the child typically holds the arm in pronation with the elbow slightly flexed, refusing to use it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: This is incorrect. Nursemaid's Elbow is not a complete dislocation of the elbow joint but rather a subluxation specifically of the proximal radioulnar joint where the radius and ulna meet at the elbow.

 

Option B: This is incorrect. Subluxation of the distal radioulnar joint typically occurs from a fall on an outstretched hand and affects the wrist area, not the elbow. This is not Nursemaid's Elbow.

 

Option D: This is incorrect. Nursemaid's Elbow does not involve a fracture of the radial head. It is a soft tissue injury involving the annular ligament rather than a bony injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nursemaid's Elbow (radial head subluxation) is a common pediatric injury involving slippage of the annular ligament over the radial head at the proximal radioulnar joint, typically caused by longitudinal traction to the arm and treated with simple reduction maneuvers.

questions.text: Kienbock disease is caused by avascular necrosis of which of the following bones? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Lunate

 

Kienbock's disease refers to avascular necrosis of the lunate bone, which is one of the carpal bones in the wrist. It appears in the classification of common osteochondrites, which are a group of miscellaneous affections of growing epiphyses in children and adolescents. This condition typically presents with wrist pain, reduced grip strength, and limited wrist motion due to the compromised blood supply to the lunate.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral neck - Avascular necrosis of the femoral neck is a different condition. In adults, it's simply called AVN of the femoral head, while in children it manifests as Perthes' disease (which affects the femoral head epiphysis, not the neck). The femoral head is particularly vulnerable to AVN due to its retrograde blood supply.

 

Option B. Medial cuneiform - There is no well-established avascular necrosis condition specifically named for the medial cuneiform bone. This bone is part of the midfoot and is not commonly affected by osteochondritis or avascular necrosis.

 

Option D. Scaphoid - While the scaphoid is prone to avascular necrosis, particularly after fracture due to its retrograde blood supply, this condition is not called Kienbock's disease. Avascular necrosis of the scaphoid typically occurs following scaphoid fractures and is not classified as an osteochondritis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Kienbock's disease specifically refers to avascular necrosis of the lunate bone, which is one of several named osteochondritis conditions affecting different bones throughout the body.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Tuberculosis of the Hip during the Stage of Synovitis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Apparent Lengthening

 

In the stage of synovitis (Stage I) of tuberculosis of the hip, there is effusion into the joint which demands the hip to be positioned for maximum capacity. This position is one of flexion, abduction, and external rotation. Due to the pelvic tilt compensating for the abduction deformity, the pelvis tilts downwards on the affected side, which creates an apparent lengthening of the limb. However, when true limb lengths are measured, both limbs are equal. This stage is therefore also called the "stage of apparent lengthening" and lasts for a very short period.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flexion, Abduction, Internal Rotation - This is incorrect because in Stage I (synovitis), the hip assumes a position of flexion, abduction, and external rotation. Internal rotation typically occurs in Stage II (arthritis) when muscle spasm develops.

 

Option B. Flexion, Adduction, External Rotation - This is incorrect because during synovitis, the position is flexion, abduction, and external rotation. Adduction deformity develops later in Stage II when articular cartilage involvement leads to muscle spasm.

 

Option D. True Shortening - This is incorrect for Stage I. True shortening occurs in Stage III (stage of erosion) when there is actual destruction of bone. In Stage I, there is apparent lengthening with equal true limb lengths.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

TB Hip Stage I (synovitis) presents with the hip in flexion, abduction, and external rotation, resulting in apparent lengthening due to downward pelvic tilt compensating for abduction deformity, while true limb lengths remain equal.

choices.text: Fracture of the Shaft of Humerus
Fracture of the Shaft of Femur

questions.text: Gallow’s traction is primarily used for which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Fracture of the Shaft of Femur

 

Gallows traction is primarily used for fractures of the shaft of femur in infants and very young children (typically under 2 years of age). In this traction method, both lower limbs are suspended vertically from overhead with the hips flexed to 90 degrees, regardless of which femur is fractured. This position allows for proper alignment of the femoral fracture while permitting diaper changes and nursing care. The child's body weight provides the counterforce for the traction.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Perthes' Disease is treated with various methods to maintain the femoral head within the acetabulum, including abduction braces, casting, or surgical containment, but Gallows traction is not typically used for this condition.

 

Option B: Fractures of the humeral shaft in children are typically treated with hanging arm casts, coaptation splints, or functional bracing. Overhead traction like Gallows traction would not be appropriate for upper extremity fractures.

 

Option D: Pelvic fractures in children are usually treated with bed rest, analgesics, and mobilization as tolerated. More severe fractures might require external fixation or open reduction, but Gallows traction is not used for pelvic fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gallows traction is a specific type of skin traction used for femoral shaft fractures in very young children that suspends both legs vertically, utilizing the child's body weight as counter-traction while allowing for easy care and diaper changes.

choices.text: Tenderness along the flexor tendon sheath
Flexed resting posture of the finger
Pain on passive flexion of the finger

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in Kanavel Signs of pyogenic flexor tenosynovitis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Pain on passive flexion of the finger

 

Kanavel's signs are the classic diagnostic features of pyogenic flexor tenosynovitis. The four cardinal signs include tenderness along the tendon sheath (the most specific sign), flexion of the finger at rest, fusiform (uniform) swelling of the finger, and pain on passive extension of the finger (not flexion). Pain occurs during extension because stretching the infected tendon sheath exacerbates the pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tenderness along the flexor tendon sheath: This is a correct Kanavel sign and is considered the most specific feature of flexor tenosynovitis. The tenderness follows the course of the infected tendon sheath.

 

Option B. Flexed resting posture of the finger: This is a correct Kanavel sign. The infected finger is typically held in slight flexion as this position minimizes tension on the inflamed tendon sheath.

 

Option C. Fusiform swelling of the finger: This is a correct Kanavel sign. The swelling in tenosynovitis is uniform throughout the length of the finger due to the inflammation of the entire tendon sheath.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Kanavel's signs for diagnosing flexor tenosynovitis include tenderness along the tendon sheath, flexed position of the finger, uniform (fusiform) swelling, and pain on passive extension (not flexion) of the finger.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is intracapsular but extrasynovial? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Long Biceps Tendon

 

The long head of biceps tendon is a classic example of a structure that is intracapsular (inside the joint capsule) but extrasynovial (outside the synovial membrane). As the tendon passes from the supraglenoid tubercle through the shoulder joint to reach the bicipital groove, it pierces the capsule but remains enveloped by a synovial sheath. This unique anatomical arrangement allows the tendon to pass through the joint while maintaining its own synovial environment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pectoralis Major - This muscle is completely extracapsular and extrasynovial. It inserts onto the lateral lip of the bicipital groove of the humerus and does not enter the joint capsule at any point.

 

Option C. Popliteus Muscle - While the popliteus tendon does have a complex relationship with the knee joint, it is not truly intracapsular and extrasynovial like the long head of biceps. Its tendon passes beneath the lateral collateral ligament outside the joint capsule. Therefore, part of its tendon is intracapsular, while the question muscle itself is largely extracapsular.

 

Option D. Supraspinatus Tendon - This tendon is part of the rotator cuff and lies outside both the joint capsule and synovial membrane, making it extracapsular and extrasynovial. It passes over the shoulder joint capsule but doesn't penetrate it.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The long head of biceps tendon has a unique anatomical position as it travels through the shoulder joint capsule (intracapsular) while remaining outside the synovial cavity (extrasynovial), which has important implications for pathological processes affecting this structure.

questions.text: Delusions are commonly observed in all of the following conditions, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Conversion Disorder

 

Explanation: 

 

Conversion Disorder (also called Functional Neurological Symptom Disorder or Dissociative Neurological Symptom Disorder in ICD-11) is characterized by neurological symptoms like paralysis, blindness, or seizures that cannot be explained by medical conditions. Importantly, delusions are not a feature of conversion disorder. Conversion disorder involves a psychological stressor that manifests as physical symptoms, but the patient does not have false, fixed beliefs (delusions) about their condition.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Schizophrenia (Incorrect): Delusions are core symptoms of schizophrenia. According to the DSM-5 criteria, delusions are one of the characteristic positive symptoms required for diagnosis.
  • Option B. Depression (Incorrect): Delusions can develop in a patient with depression. These may include delusions of guilt, nihilistic delusions (e.g., believing internal organs have rotted), or delusions of poverty.
  • Option C. Dementia (Incorrect): Delusions can occur in dementia, particularly in moderate to severe stages. These are usually transient and less complex than those seen in primary psychotic disorders. Common delusions in dementia include persecutory delusions, delusions of theft, or misidentification delusions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Delusions are common features of psychotic disorders like schizophrenia, severe mood disorders with psychotic features (including depression), and neurocognitive disorders like dementia. Conversion disorder, however, is characterized by unexplained neurological symptoms without the presence of delusions, as it belongs to the somatic symptom/dissociative disorder category rather than the psychotic spectrum.

questions.text: A two-year-old boy presents with delayed speech, difficulties in communication, and repetitive behaviors such as staring at his own hands. He struggles with making friends and concentrating. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Autism

 

Explanation: 

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests Autism (now classified as Autism Spectrum Disorder in current diagnostic systems). The key features presented in this case include:

  1. Delayed speech and difficulties in communication (language impairment)
  2. Repetitive behaviors (staring at hands) which represent restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior
  3. Social interaction difficulties (struggles with making friends)
  4. Age of presentation before 3 years (the child is 2 years old)

 

These symptoms align perfectly with the core diagnostic criteria of autism, which includes impairments in social interaction, and restricted/repetitive behaviors. Communication deficits are also often seen in autism.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. ADHD (Incorrect): While ADHD can present with concentration difficulties, it typically doesn't include speech delays, repetitive behaviors, or social interaction difficulties as primary symptoms. ADHD is characterized primarily by inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. 
  • Option C. Mental Retardation (Incorrect): Now termed Intellectual Disability, this condition involves below-average intellectual functioning and adaptive behavior. While intellectual disability can co-occur with autism (around 30% of cases), the repetitive behaviors and specific social interaction difficulties described are more characteristic of autism than isolated intellectual disability.
  • Option D. Specific Learning Disability (Incorrect): Learning disabilities involve difficulties in specific academic skills (reading, writing, mathematics) out of proportion to the intellectual functioning of the child. They aren't typically diagnosed in toddlers as these skills aren't yet expected, and they don't explain the communication deficits, repetitive behaviors, or social difficulties described.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Autism is characterized by impairments in social interaction, and restricted/repetitive behaviors. Communication deficits are also often present in autism. These symptoms typically manifest before age 3, making early identification possible.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to impair scholastic performance? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. PICA

 

Explanation: 

 

PICA is an eating disorder characterized by the persistent consumption of non-nutritive, non-food substances (such as dirt, clay, paper, paint chips, etc.) that is inappropriate for the developmental level of the individual. While PICA can have health consequences due to ingestion of potentially harmful substances, it does not directly impact cognitive functions or learning abilities in the way the other listed conditions do. Therefore, PICA is least likely to directly impair scholastic performance.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) (Incorrect): ADHD is characterized by inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. These symptoms directly interfere with learning processes, classroom behavior, and academic achievement. Children with ADHD often struggle with focusing during lessons, completing assignments, following instructions, and staying organized, all of which significantly impact scholastic performance.
  • Option B. Specific Learning Disability (SLD) (Incorrect): SLD is defined by significant impairment in one or more specific academic skills (reading, writing, mathematics) despite normal intellectual functioning. By definition, SLD directly impacts scholastic performance, as it specifically affects the acquisition and use of academic skills.
  • Option C. Anxiety (Incorrect): Anxiety disorders can significantly impair scholastic performance through several mechanisms. Test anxiety can lead to underperformance in examinations, social anxiety can interfere with class participation and group activities, and generalized anxiety can affect concentration, working memory, and overall cognitive functioning in the classroom setting.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When considering psychiatric disorders that impact academic performance, it's important to differentiate between conditions that directly affect cognitive functions, learning processes, or classroom behavior (like ADHD, learning disabilities, and anxiety) versus conditions that primarily affect other domains of functioning (like certain eating disorders). PICA, as an eating disorder characterized by consumption of non-food substances, has physiological and health implications but does not directly impact the cognitive processes essential for learning.

questions.text: The General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS) primarily describes the body's response to which of the following? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Stressful situations

 

Explanation: 

 

The General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS) is a model developed by Hans Selye that describes the body's physiological response to stress. It outlines how the body responds to any demand (stressor) placed upon it, regardless of whether the stressor is physical, psychological, or environmental. The GAS consists of three stages: alarm reaction (fight-or-flight response), resistance (adaptation), and exhaustion. It represents a general biological response to stress rather than being specific to any particular psychiatric condition.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Panic Attacks (Incorrect): While panic attacks involve physiological stress responses, they represent a specific type of anxiety response rather than the general stress response described by GAS. Panic attacks are acute episodes characterized by intense fear and specific physical symptoms like palpitations, sweating, and shortness of breath.
  • Option B. Depression (Incorrect): Depression represents a mood disorder with persistent low mood, anhedonia, and other emotional and physical symptoms. While chronic stress can contribute to depression, and there may be HPA axis dysregulation in depression, GAS describes the general stress response rather than the specific pathophysiology of depression.
  • Option C. Anxiety Disorders (Incorrect): Anxiety disorders involve excessive worry, fear, and physiological arousal. While anxiety certainly involves stress response systems, GAS describes the broader physiological response to any stressor, not just anxiety disorders.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS) is a fundamental model describing how the body responds physiologically to any type of stressor through three stages: alarm reaction, resistance, and exhaustion. It involves the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis and represents a non-specific response to stress rather than being particular to any specific psychiatric condition.

questions.text: Repeated Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS) of the brain has been FDA-approved for the treatment of which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Depression

 

Explanation: 

 

Repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS) has been approved by the FDA for the treatment of major depressive disorder. rTMS uses rapidly changing magnetic fields to produce small electric currents (known as eddy currents) in superficial cortical neurons" and is "approved as a treatment modality in major depressive disorder." It is typically used for patients with depression who have not responded adequately to antidepressant medications.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Resistant Schizophrenia (Incorrect): While there is ongoing research into the potential benefits of rTMS for various symptoms of schizophrenia, it is not FDA-approved for the treatment of resistant schizophrenia. Clozapine remains the standard treatment for treatment-resistant schizophrenia.
  • Option C. Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (Incorrect): Deep TMS was approved by the FDA for the treatment of OCD in 2018. At the time this question was written, option C was incorrect; however, as of today, it would also be considered a correct option.
  • Option D. Acute Psychosis (Incorrect): rTMS is not FDA-approved for the treatment of acute psychosis. Antipsychotic medications are the primary treatment for acute psychotic episodes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS) is a non-invasive brain stimulation technique that has the FDA approval for the following psychiatric disorders:

  1. Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) 
  2. Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) 
  3. Anxious Depression 
  4. Smoking Cessation

questions.text: A woman compulsively washes her hands at least 40 times per day without any logical reason. Which of the following Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) techniques is most appropriate for her treatment? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Response Prevention

 

Explanation: 

 

Response Prevention is the most appropriate technique for treating compulsive hand washing, which is a classic symptom of OCD. In this case, the woman engages in repetitive handwashing (compulsion) likely in response to obsessive thoughts about contamination. Response Prevention involves preventing the person from performing the compulsive behavior (handwashing) when they feel the urge. This breaks the reinforcement cycle where the anxiety reduction from performing the compulsion reinforces the behavior. When used together with Exposure therapy, it forms "Exposure and Response Prevention" (ERP), which is the first-line psychotherapeutic treatment for OCD.

 

Other Options:

  • Option B. Exposure (Incorrect): While Exposure is an important component of treating OCD, it is typically used in conjunction with Response Prevention. Exposure alone (having the patient confront the feared contaminant) without preventing the compulsive response would not effectively treat the condition as the patient would continue to use handwashing to reduce anxiety. Hence, if we have to pick between exposure and response prevention, the response prevention becomes the better answer.
  • Option C. Thought Stopping (Incorrect): Thought stopping is a technique where the patient attempts to interrupt unwanted thoughts, often using distraction or verbal commands. While sometimes used in cognitive therapy, it's not considered highly effective for OCD treatment and is not the first-line approach for compulsive behaviors.
  • Option D. Desensitization (Incorrect): Systematic desensitization involves gradually exposing patients to anxiety-provoking stimuli while they are in a relaxed state. While useful for specific phobias, it is not the primary technique for treating compulsive behaviors in OCD. The technique doesn't address the response component of the OCD cycle.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) is the treatment of choice for OCD, including compulsive hand washing. Response Prevention specifically targets the compulsive behavior by preventing the ritualistic response, while Exposure targets the obsessional fears. Together they break the OCD cycle of obsessions leading to anxiety, followed by compulsions that temporarily reduce anxiety but ultimately reinforce the behavior.

choices.text: Consumption of large amounts of drug over a prolonged period

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of drug dependence? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Use of illegal substances

 

Explanation: 

 

Use of illegal substances is not a diagnostic feature of drug dependence. Drug dependence is defined by specific psychological and physiological features related to substance use patterns and their effects, regardless of whether the substance is legal or illegal. Dependence can develop to legal substances (such as alcohol, prescription medications) just as it can to illegal substances.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Tolerance (Incorrect): Tolerance is a core feature of drug dependence, defined as "increasing amounts of a substance are required to get the desired effect." As the body adapts to the presence of the substance, more is needed to achieve the same psychoactive effects, which is a hallmark sign of dependence.
  • Option B. Persistent desire to quit drug (Incorrect): A persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to cut down or control substance use is a recognized feature of dependence. This represents the loss of control aspect of addiction, where individuals recognize the problems caused by their substance use but struggle to stop despite their intentions.
  • Option C. Consumption of large amounts of drug over a prolonged period (Incorrect): Taking the substance in larger amounts or over a longer period than was intended is a characteristic feature of dependence. This reflects the impaired control over substance use that defines dependence.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Dependence is characterised by a strong drive to use the substance, as manifested by 

  1. Tolerance- Increasing amounts of a substance are required to get the desired effect 
  2. Withdrawal symptoms: Typical symptoms that develop when the substance intake is reduced or stopped.
  3. Craving- Strong desire or urge to use the substance
  4. Inability to control substance taking behaviour in terms of its onset, termination or levels of use.
  5. Continued use of a substance despite clear harmful consequences.
  6. Progressive neglect of other interests because of substance use.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy involved in drug abuse reports experiencing cross-over of sensory perceptions, where he describes that sounds can be seen and colors can be heard. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible for this effect? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. LSD

 

Explanation: 

 

The phenomenon described is synesthesia (reflex hallucinations), where stimulation in one sensory modality leads to experiences in another sensory modality (e.g., "seeing" sounds or "hearing" colors). This effect is most commonly associated with hallucinogens, particularly LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide).

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Cocaine (Incorrect): Cocaine is a stimulant that primarily causes sympathetic activation (tachycardia, hypertension, mydriasis) and euphoria. While cocaine can cause psychotic symptoms like paranoia and tactile hallucinations ("cocaine bugs" or formication), it does not typically cause synesthesia or sensory crossover effects.
  • Option C. Marijuana (Incorrect): While cannabis (marijuana) can also cause synaesthesia or reflex hallucinations, between cannabis & LSD, LSD remains the better answer as these perceptual disturbances are the characteristic feature of hallucinogen intoxication.
  • Option D. PCP (Incorrect): Phencyclidine (PCP) is a dissociative anesthetic that can cause hallucinations, detachment from reality, and severe behavioral disturbances. While it can cause various perceptual disturbances, the specific cross-sensory phenomenon of synesthesia is more characteristic of classical hallucinogens like LSD.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Synesthesia (the crossing or merging of sensory modalities) is a characteristic effect of hallucinogenic drugs, particularly LSD. This perceptual phenomenon, where stimuli in one sensory domain trigger experiences in another (like seeing sounds or tasting colors), is part of the profound alterations in consciousness that make LSD and similar substances powerful hallucinogens.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Pediatric Assessment Triangle? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Heart Rate

 

Explanation: 

 

The Pediatric Assessment Triangle (PAT) is a rapid visual assessment tool used in pediatric emergencies that consists of exactly three components. These components allow for quick evaluation without touching the patient or using equipment. Heart rate is not part of the PAT as it cannot be visually assessed and requires physical examination with a stethoscope or monitoring equipment. Heart rate is instead evaluated during the subsequent hands-on assessment after the initial PAT is completed.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. General Appearance - This is a correct component of the PAT. It includes assessment of the child's tone, interactivity, consolability, look/gaze, and speech/cry to rapidly determine the child's overall status and level of distress.

 

Option B. Breathing Effort - This is a correct component of the PAT. It involves assessment of airway patency and breathing adequacy through observation of positioning, retractions, flaring, and audible breathing sounds.

 

Option C. Skin Circulation - This is a correct component of the PAT. It involves visual assessment of skin color (pale, mottled, cyanotic) and overall perfusion without touching the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Pediatric Assessment Triangle is a rapid visual assessment tool consisting of only three components: general appearance, breathing effort, and circulation to skin - allowing for immediate categorization of severity and type of illness without equipment or physical contact.

choices.text: Weight for height <3 SD of WHO Standard
Height for Age <2 SD of WHO Standard

questions.text: Severe Acute Malnutrition is defined by all of the following criteria, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Height for Age <2 SD of WHO Standard 

 

Explanation: 

 

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) is defined by specific anthropometric and clinical criteria. According to the WHO classification, SAM includes weight for height <-3 SD (severe wasting), mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) <11.5 cm (<115 mm) in children 6-59 months, and bilateral pitting edema (kwashiorkor) regardless of anthropometric measurements. Height for age <-2 SD defines stunting, which is a marker of chronic malnutrition rather than acute malnutrition, making it not a criterion for SAM diagnosis.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Mid-Upper-Arm Circumference <115mm - This is a correct criterion for SAM diagnosis. MUAC <11.5 cm indicates severe acute malnutrition in children aged 6-59 months and is a simple field measurement tool.

 

Option B. Weight for height <3 SD of WHO Standard - This is a correct criterion for SAM, indicating severe wasting. It reflects acute weight loss or failure to gain weight relative to height.

 

Option D. Bilateral Pitting Edema - This is a correct criterion for SAM diagnosis regardless of anthropometric measurements. It indicates kwashiorkor, a form of SAM characterized by protein deficiency leading to fluid retention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) is diagnosed by weight for height <-3 SD, MUAC <11.5 cm, or bilateral pitting edema, while stunting (height for age <-2 SD) reflects chronic malnutrition and is not part of SAM diagnostic criteria.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Kwashiorkor is not true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. All Skin and Bone Appearance

 

Explanation: 

 

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition primarily due to protein deficiency while maintaining relatively adequate caloric intake. The "all skin and bone appearance" is characteristic of marasmus, not kwashiorkor. Children with kwashiorkor typically have edema that masks the muscle wasting, giving them a falsely "plump" appearance. They have a distended abdomen, edema (especially of the feet and legs), and fatty liver due to decreased lipoprotein production and transport.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Moaning Cry - This is a true feature of kwashiorkor. Children with kwashiorkor often have a characteristic plaintive, moaning cry due to general irritability and weakness.

 

Option B. Red-Haired Boy - This is a true feature. Kwashiorkor causes depigmentation of hair, leading to reddish or yellowish discoloration (flag sign), particularly noticeable in children with naturally dark hair.

 

Option C. Mosaic Dermatitis - This is a true feature of kwashiorkor. Also called "flaky paint dermatosis," the skin develops patches that crack and peel, particularly in areas exposed to repeated friction or pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kwashiorkor is characterized by edema, red/blonde hair discoloration, irritability, and mosaic dermatosis, while the "all skin and bone" appearance is typical of marasmus due to calorie deficiency with relative sparing of protein.

choices.text: This infant is achieving desired target oxygen saturation.
Supplemental oxygen should be given at 100% concentration.

questions.text: A term infant has a preductal oxygen saturation of 85%, 5 minutes after birth. Which of the following is true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. This infant is achieving desired target oxygen saturation. 

 

Explanation: 

 

Normal oxygen saturation in newborns follows a predictable pattern after birth as the transition from fetal to neonatal circulation occurs. According to neonatal resuscitation guidelines, the preductal oxygen saturation (measured at right hand) at 5 minutes of life should be between 80-85%. The target ranges progress from 60-65% at 1 minute, 65-70% at 2 minutes, 70-75% at 3 minutes, 75-80% at 4 minutes, 80-85% at 5 minutes, and 85-95% at 10 minutes. Therefore, a preductal oxygen saturation of 85% at 5 minutes is within the normal range for a newborn and does not require intervention.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Oxygen supplementation is necessary - Incorrect. Supplemental oxygen is not needed when SpO2 is within normal range for age in minutes. Unnecessary oxygen can cause hyperoxemia and oxidative stress.

 

Option B. Cyanotic heart disease is suspected - Incorrect. This oxygen level is normal for a 5-minute-old infant, not suggestive of congenital heart disease. PaO2 <100mmHg despite 100% oxygen for 10-15 minutes - hyperoxia test fail suggesting cyanotic heart disease is likely.

 

Option D. Supplemental oxygen should be given at 100% concentration - Incorrect. Not only is supplemental oxygen unnecessary at this saturation, but 100% oxygen is no longer recommended in neonatal resuscitation except in specific circumstances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal oxygen saturation in newborns rises gradually after birth, with 80-85% being the normal target range at 5 minutes of life. Understanding these normal transitional physiology values prevents unnecessary oxygen administration.

questions.text: Which virus is the most common cause of croup in children? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Parainfluenza 

 

Explanation: 

 

Parainfluenza virus (especially types 1 and 2) is the most common cause of croup in children, accounting for approximately 75% of all cases. Croup, also known as laryngotracheobronchitis, is characterized by barky cough, hoarseness, and inspiratory stridor resulting from inflammation and narrowing of the subglottic area. Parainfluenza virus causes inflammation and edema of the larynx, trachea, and bronchi, with the narrowest portion of the pediatric airway (subglottic region) being particularly affected.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) - Incorrect. RSV is the leading cause of bronchiolitis in children under 2 years of age, but it is not the primary causative agent of croup. RSV affects the lower respiratory tract, causing inflammation of the small airways (bronchioles).

 

Option B. Influenza - Incorrect. While influenza can cause croup-like symptoms, it is not the most common viral cause. Influenza typically causes more systemic symptoms like high fever, myalgia, and fatigue in addition to respiratory symptoms.

 

Option D. Streptococcus Pneumoniae - Incorrect. This is a bacterium, not a virus. Streptococcus pneumoniae is a major cause of bacterial pneumonia, otitis media, and sinusitis, but not typically associated with croup, which is predominantly viral in etiology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parainfluenza virus is the most common cause of viral croup in children, typically presenting with the classic triad of barky cough, inspiratory stridor, and hoarseness, with symptoms often worsening at night.

questions.text: Hecht's Pneumonia is typically associated with which of the following infections? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Measles 

 

Explanation: 

 

Hecht's pneumonia refers to the giant cell pneumonia that occurs as a complication of measles infection. It is characterized by the presence of multinucleated giant cells (Warthin-Finkeldey cells) in the lung tissue, which are pathognomonic for measles. This form of pneumonia represents a serious complication of measles and is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Measles virus directly infects the respiratory epithelium, leading to necrosis and the formation of these characteristic giant cells in the lungs.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Malaria - Incorrect. Malaria is a parasitic infection caused by Plasmodium species transmitted by mosquitoes. While it can cause pulmonary complications (particularly P. falciparum), it does not cause Hecht's pneumonia or the formation of multinucleated giant cells in the lungs.

 

Option C. RSV - Incorrect. Respiratory Syncytial Virus causes bronchiolitis and pneumonia, especially in young children, but is not associated with Hecht's pneumonia or giant cell formation. RSV typically causes inflammation of the bronchioles with mucus plugging and epithelial cell necrosis.

 

Option D. Pneumococcus - Incorrect. Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common bacterial cause of community-acquired pneumonia in all age groups, but causes a lobar pneumonia pattern with neutrophilic infiltration, not giant cell pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hecht's pneumonia (giant cell pneumonia) is a specific and severe complication of measles infection, characterized by the pathognomonic Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells in lung tissue, and represents one of the serious complications that can occur with measles.

questions.text: Round pneumonia is most commonly associated with which of the following? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Streptococcal pneumonia 

 

Explanation: 

 

Round pneumonia is a distinct radiological pattern of pneumonia that appears as a round or oval opacity on chest imaging, mimicking a mass lesion. It is most commonly associated with Streptococcal pneumonia (Streptococcus pneumoniae infection). This presentation is particularly common in children under 8 years of age due to the lack of development of complete interlobular septae and pores of Kohn, which allows infection to spread more uniformly in a centrifugal pattern rather than respecting anatomical boundaries. Round pneumonia typically resolves completely with appropriate antibiotic therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kerosene oil aspiration - Incorrect. Kerosene aspiration typically causes chemical pneumonitis with bilateral infiltrates, often with a predominantly basal distribution. It does not present as round pneumonia but rather as diffuse or patchy infiltrates.

 

Option C. Lung cancer - Incorrect. While lung cancer can present as a round mass on imaging, this is not classified as round pneumonia. Round pneumonia is an infectious process that resolves with antibiotics, unlike malignant lesions.

 

Option D. Mendelson syndrome - Incorrect. This refers to chemical pneumonitis caused by aspiration of acidic gastric contents. It typically presents with bilateral infiltrates in dependent lung zones, not as a solitary round opacity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Round pneumonia is a distinct radiological presentation most commonly caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae infection in children, appearing as a well-defined round opacity that may mimic a tumor but resolves completely with appropriate antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: Which congenital heart disease is most commonly associated with Down's Syndrome? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Atrioventricular Septal Defect (AVSD)

 

Explanation: 

 

Atrioventricular Septal Defect (AVSD), also known as endocardial cushion defect or atrioventricular canal defect, is the most commonly associated congenital heart defect in Down syndrome (Trisomy 21). About 40-60% of children with Down syndrome have congenital heart disease, and AVSD is the most specific cardiac anomaly, accounting for approximately 30-40% of these cardiac defects. AVSD occurs due to failure of proper development of the endocardial cushions, which are essential for the formation of the lower portion of the atrial septum, the upper portion of the ventricular septum, and the mitral and tricuspid valves.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) - Incorrect. While PDA can occur in Down syndrome, it is not the most common or specific cardiac defect associated with the condition. PDA represents failure of the fetal connection between the aorta and pulmonary artery to close after birth.

 

Option B. Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) - Incorrect. Ostium secundum ASD is common in Down syndrome but not as specific or prevalent as AVSD. The ostium primum type of ASD is actually part of the AVSD spectrum.

 

Option C. Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) - Incorrect. TOF occurs in approximately 6-8% of Down syndrome patients with cardiac defects but is not the most common cardiac anomaly in this population. TOF is more commonly associated with 22q11 deletion syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrioventricular Septal Defect (AVSD) is the most common and specific congenital heart defect in Down syndrome, affecting approximately 30-40% of patients with cardiac anomalies due to abnormal development of the endocardial cushions.

questions.text: At what age does the kidney typically attain adult-level Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR)? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. 1-2 years 

 

Explanation: The Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) increases rapidly after birth as the kidneys mature. At birth, the GFR is significantly lower than adult values, typically around 15-20 ml/min/1.73m². During the first few weeks of life, GFR increases dramatically, reaching approximately 50% of adult values by 1-2 weeks of age. By 1-2 years of age, the GFR reaches adult levels of approximately 100-120 ml/min/1.73m². This rapid maturation reflects the postnatal development of renal blood flow, increased filtration surface area, and improved filtration pressure.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Birth - Incorrect. At birth, the GFR is only about 15-20% of adult values. The kidneys are still immature with limited filtration capacity, which is why newborns have limited ability to concentrate urine and excrete waste products.

 

Option C. 2-5 years - Incorrect. This is too late, as adult levels of GFR are already achieved by 1-2 years of age. By 2-5 years, kidney function has been at adult levels for some time.

 

Option D. Puberty - Incorrect. This is much too late. Adult-level GFR is reached many years before puberty. At puberty, the kidneys have long been functioning at adult capacity in terms of filtration rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal function matures rapidly during infancy, with GFR reaching adult levels by 1-2 years of age.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines was withdrawn due to an increased risk of intussusception? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Rotavirus Vaccine 

 

Explanation: 

 

The first licensed rotavirus vaccine (RotaShield) was withdrawn from the market in 1999 due to an increased risk of intussusception. Intussusception is a condition where one segment of intestine telescopes into another segment, causing intestinal obstruction. The original RotaShield vaccine showed an association with intussusception at a rate of approximately 1 case per 10,000 vaccinated infants, with most cases occurring within 1 week of the first dose. This led to its voluntary withdrawal. Newer rotavirus vaccines (RotaTeq and Rotarix) were subsequently developed and have a much lower risk of intussusception (approximately 1-5 cases per 100,000 vaccinated infants).

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. MMR (Measles, Mumps, and Rubella) - Incorrect. The MMR vaccine has never been withdrawn from the market. While it has faced controversy due to a now-retracted publication suggesting a link to autism, this claim has been thoroughly disproven by multiple large studies, and MMR remains an essential component of childhood immunization programs.

 

Option C. JE Vaccine (Japanese Encephalitis) - Incorrect. The JE vaccine has not been withdrawn due to intussusception. Some older versions had higher rates of adverse effects, but these were primarily allergic reactions, not intussusception.

 

Option D. Polio Vaccine - Incorrect. The oral polio vaccine (OPV) has been replaced by the inactivated polio vaccine (IPV) in many countries, but this was due to the rare risk of vaccine-associated paralytic poliomyelitis (VAPP), not intussusception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The original rotavirus vaccine (RotaShield) was withdrawn due to an increased risk of intussusception.

questions.text: Complete heart block in Neonatal Lupus is associated with which maternal autoantibodies? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Anti-Ro 

 

Explanation: 

 

Complete congenital heart block in neonatal lupus erythematosus (NLE) is strongly associated with maternal anti-Ro (SSA) antibodies. These autoantibodies cross the placenta during pregnancy and can affect the developing fetal cardiac conduction system, particularly the atrioventricular (AV) node. The maternal anti-Ro antibodies can cause inflammation and subsequent fibrosis of the fetal cardiac conduction system, resulting in complete heart block. The risk of developing congenital heart block is approximately 2% in anti-Ro positive mothers, but increases to about 15-20% if there is a previous child with neonatal lupus. Anti-La (SSB) antibodies often coexist with anti-Ro and may increase the risk.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Anti-RNP - Incorrect. While anti-RNP antibodies are found in mothers with mixed connective tissue disease and SLE, they are not specifically associated with congenital heart block in neonatal lupus.

 

Option C. Anti-ds-DNA - Incorrect. Anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies are highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus in mothers but are not the primary antibodies associated with congenital heart block in the fetus.

 

Option D. Anti-Sm - Incorrect. Anti-Smith antibodies are highly specific for SLE diagnosis in mothers but are not specifically linked to congenital heart block in neonatal lupus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maternal anti-Ro (SSA) antibodies are specifically associated with congenital complete heart block in neonatal lupus, requiring careful monitoring of the fetal heart rate during pregnancy in anti-Ro positive mothers, especially those with a previous affected child.

questions.text: What is the maximum score that can be achieved in the New Ballard Score? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. 50 

 

Explanation: 

 

The New Ballard Score (also called the Expanded New Ballard Score) is a clinical assessment tool used to determine gestational age in newborns. It evaluates both neuromuscular and physical maturity criteria. The score consists of six neuromuscular criteria (posture, square window, arm recoil, popliteal angle, scarf sign, and heel to ear) and six physical maturity criteria (skin, lanugo, plantar surface, breast, eye/ear, and genitalia). A total possible range is from -10 to +50 points. Thus, the maximum achievable score is 50, which corresponds to a gestational age of approximately 44 weeks.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. 30 - Incorrect. This is below the maximum possible score. A score of 30 would correspond to a gestational age of approximately 36-38 weeks.

 

Option B. 40 - Incorrect. This is below the maximum possible score. A score of 40 would correspond to a gestational age of approximately 40-42 weeks.

 

Option D. 60 - Incorrect. This exceeds the maximum possible score for the New Ballard Score. The highest possible score is 50 points.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The New Ballard Score has a maximum value of 50 points, which corresponds to a post-term infant of approximately 44 weeks gestational age. This scoring system allows for assessment of premature infants as young as 20 weeks gestational age (score of -10).

questions.text: According to the Lund-Browder Chart, which body region's surface area percentage remains constant across all age groups? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Arm

 

Explanation: 

 

The Lund-Browder chart is used to calculate the percentage of total body surface area (TBSA) involved in burns and is specifically modified for children to account for the changing body proportions with age. According to this chart, the arm (including both anterior and posterior surfaces) consistently accounts for 9% of the total body surface area regardless of age. This percentage remains constant from birth through adulthood, making it a stable reference point when calculating burn surface area across different age groups.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Head - Incorrect. The head's surface area percentage changes dramatically with age. It accounts for approximately 19% of TBSA in infants but decreases to about 9% in adults as the body grows and proportions change.

 

Option B. Thigh - Incorrect. The thigh's surface area percentage increases with age. In infants, each thigh (anterior and posterior together) accounts for about 5.5% of TBSA, which increases to about 9.5% in adults.

 

Option C. Leg - Incorrect. The leg's surface area percentage also changes with age, increasing slightly from infancy (5%) to adulthood (7%) as the lower extremities become proportionally longer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When using the Lund-Browder chart for burn assessment in pediatric patients, the arm surface area remains constant at 9% throughout all age groups, while head and lower extremity percentages change significantly with age.

questions.text: The classical triad of Congenital Rubella Syndrome includes all of the following, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Mental Retardation

 

Explanation: 

 

The classical triad of Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS) consists of cataract, deafness, and congenital heart defects (particularly Patent Ductus Arteriosus). This triad represents the most characteristic manifestations of maternal rubella infection during pregnancy, especially when infection occurs during the first trimester. While mental retardation can occur in children with CRS, it is not part of the classical diagnostic triad but rather an additional manifestation that may be present in severe cases.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cataract - Correct component of the CRS triad. Cataracts are typically bilateral but can be unilateral and develop from damage to the developing lens during embryogenesis.

 

Option B. Deafness - Correct component of the CRS triad. Sensorineural hearing loss is the most common manifestation of CRS, affecting up to 80% of infected infants.

 

Option C. Heart Defects - Correct component of the CRS triad. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common cardiac defect, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis and ventricular septal defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic triad of Congenital Rubella Syndrome consists of cataracts, deafness, and congenital heart defects (primarily PDA). Additional manifestations may include microcephaly, mental retardation, purpuric rash ("blueberry muffin" appearance), hepatosplenomegaly, and intrauterine growth restriction.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not cause conductive hearing loss? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endolymphatic Hydrops

 

Explanation:


Endolymphatic hydrops is the pathological condition underlying Ménière's disease. It involves an excessive accumulation of endolymph in the inner ear's membranous labyrinth, particularly affecting the cochlea. This condition causes sensorineural hearing loss (not conductive) because it affects the sensory hair cells in the cochlea. The hearing loss in Ménière's disease is typically fluctuating and predominantly affects the lower frequencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otosclerosis: This condition causes conductive hearing loss. Otosclerosis involves abnormal bone formation around the stapes footplate, leading to its fixation in the oval window. This prevents normal transmission of sound vibrations from the middle ear to the inner ear, resulting in conductive hearing loss of up to 60 dB.

 

Option B. Serous otitis media: This condition causes conductive hearing loss. Also known as otitis media with effusion, it involves accumulation of non-purulent fluid in the middle ear space. This fluid impedes the movement of the tympanic membrane and ossicular chain, resulting in conductive hearing loss typically ranging from 20-40 dB.

 

Option D. Suppurative otitis media: This condition causes conductive hearing loss. Acute or chronic suppurative otitis media involves infection of the middle ear with purulent discharge. The presence of pus in the middle ear and/or perforation of the tympanic membrane interferes with sound transmission, resulting in conductive hearing loss.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Endolymphatic hydrops (Ménière's disease) is an inner ear disorder causing sensorineural hearing loss, while conditions affecting the external or middle ear (otosclerosis, otitis media) cause conductive hearing loss by interfering with the mechanical transmission of sound to the inner ear.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient presents with an extremely painful lesion in the external ear accompanied by otorrhea that has not responded to antibiotics. Granulation tissue is observed in the external ear, and there is evidence of bony erosion along with facial nerve palsy. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malignant Otitis Externa

 

Explanation:


The clinical presentation strongly indicates Malignant Otitis Externa (MOE), also known as necrotizing otitis externa. Key diagnostic features present in this case include: extreme pain in the external ear, otorrhea unresponsive to antibiotics, presence of granulation tissue in the external ear canal, bony erosion, facial nerve palsy, and importantly, a diabetic patient. MOE is primarily caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection and occurs most commonly in elderly diabetic patients or immunocompromised individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma: This typically presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, conductive hearing loss due to eustachian tube dysfunction, and cranial nerve palsies (particularly CN V and VI) from skull base invasion. Primary symptoms would be in the nasopharynx rather than the external ear, and there would not be granulation tissue in the external ear canal.

 

Option C. Chronic suppurative otitis media: This involves a long-standing infection of the middle ear with tympanic membrane perforation and persistent discharge. While it can cause bone erosion and complications like facial palsy, it wouldn't present with granulation tissue in the external ear canal as the primary site of disease is the middle ear. The extreme pain described is also more characteristic of MOE.

 

Option D. Acute suppurative otitis media: This is an acute infection of the middle ear presenting with otalgia, fever, and sometimes otorrhea if the tympanic membrane ruptures. It doesn't cause bony erosion or facial nerve palsy in its typical presentation, and would generally respond to appropriate antibiotic therapy, unlike the case described.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Malignant otitis externa should be strongly suspected in elderly diabetic patients presenting with severe otalgia, otorrhea unresponsive to therapy, granulation tissue in the ear canal, and complications like facial nerve palsy or evidence of bony erosion.

questions.text: Infections of the middle ear can extend to the brain through all of the following routes, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Spread through Lymphatic Channels

 

Explanation:

 

Middle ear infections do not spread to the brain through lymphatic channels because there are no lymphatic connections between the middle ear and intracranial structures. The brain and cranial cavity lack a traditional lymphatic system. Infection from the middle ear to the brain occurs through other routes including direct bone erosion, preformed pathways, or hematogenous spread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct Bony Invasion: This is a common route of intracranial spread of middle ear infection. Cholesteatoma or chronic infection can erode the tegmen tympani (roof of middle ear), allowing infection to spread to the middle cranial fossa causing extradural or subdural abscess. Similarly, erosion of the posterior wall can lead to cerebellar abscess.

 

Option B. Oval or Round Window: These are preformed pathways through which infection can spread from the middle ear to the inner ear (labyrinthitis), and then to the internal auditory canal and cerebellopontine angle through the cochlear aqueduct or internal auditory canal. The subarachnoid space can be accessed through the cochlear aqueduct, which connects the scala tympani with the subarachnoid space.

 

Option C. Spread via Bloodstream: Hematogenous spread is another valid route where infection spreads through venous channels, particularly through emissary veins or by thrombophlebitis of the sigmoid sinus. This can lead to lateral sinus thrombosis, meningitis, or brain abscess.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While middle ear infections can spread to intracranial structures through direct bone erosion, preformed pathways (oval/round windows), and bloodstream, there is no lymphatic route for such spread since the brain lacks traditional lymphatics.

choices.text: Cochlear implants lead to improved speech and sound perception.
Cochlear implants offer a better chance of acquiring normal or near-normal verbal skills.
Cochlear implants improve sound localization and discrimination.
Cochlear implants increase tinnitus in patients who had tinnitus before implantation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about cochlear implants is not true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cochlear implants increase tinnitus in patients who had tinnitus before implantation.

 

Explanation:


Cochlear implants do not increase tinnitus in patients who had tinnitus before implantation. In fact, the opposite is true - cochlear implants often help reduce tinnitus in most patients who experience it prior to implantation. The electrical stimulation provided by the implant can mask or suppress the tinnitus sensation. Studies show that cochlear implantation can reduce or even eliminate pre-existing tinnitus in approximately 70-80% of cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cochlear implants lead to improved speech and sound perception: This statement is true. Cochlear implants bypass damaged hair cells in the cochlea and directly stimulate the auditory nerve, allowing for improved detection and discrimination of sounds. This leads to enhanced speech perception and better understanding of environmental sounds.

 

Option B. Cochlear implants offer a better chance of acquiring normal or near-normal verbal skills: This statement is true, especially for children who receive implants early. Early implantation (before 6 years of age in pre-lingual deaf children) allows for better development of auditory pathways and improved chances of developing age-appropriate speech and language skills.

 

Option C. Cochlear implants improve sound localization and discrimination: This statement is true. Cochlear implants help improve sound discrimination abilities, allowing recipients to better distinguish between different sounds. Bilateral implantation particularly improves sound localization abilities by providing binaural cues necessary for spatial hearing.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Contrary to increasing tinnitus, cochlear implants typically reduce or suppress pre-existing tinnitus in most patients due to the masking effect of electrical stimulation and reorganization of central auditory pathways following implantation.

questions.text: Which of the following tumors arises from the olfactory nasal mucosa? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Esthesioneuroblastoma

 

Explanation:


Esthesioneuroblastoma, also called olfactory neuroblastoma, specifically arises from the olfactory epithelium in the upper third of the nasal cavity. It is also known as olfactory placode tumor, highlighting its origin from the specialized olfactory mucosa. This tumor typically presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis, and can invade surrounding structures including the orbit and intracranial cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasal Glioma: This is a congenital lesion that represents entrapped neural tissue during embryonic development. It doesn't arise from the olfactory mucosa but is a developmental anomaly. Nasal gliomas are typically seen in infants and children and may be extranasal (60%), intranasal (30%) or both (10%).

 

Option B. Adenoid cystic carcinoma: This tumor arises from the glands of the mucous membrane or minor salivary glands, rather than from the olfactory epithelium. It typically involves the upper part of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity but is not derived from olfactory tissue.

 

Option C. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma: This tumor originates from the epithelial lining of the nasopharynx, not from the olfactory mucosa in the nasal cavity. It arises from a completely different anatomical site.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Esthesioneuroblastoma is a distinctive neoplasm that uniquely originates from the specialized olfactory epithelium in the upper nasal cavity, making it the only true tumor of olfactory mucosal origin among the options provided.

questions.text: An elderly male presents with a history of dysphagia, regurgitation, foul breath, and cough. Bilateral lung crepitations are noted on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zenker's Diverticulum

 

Explanation:


Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum that occurs when pharyngeal mucosa herniates through Killian's dehiscence (a weak area between the two parts of the inferior constrictor muscle). This condition typically affects elderly individuals, particularly those over 60 years. The clinical presentation in this case is classic: dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), regurgitation of undigested food, halitosis (foul breath), and cough with evidence of aspiration pneumonia (bilateral lung crepitations).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schatzki Ring: This is a circumferential narrowing at the gastroesophageal junction that typically causes intermittent dysphagia for solids only. It would not explain the regurgitation, halitosis, or respiratory symptoms seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Corkscrew Esophagus: This refers to diffuse esophageal spasm with non-peristaltic contractions of the esophagus. While it can cause dysphagia and chest pain, it doesn't lead to regurgitation, halitosis, or aspiration pneumonia.

 

Option D. Plummer-Vinson Syndrome: This is characterized by a triad of dysphagia, iron-deficiency anemia, and esophageal webs. It predominantly affects middle-aged women, not elderly men, and doesn't typically cause regurgitation, foul breath, or aspiration pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, halitosis, and respiratory complications due to aspiration in an elderly patient strongly points to Zenker's diverticulum. Food collects in the pouch and can later be regurgitated, causing aspiration pneumonia.

choices.text: It is the most common congenital anomaly of the larynx.
It is associated with an omega-shaped epiglottis.
Stridor is increased on crying and relieved on lying prone.
Surgical Tracheostomy is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Laryngomalacia is not true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Surgical Tracheostomy is the treatment of choice.

 

Explanation:


Laryngomalacia is primarily managed conservatively, with observation being the mainstay of treatment. Tracheostomy is only required in select cases with severe respiratory obstruction, not as the first-line or treatment of choice. The condition typically resolves by 2 years of age as the laryngeal cartilages become more rigid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the most common congenital anomaly of the larynx: This is true. Laryngomalacia is indeed the most common congenital abnormality of the larynx.

 

Option B. It is associated with an omega-shaped epiglottis: This is true. Direct laryngoscopy findings include elongated epiglottis curled upon itself (omega-shaped Ω), floppy aryepiglottic folds and prominent arytenoids.

 

Option C. Stridor is increased on crying and relieved on lying prone: This is true. Stridor increases on crying but subsides when the child is placed in prone position. This clinical feature is characteristic of laryngomalacia and helps in its diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital laryngeal anomaly characterized by flaccid supraglottic structures causing inspiratory stridor that worsens with crying and improves in prone position; it typically resolves spontaneously by age 2 with conservative management being the mainstay of treatment, while tracheostomy is reserved only for severe cases.

choices.text: It is a dystonia of the laryngeal muscles.
Standard treatment is with injection of Botulinum Toxin.
Multiple injections of Botulinum toxin are required.
Patients with Abductor Type Dysphonia have a strained and strangled voice.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about spasmodic dysphonia is not true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Patients with Abductor Type Dysphonia have a strained and strangled voice.

 

Explanation:


This statement is incorrect because patients with Abductor Type Dysphonia actually present with a breathy voice or breathy breaks in voice, not a strained and strangled voice. The strained or strangled voice quality with phonation interruptions and voice breaks is characteristic of Adductor Dysphonia, where the adductor muscles of the larynx go into spasm causing vocal cords to adduct excessively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a dystonia of the laryngeal muscles. This is true. Spasmodic dysphonia involves abnormal muscular contractions (spasms) of the laryngeal muscles during speech. The condition can involve either adductor or abductor muscles, causing different voice patterns.
