Option B. Standard treatment is with injection of Botulinum Toxin. This is true. Botulinum toxin injections are the standard treatment for both adductor and abductor spasmodic dysphonia. In adductor type, injections target the thyroarytenoid muscle, while in abductor type, the posterior cricoarytenoid muscles are injected.

 

Option C. Multiple injections of Botulinum toxin are required. This is true. The benefit of botulinum toxin injections typically lasts only up to 16 weeks, after which repeat injections are needed. This makes it a recurring treatment rather than a one-time solution.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Adductor and Abductor spasmodic dysphonias present with distinctly different voice qualities - strained/strangled in adductor type versus breathy in abductor type - though both are treated with botulinum toxin injections that require periodic repetition due to their temporary effect.

choices.text: Prevention of scar tissue formation in Laryngotracheal stenosis

questions.text: Topical application of Mitomycin C is commonly used in the treatment of which condition? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prevention of scar tissue formation in Laryngotracheal stenosis

 

Explanation:


Mitomycin-C is used post-operatively in laryngotracheal reconstruction to prevent adhesions and fibrosis. In the treatment of subglottic stenosis, after procedures such as laryngotracheal reconstruction with cartilage grafts or resection of stenosed segments, Mitomycin-C is specifically applied to prevent scar tissue formation that could lead to recurrent stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoscopic management of Angiofibroma: This is incorrect. Mitomycin-C is not used in the management of angiofibroma. These tumors are typically managed with surgical excision, preoperative embolization, or radiation in some cases.

 

Option B. Management of Sturge-Weber syndrome: This is incorrect. Mitomycin-C is not used for Sturge-Weber syndrome. This vascular condition typically requires different management approaches.

 

Option C. Treatment of Skull base osteomyelitis: This is incorrect. Skull base osteomyelitis treatment typically involves long-term antibiotics and sometimes surgical debridement, but Mitomycin-C application is not part of the standard treatment protocol.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mitomycin-C is an antifibrotic agent applied topically during laryngotracheal procedures to inhibit fibroblast proliferation and prevent adhesions and stenosis formation, making it particularly valuable in the management of laryngotracheal stenosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not another name for an inverted papilloma of the nose? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Juvenile papilloma

 

Explanation:


Juvenile papilloma is not a recognized alternative name for inverted papilloma of the nose. Inverted papilloma is a distinctive tumor of the nasal cavity that grows in an inverted fashion, with hyperplastic papillomatous tissue growing into the stroma rather than in an exophytic manner. It most commonly arises from the lateral wall of the nose in the middle meatus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transitional cell papilloma: This is a correct alternative name for inverted papilloma. The term relates to the transitional epithelium that lines the tumor.

 

Option B. Ringertz tumor: This is indeed another name for inverted papilloma, named after the pathologist who described its characteristic inverted growth pattern.

 

Option C. Schneiderian papilloma: This is a valid alternative name for inverted papilloma, referring to its origin from the Schneiderian membrane (the non-olfactory mucosa of the nose).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Inverted papilloma is known by several names including transitional cell papilloma, Ringertz tumor, and Schneiderian papilloma, reflecting its histological features and growth pattern, but juvenile papilloma is not among its recognized synonyms.

questions.text: The extra layer of skin found in the epidermis of the palms and soles is: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stratum Lucidum.

 

  • Stratum lucidum is the extra layer of epidermis that is specifically located over palms and soles. 
  • This layer is characterized by its translucency (lucidum refers to translucency) and contains Eleidin granules. 
  • The stratum lucidum is positioned between the stratum granulosum and stratum corneum in the epidermal layers of palms and soles.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stratum Corneum:

 

  • This is the outermost layer of the epidermis, not an extra layer. 
  • It is present in all skin areas and consists of anucleate, fully keratinized flat cells forming the dead protective layer.

 

Option B. Stratum Granulosum:

 

  • This layer contains keratohyaline granules and lamellar granules (Odland bodies). 
  • It is present throughout the epidermis and is not an extra layer specific to palms and soles.

 

Option D. Stratum Spinosum:

 

  • Also known as the prickle cell layer, this contains polygonal keratinocytes connected by desmosomes.
  • It appears beneath the stratum granulosum throughout the epidermis and is not an additional layer specific to palms and soles.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The stratum lucidum is a distinct translucent epidermal layer found exclusively on palms and soles, positioned between the stratum granulosum and stratum corneum, containing eleidin granules.

questions.text: Which of the following is not related to sebaceous glands? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glands of Moll

 

  • Glands of Moll are modified apocrine glands, not sebaceous glands. 
  • They are located in the eyelids, specifically at the lid margin. 
  • The key distinction is their secretion method - apocrine glands secrete by a decapitation process where the apex of the cell is pinched off during secretion, unlike sebaceous glands which use holocrine secretion (whole cell disintegration).

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zeis Glands:

 

  • These are indeed sebaceous glands associated with the eyelids. 
  • They are connected to the follicles of eyelashes and produce sebum that lubricates the eyelashes.

 

Option B. Meibomian Glands:

 

  • These are Ectopic sebaceous glands embedded in the tarsal plates of eyelids. 
  • They secrete meibum, an oily substance that forms the outer layer of the tear film and prevents evaporation.

 

Option D. Fordyce Spots:

 

  • These are ectopic sebaceous glands (not associated with hair follicles) that appear as small yellowish papules on the upper lip, buccal mucosa, and other areas.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glands of Moll are modified apocrine glands in the eyelids with decapitation-type secretion, making them distinct from sebaceous glands, which use holocrine secretion and are represented by Zeis glands, Meibomian glands, and Fordyce spots.

questions.text: Tiny bleeding spots observed after the removal of deep scales in Plaque Psoriasis is known as: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auspitz Sign

 

  • Auspitz sign is a characteristic finding in psoriasis observed during a three-step process. 
  • First, lesions are gently scraped with a glass slide to accentuate the silvery scales (Grattage test). 

 

 

  • As scraping continues, a glistening white adherent membrane called Bulkley's membrane appears.
  • When this membrane is removed, punctate bleeding points become visible - this is the positive Auspitz sign. 

 

 

  • These bleeding points occur due to the dilated and tortuous capillary loops in the dermal papillae that become exposed after scale removal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hutchinson Sign:


 Hutchinson sign refers to two different entities depending on the context:

 

  1. In herpes zoster ophthalmicus, it indicates vesicular lesions on the tip of the nose, signaling nasociliary nerve involvement and a high risk of ocular complications.




     
  2. Subungual melanoma it refers to pigmentation extending onto the proximal or lateral nail folds, suggesting malignancy.

     

It has no association with tiny bleeding spots or plaque psoriasis and is not observed after removal of scales.

 

Option C. Dariers Sign:

 

  • Dariers sign is seen in mastocytosis or urticaria pigmentosa. 
  • It refers to the appearance of a wheal and erythema when a lesion is rubbed or stroked due to mast cell degranulation. 

 

 

 

Option D. Nikolsky Sign:

 

  • The Nikolsky sign is positive in conditions like pemphigus vulgaris, where acantholysis leads to intraepidermal cleavage. 

 

 

  • Rubbing normal-appearing skin causes the outer layers to slough off. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Auspitz sign is the appearance of tiny bleeding spots after removal of deep scales in plaque psoriasis due to exposure of dermal capillaries.

questions.text: Which glands can be involved in Bromhidrosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both Apocrine and Eccrine Glands

 

  • Bromhidrosis refers to offensive body odor originating from apocrine and eccrine sweat glands.
  • Specifically, bromhidrosis affects "Apocrine (Axilla) or Eccrine (Feet)" glands. 
  • While apocrine glands produce odorous secretions containing pheromones associated with body odor (particularly in axillary regions), eccrine glands can also be affected, especially on the feet. 
  • The interaction between sweat and bacteria on the skin surface leads to the breakdown of sweat components, resulting in malodorous compounds.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apocrine Sweat Glands only: 

 

  • While apocrine glands are commonly associated with body odor due to their secretions containing pheromones, bromhidrosis isn't limited to these glands alone. 
  • This would be correct if bromhidrosis only affected the axillary region.

 

Option B. Eccrine Sweat Glands only: 

 

  • Eccrine glands can cause bromhidrosis, particularly on the feet, but this option is incomplete since apocrine glands are also involved. 
  • This would be correct if bromhidrosis only affected the feet.

 

Option C. Sebaceous Glands: 

 

  • Sebaceous glands produce sebum through holocrine secretion and function to lubricate skin and hair. 
  • They aren't primarily responsible for bromhidrosis. 
  • These glands are associated with conditions like acne vulgaris rather than body odor.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Bromhidrosis (offensive body odor) can originate from both apocrine glands (primarily in axillary regions) and eccrine glands (commonly on feet), resulting from bacterial decomposition of sweat components on the skin surface.

questions.text: Contact dermatitis known as the ‘Scourge of India’ is caused by: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parthenium.

 

  • Parthenium hysterophorus (also known as congress grass or communist plant) is the causative agent for airborne contact dermatitis that has been referred to as the 'Scourge of India'. 

 

 

Scourge = A thing that causes great trouble or suffering

 

  • This plant releases sesquiterpene lactone (SQL) allergens into the air which settle onto exposed skin parts causing characteristic dermatitis patterns typically affecting the neck, upper eyelids, face, and V-areas of the chest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Detergents - This is incorrect. 

 

  • Detergents are common causes of irritant contact dermatitis rather than allergic contact dermatitis. 
  • They cause direct tissue damage through non-immunologic mechanisms and are not specifically associated with being called the 'Scourge of India'.

 

Option C. Nickel - This is incorrect. 

 

  • While nickel is the common cause of allergic contact dermatitis worldwide, it typically causes localized reactions at sites of direct contact with metal objects (like jewelry) 

 

Option D. Ragweed - This is incorrect. 

 

  • Ragweed is a common cause of respiratory allergies and allergic rhinitis but is not specifically identified as a major cause of contact dermatitis in India. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Parthenium hysterophorus causes airborne contact dermatitis predominantly affecting exposed areas like face and neck, and due to its widespread presence and significant impact on the population, it has earned the title 'Scourge of India'.

questions.text: Which antibodies are characterized against Mucocutaneous Pemphigus Vulgaris? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Desmoglein 1 and 3.

 

  • Mucocutaneous Pemphigus Vulgaris is characterized by antibodies against both Desmoglein 1 and Desmoglein 3. 

 

 

  • In Pemphigus vulgaris, the target antigens are "Desmoglein-3 > 1," which means both are involved but Desmoglein-3 is predominant. 
  • While mucosal-dominant PV has antibodies primarily against Desmoglein 3, mucocutaneous PV (affecting both skin and mucosa) requires antibodies to both Desmoglein 1 and 3. 
  • The presence of both antibodies explains the development of skin lesions in addition to oral involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Desmoglein 1: 

 

  • This is primarily the target antigen in Pemphigus foliaceus. When only anti-Dsg1 antibodies are present, they cause skin lesions without mucosal involvement. 
  • Isolated anti-Dsg1 antibodies cannot explain the mucocutaneous manifestation of PV.

 

Option B. Desmoglein 3: 

 

  • While anti-Dsg3 antibodies are predominant in Pemphigus vulgaris, having only anti-Dsg3 antibodies typically results in mucosal-dominant disease. 
  • Mucocutaneous PV requires both anti-Dsg1 and anti-Dsg3 antibodies.

 

Option D. None: 

 

  • Incorrect as Pemphigus vulgaris definitely has autoantibodies against desmogleins. The absence of anti-desmoglein antibodies would be inconsistent with the diagnosis of Pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mucocutaneous Pemphigus vulgaris requires antibodies against both Desmoglein 1 and 3, with Desmoglein-3 antibodies typically being predominant; this combined antibody profile explains the involvement of both skin and mucous membranes.

questions.text: The "Hanging Curtain Sign" is observed in which of the following conditions?  (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pityriasis Rosea.

 

  • The Hanging Curtain Sign is specifically associated with pityriasis rosea, particularly the herald patch. 
  • This sign is observed when stretching the skin along the long axis of the herald patch causes the scales to fold along the lines of stretch. 

 

 

  • This occurs because of the characteristic collarette scales found at the periphery of lesions in pityriasis rosea. 
  • These scales have their outer edge attached within the active margin of the lesion, while the inner edge remains free, allowing them to fold like a curtain when the skin is stretched.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Psoriasis - This is incorrect. 

 

  • Psoriasis has characteristic silvery white scales that are loosely attached. 
  • When scraped, psoriasis demonstrates Auspitz sign (pinpoint bleeding) rather than the Hanging Curtain Sign. 
  • Psoriatic scales are uniformly distributed over the lesion rather than arranged in a collarette pattern.

 

Option B. Lichen Planus - This is incorrect. 

 

  • Lichen Planus is characterized by flat-topped, polygonal, violaceous papules with minimal scaling. 
  • The characteristic sign of lichen planus is Wickham's striae (whitish lacy pattern on the surface of the papules) rather than the Hanging Curtain Sign.

 

Option D. Hordeolum externum - This is incorrect. 

 

  • Hordeolum externum (external stye) is an acute infection of the sebaceous glands of Zeis or apocrine glands of Moll at the eyelid margin. 

 

 

  • It presents as a localized, painful, erythematous swelling and does not feature any scaling that would demonstrate the Hanging Curtain Sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Hanging Curtain Sign is a characteristic feature of pityriasis rosea where stretching the herald patch causes the collarette scales to fold along the lines of stretch due to their unique attachment pattern with the outer edge attached and inner edge free.

questions.text: The "Carpet Tack Sign" is observed in which of the following conditions?  (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Discoid Lupus Erythematosus (DLE)

 

  • The Carpet Tack Sign (also called Tin Tack Sign or Cat Tongue Sign) is a characteristic finding in Discoid Lupus Erythematosus. 
  • When the adherent scale from a DLE lesion is removed, the undersurface shows keratotic spikes that have occupied the dilated pilosebaceous canals. 
  • This creates a pattern resembling the underside of a carpet tack.

 

 

  • DLE typically presents as well-demarcated, discoid erythematous plaques with adherent scales on sun-exposed areas like face, scalp, and ears. 
  • The lesions characteristically show follicular plugging, central scarring with depigmentation, and peripheral hyperpigmentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pityriasis Versicolor:

 

  • This is a superficial fungal infection caused by Malassezia species with fine scales that don't demonstrate the carpet tack sign. 

 

Option C. Psoriasis:

 

  • Though psoriasis has silvery scales, they are loose and don't adhere tightly to the skin. 
  • When removed, they show Auspitz sign (pinpoint bleeding) but not keratotic projections on the undersurface of scales.

 

Option D. Lichen Planus:

 

  • Features polygonal, flat-topped, violaceous papules with Wickham's striae. 
  • It doesn't typically have adherent scales that would demonstrate the carpet tack phenomenon.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The Carpet Tack Sign is pathognomonic for Discoid Lupus Erythematosus, where removal of adherent scales reveals keratotic projections on the undersurface that had occupied dilated follicular openings.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cutaneous manifestation of Dermatomyositis?  (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gorlin Sign

 

  • Gorlin sign is the ability of a person to touch the tip of their nose with their tongue.

 

 

  • This sign is a marker of generalized connective tissue laxity {Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS)}
  • Gorlin Sign is not a cutaneous manifestation of dermatomyositis. 

 

Dermatomyositis

 

  • The cutaneous manifestations of dermatomyositis include several characteristic signs, such as Gottron's papules (violaceous flat-topped papules over the knuckles), 
  • Gottron's sign (violaceous macular erythema over joints), 
  • Heliotrope rash (violaceous discoloration of the eyelids with edema), 
  • Mechanic's hands (hyperkeratotic fissuring involving tips and sides of digits), 

 

Distribution-based Dermatomyositis signs, including the 

 

  • Shawl sign (erythema over the upper back and shoulders), 
  • V-sign (erythema over the anterior chest)
  • Holster sign (erythema on the lateral aspect of the thighs).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shawl Sign:

 

  • This is a genuine manifestation of dermatomyositis, characterized by erythema over the upper back, shoulders, and posterior neck in a shawl-like distribution.

 

 

Option B. Heliotrope Rash:

 

  • This is a classic cutaneous feature of dermatomyositis. 
  • It presents as violaceous (lilac/purple) discoloration with edema of the periorbital region, named after the heliotrope flower, which has a similar violet color.

 

 

Option C. Mechanic's Hands:

 

  • This is a characteristic finding in dermatomyositis, characterized by hyperkeratotic fissuring involving the tips and sides of digits. 

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Dermatomyositis has several pathognomonic cutaneous manifestations, including Gottron's papules/sign, heliotrope rash, mechanic's hands, and distribution-specific patterns like the Shawl sign, V-sign, and Holster sign, but Gorlin sign is not among them.

questions.text: Bioavailability of an orally administered drug is best described as: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. AUC oral ÷ AUC intravenous × 100

 

Explanation:

 

Bioavailability refers to the fraction of administered dose of a drug that reaches the systemic circulation in the unchanged form. When calculating bioavailability of an orally administered drug, we compare its absorption to that of the same drug given intravenously (which has 100% bioavailability by definition).

 

The formula for bioavailability is: Bioavailability = AUC oral ÷ AUC intravenous × 100

 

This formula correctly expresses bioavailability as a percentage by comparing the area under the plasma concentration-time curve (AUC) of the oral formulation to the AUC of the intravenous formulation.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A (AUC intravenous ÷ AUC oral × 100) - is the inverse of the correct formula and would give values >100% for drugs with incomplete oral absorption.
  • Option C (AUC oral ÷ AUC intravenous) - gives the correct ratio but omits multiplication by 100, thus not expressing bioavailability as a percentage.
  • Option D (AUC intravenous ÷ Time) - does not compare oral and intravenous administration, and thus cannot measure bioavailability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bioavailability of an orally administered drug is calculated as the ratio of AUC oral to AUC intravenous multiplied by 100 to express it as a percentage.

questions.text: The Logarithmic Graded Dose Response Curve is typically: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Sigmoid

 

Explanation:

 

The Logarithmic Graded Dose Response Curve (Log DRC) is typically sigmoid (S-shaped) in nature. When the dose is plotted on a logarithmic scale rather than a linear scale, the hyperbolic dose-response relationship transforms into a sigmoid curve.

 

This sigmoid curve has three distinct regions:

  • An initial flat portion at low doses
  • A steep linear middle portion
  • A plateau at high doses where maximum effect is reached

 

The sigmoid shape of the Log DRC is clinically useful as it helps determine three important parameters:

  1. Potency (position on x-axis)
  2. Efficacy (maximum height of the curve)
  3. Slope (steepness of the middle portion)

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Hyperbolic- describes the standard dose-response curve when doses are plotted on a linear scale, not logarithmic scale.
  • Option B. Parabola - is not representative of dose-response relationships in pharmacology.
  • Option D. Gaussian - represents a normal distribution curve, not a dose-response relationship.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Log Dose Response Curve is sigmoid in shape, allowing better visualization of drug parameters like potency, efficacy, and the therapeutic range.

questions.text: Identify the correct agonist-antagonist pairing among the following adrenergic drugs: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Clonidine-Yohimbine

 

Explanation:

 

Clonidine is an α₂ adrenergic receptor agonist that acts as a "brake" for the sympathetic system and is used in hypertension. Yohimbine is a relatively selective α₂ adrenergic receptor antagonist. This makes them a correct agonist-antagonist pair acting on the same receptor subtype.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Phenylephrine-Yohimbine - Phenylephrine is a selective α₁ agonist used for mydriasis and vasoconstriction, while Yohimbine is an α₂ antagonist. They act on different receptor subtypes, so they don't form an agonist-antagonist pair for the same receptor.
  • Option B. Dobutamine-Ritodrine - Dobutamine primarily acts on β₁ receptors (cardiac stimulant for CHF), while Ritodrine is a β₂ agonist used as a tocolytic. Both are agonists acting on different receptor subtypes, not an agonist-antagonist pair.
  • Option D. Salbutamol-Atenolol - Salbutamol is a β₂ agonist used as a bronchodilator, while Atenolol is a selective β₁ antagonist. Though both are adrenergic drugs, they act on different receptor subtypes (β₂ vs β₁), so they don't constitute a proper agonist-antagonist pair for the same receptor.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A true agonist-antagonist pairing requires drugs that act on the same receptor subtype but with opposite effects - one activating (agonist) and the other blocking (antagonist) the same receptor.

choices.text: Rise followed by fall in blood pressure
Fall followed by rise in blood pressure

questions.text: What is the effect of adrenaline on blood pressure when administered after an alpha-receptor blockade? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Fall in blood pressure

 

Explanation:

 

When adrenaline is administered after alpha-receptor blockade, it causes a fall in blood pressure. This phenomenon is known as "vasomotor reversal of Dale." Alpha blockade prevents adrenaline's vasoconstrictive effects, leaving only its beta₂-mediated vasodilatory actions unopposed. This results in decreased peripheral resistance and hypotension.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Rise in blood pressure - Incorrect Normal adrenaline administration causes a rise in blood pressure through alpha₁ receptor-mediated vasoconstriction. However, when alpha receptors are blocked, this vasoconstrictive effect is abolished, and adrenaline cannot raise blood pressure.
  • Option C. Rise followed by fall in blood pressure - Incorrect This biphasic response describes the normal effect of high-dose intravenous adrenaline without alpha blockade. Initially, alpha effects predominate (vasoconstriction), followed by beta₂ effects (vasodilation). With alpha blockade already in place, only the fall in blood pressure occurs.
  • Option D. Fall followed by rise in blood pressure - Incorrect This pattern is not observed with adrenaline administration after alpha blockade. Once the beta₂-mediated vasodilation occurs, there is no mechanism for a subsequent rise in blood pressure as long as the alpha blockade persists.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha receptor blockade reverses adrenaline's typical pressor effect to a depressor effect by unmasking its beta₂-mediated vasodilatory action, demonstrating the "vasomotor reversal of Dale" phenomenon.

questions.text: All of the following are side effects of nitrates, EXCEPT: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Gastrointestinal disturbance

 

Explanation:

 

The adverse effects of nitrates are primarily related to their vasodilatory properties. These include fullness in head, throbbing headache, flushing, weakness, sweating, palpitation, dizziness and fainting. These symptoms occur due to postural hypotension and can be mitigated by lying down. Gastrointestinal disturbances are not characteristic side effects of nitrate therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Orthostatic hypotension - Postural (orthostatic) hypotension is a well-documented side effect of nitrates. Standing still and alcohol consumption can accentuate this effect due to enhanced peripheral pooling of blood.
  • Option B. Tachycardia - With large doses of nitrates and significant drops in mean blood pressure, reflex sympathetic stimulation occurs, leading to tachycardia and increased cardiac contractility. This can paradoxically increase cardiac work and potentially precipitate angina.
  • Option D. Tachyphylaxis - Tolerance (tachyphylaxis) to the hemodynamic and anti-ischemic effects of nitrates develops in a dose and duration-dependent manner when they are continuously present in the body. This tolerance wanes rapidly (within hours) when the body is free of the drug.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Nitrates produce side effects primarily related to vasodilation and can lead to tolerance with continuous use, but gastrointestinal disturbances are not characteristic of this drug class.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of Levosimendan? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Calcium Sensitizer

 

Explanation:

 

Levosimendan acts by sensitizing myocardial troponin C to calcium, which produces an inotropic effect without changing cytosolic calcium concentration. This mechanism allows for increased cardiac contractility even in patients receiving beta-blockers. It also opens ATP-sensitive potassium channels in vascular smooth muscle cells, causing vasodilation. Thus, it functions as an "inodilator," improving cardiac output while simultaneously reducing both preload and afterload.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Potassium Channel Opener - While levosimendan does open ATP-sensitive potassium channels in vascular smooth muscle, this is a secondary mechanism. Its primary therapeutic action is calcium sensitization in the myocardium.
  • Option C. Selective Myosin Activator - This describes the mechanism of omecamtiv mecarbil, which directly activates cardiac myosin to increase contractility without affecting calcium levels.
  • Option D. Na+-K+ ATPase Inhibitor - This mechanism belongs to cardiac glycosides like digoxin, which inhibit the sodium-potassium pump leading to increased intracellular calcium and enhanced contractility. Levosimendan does not affect Na+-K+ ATPase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Levosimendan provides inotropic support through calcium sensitization rather than increasing calcium concentrations, while also offering vasodilation through potassium channel activation - making it particularly valuable in acutely decompensated heart failure.

questions.text: Which of the following is a Cholesteryl Ester Transfer Protein (CETP) inhibitor used for the treatment of dyslipidemia? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Evacetrapib

 

Explanation:

 

Evacetrapib belongs to the class of Cholesteryl Ester Transfer Protein (CETP) inhibitors. CETP normally facilitates the exchange of cholesterol esters from HDL particles with triglycerides from VLDL and LDL particles. By inhibiting this protein, evacetrapib increases HDL-cholesterol levels, potentially enhancing reverse cholesterol transport - the process by which excess cholesterol is carried from peripheral tissues back to the liver for excretion.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Lomitapide - Lomitapide is a Microsomal Triglyceride Transfer Protein (MTP) inhibitor. MTP is essential for the assembly and secretion of VLDL in the liver. By inhibiting MTP, lomitapide reduces VLDL production and consequently lowers LDL levels.
  • Option B. Niacin - Niacin (Vitamin B3) is a traditional lipid-lowering agent that works through multiple mechanisms. While it has the highest HDL-raising potential among older agents and uniquely decreases Lipoprotein(a), it does not function by inhibiting CETP.
  • Option C. Mipomersen - Mipomersen is an antisense oligonucleotide that targets apolipoprotein B100 mRNA, reducing the production of all apoB100-containing lipoproteins including VLDL and LDL. It does not affect CETP activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CETP inhibitors like evacetrapib represent a mechanistically distinct approach to dyslipidemia management, specifically targeting the reverse cholesterol transport pathway to increase HDL levels rather than primarily focusing on LDL reduction. However evacetrapib could not get FDA approval as it does not provide a significant benefit over placebo in reducing cardiovascular events.

questions.text: All of the following are considered first-line drugs for the management of hypertension in patients with no other comorbidities, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Beta Blocker

 

Explanation:

 

Beta blockers are no longer considered first-line therapy for uncomplicated hypertension. They have been excluded from the list of first-line drugs due to their lower efficacy in primary prevention of myocardial infarction and stroke compared to other antihypertensive classes. Additional concerns include their unfavorable metabolic effects on lipid profiles and glucose tolerance, and negative impact on quality-of-life parameters including exercise capacity, fatigue, and cognitive function.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. ACE Inhibitor - ACE inhibitors remain first-line agents for hypertension management. They are particularly effective in young (<55 years) non-black patients and have demonstrated significant cardiovascular protection benefits beyond blood pressure reduction.
  • Option C. Calcium Channel Blocker - Calcium channel blockers are recommended as first-line therapy, especially for older patients and black patients of any age. Their efficacy in reducing blood pressure and stroke prevention has been well-established in multiple clinical trials.
  • Option D. Diuretics - Thiazide and thiazide-like diuretics (particularly at low doses of 12.5-25 mg/day) remain first-line agents for hypertension management. They effectively reduce cardiovascular morbidity and mortality while being cost-effective.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Current evidence-based approach to uncomplicated hypertension management recommends ACE inhibitors/ARBs, calcium channel blockers, and thiazide diuretics as first-line therapy, while beta blockers have been relegated to second or third-line options except in specific compelling indications like post-MI or heart failure.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs, when combined with Thiazide diuretics, is least effective in further reducing blood pressure? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Beta Blocker

 

Explanation

 

When Thiazide diuretics are used to manage hypertension, they are often combined with other antihypertensive drugs to achieve target blood pressure levels. The effectiveness of these combinations can vary. Among the options provided, the combination of a Thiazide diuretic and a Beta Blocker is generally considered to be least effective in providing additional synergistic blood pressure reduction and has a less favorable overall profile compared to the other listed combinations for many patients.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option ACE Inhibitor + Thiazide: This is a highly effective and commonly recommended combination. Thiazide diuretics can increase renin activity, and ACE inhibitors counteract this effect, leading to a synergistic reduction in blood pressure.
  • Option B. ARB (Angiotensin II Receptor Blocker) + Thiazide: Similar to ACE inhibitors, ARBs also block the renin-angiotensin system, leading to a strong synergistic effect when combined with thiazide diuretics. This is also a highly effective and recommended combination.
  • D. Calcium Channel Blocker + Thiazide: This is also a very effective combination. Calcium channel blockers cause vasodilation, and thiazides reduce fluid volume. These different mechanisms of action complement each other well, leading to significant blood pressure reduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of a Beta Blocker with a Thiazide diuretic is generally considered the least effective or least favorable option among the choices due to a less optimal balance of efficacy, synergistic effect, and potential for adverse metabolic consequences compared to combinations with ACE inhibitors, ARBs, or Calcium Channel Blockers.

questions.text: Which of the following is known as a "Peakless" Insulin? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Insulin Glargine

 

Explanation:

 

Insulin Glargine is classified as a "peakless" insulin because it maintains a relatively constant blood level without pronounced concentration spikes. It belongs to the ultra-long acting insulin category along with insulin detemir and degludec. These insulins provide steady basal insulin levels, significantly reducing hypoglycemia risk. Insulin glargine has an onset of action of 2-4 hours and provides coverage for approximately 24 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Regular Insulin: This short-acting insulin shows a distinct peak of action at 2-3 hours after administration. With an onset of 0.5-1 hour and duration of 6-8 hours, its pronounced peak makes it unsuitable for basal insulin coverage.
  • Option C. NPH Insulin: As an intermediate-acting insulin, NPH demonstrates a definite peak at 8-10 hours post-administration. Its duration spans 12-20 hours, making it far from "peakless" in its activity profile.
  • Option D. Insulin Glulisine: This rapid-acting insulin analog shows a pronounced peak at 1-2 hours after administration. With a short duration of only 3-5 hours, it's specifically designed for mealtime coverage rather than steady basal insulin provision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ultra-long-acting insulins like glargine provide steady blood levels without pronounced peaks, making them ideal for basal insulin replacement with minimal hypoglycemia risk.

choices.text: Seizures are not reversed by Naloxone

questions.text: All of the following statements about Pethidine/Meperidine are true, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Has pronounced Antitussive action

 

Explanation:

 

Pethidine (Meperidine) is an opioid analgesic that lacks significant antitussive effects. It does not effectively suppress cough, which is an important distinguishing feature from morphine and codeine, which are effective cough suppressants.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Has significant Antimuscarinic effects - Pethidine was originally synthesized as an atropine substitute and retains antimuscarinic properties. It produces effects like dry mouth, blurred vision, and tachycardia due to these anticholinergic actions.
  • Option B. Has pronounced Antidiuretic Properties - Opioids, including pethidine, have antidiuretic effects that can lead to urinary retention, which is one of their known side effects.
  • Option D. Seizures are not reversed by Naloxone - Seizures associated with pethidine result from accumulation of its metabolite norpethidine, which has excitatory effects. While naloxone reverses respiratory depression and other opioid effects, it doesn't counteract these excitatory seizure-inducing properties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pethidine differs from other opioids by having antimuscarinic properties and producing excitatory metabolites, while lacking effective cough suppression activity, making it unsuitable for treating cough.

questions.text: Which of the following carbapenems is not advised for the treatment of nosocomial infections? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Ertapenem

 

Explanation:

 

Ertapenem is not advised for treating nosocomial infections because it has poor activity against Pseudomonas, Acinetobacter, MRSA, penicillin-resistant Strep. pneumoniae, and atypical respiratory pathogens. These organisms are common causes of hospital-acquired infections. Ertapenem has a more limited spectrum compared to other carbapenems, making it less suitable for the complex, often resistant pathogens encountered in hospital settings.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Imipenem - This is an extremely potent and broad-spectrum β-lactam antibiotic whose range of activity includes gram-positive cocci, Enterobacteriaceae, Ps. aeruginosa, Listeria as well as anaerobes. It has proven effective in treating serious hospital-acquired respiratory, urinary, abdominal, pelvic, skin and soft tissue infections.
  • Option C. Meropenem - Meropenem is somewhat more potent on gram-negative aerobes, especially Ps. aeruginosa. It is a reserve drug for the treatment of serious nosocomial infections like septicaemia, febrile neutropenia, intraabdominal and pelvic infections.
  • Option D. Doripenem - Doripenem has antimicrobial activity similar to meropenem, but is more active against some resistant Pseudomonas. Its clinical indications are similar to meropenem, including treatment of nosocomial infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ertapenem differs from other carbapenems in its inability to treat Pseudomonas infections, making it unsuitable for nosocomial infections where Pseudomonas is a common pathogen.

questions.text: Which of the following aminoglycosides is associated with more cochlear toxicity than vestibular toxicity? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Kanamycin

 

Explanation:

 

Kanamycin is associated with more cochlear toxicity than vestibular toxicity. Aminoglycosides cause ototoxicity affecting either vestibular or cochlear function, with different drugs showing preferential toxicity to one area. Kanamycin primarily damages the cochlear portion of the inner ear, leading to hearing loss rather than balance disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Streptomycin  - Streptomycin primarily causes vestibular toxicity. It produces more vestibular than cochlear toxicity, making it more likely to cause dizziness, vertigo, and ataxia rather than hearing impairment. Streptomycin has the highest vestibular toxicity among aminoglycosides.
  • Option B. Tobramycin  - Tobramycin has intermediate cochlear and vestibular toxicity. It is not specifically characterized by predominant cochlear toxicity. Its toxicity profile is more balanced between vestibular and cochlear effects.
  • Option D. Sisomicin - Sisomicin, like gentamicin, tends to cause more vestibular toxicity than cochlear toxicity. It is not characterized by predominant cochlear damage. Its toxicity profile is similar to gentamicin but with somewhat lower overall ototoxicity.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Different aminoglycosides have varying ototoxic profiles, with kanamycin predominantly causing cochlear damage (hearing loss), while streptomycin primarily causes vestibular damage (balance disorders).
